PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 14 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned South Australian citizens respectfully showeth:
That:
The South Australian and Australian National Railways systems were intended to provide essential transport services to country, semi-isolated and isolated regions;
Australian National Railways' large increases in freight and parcel rates are forcing people to use Australia Post and road transport services;
Country businesses are suffering as a result of Australian National Railways' freight and parcel rate increases;
At the direction of the Federal Government, the Australian National Railways Commission is destroying country rail services in South Australia;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will urgently review the freight increases imposed by Australian National Railways and require the Commissioner to-
Reduce freight and parcel rates to reasonable levels
Encourage greater public utilisation of the Commission's services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: TEAGUE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 9 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 20 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That in recent years thousands of families have lost their homes, the building industry and employment is at an all time low, with social disruption from continued increases in interest rates.
All this, in our opinion, is due to extortionate interest rates that have passed the bounds of all reason and void of equity and moral justification.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board, also in the political arena a conscience vote is essential.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON; MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Macklin I present the following petition from 55 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners do not want a uranium enrichment plant constructed in south-east Queensland because:
(a) There is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) There has not been an environment impact study conducted into the effects of such a uranium enrichment plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) The risk to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) The products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) The local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) The investment in such a uranium enrichment plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) Legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of products from uranium enrichment plants;
(b) Reject all applications for the export of products from uranium enrichment plants;
(c) Legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in uranium enrichment plants;
(d) Reject all applications for foreign investment in uranium enrichment plants ;
(e) Do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a uranium enrichment plant in south-east Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WATSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 14 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only church built in Lithuania after World War II;
(2) This church was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August, 1960 and confiscated in 1961 under the direct order of Mr Kruschev.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to raise with its counterpart in the USSR the great concern of many Australians that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the religious worshippers of Klaipeda in Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GIETZELT; KEEFFE

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Keeffe I present the following petition from 16 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) Many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) The Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(a) Express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) Urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 12 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within four years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GILES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1306 citizens of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that some single supporting parents are unfairly disadvantaged in having chosen to care for children fulltime during the formative years, believing such care was essential to their well-being; and that women without dependent children, and who are under 50 years of age are not eligible for a continuous pension. These women have devoted their whole lives to their families and do not have skills relevant to the present employment situation. Their future prospects, with increasing age and length of time out of the work force are a deterrent to employers. Skilled workers find it difficult to obtain employment and unskilled workers find it even more difficult. Unemployment benefit was not designed for long term usage and the low rate of payment plus the work tests over a long period of time lead to a general decline in the physical and mental health, with the result that the women are being placed on sickness benefits. Sickness benefits, however, were also designed for short term usage and is unable to provide security for these women.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(i) Amend the Social Services Act to reduce the age of eligibility for a Class B Widow's pension from 50 to 40 years; and
(ii) Expand existing training schemes to include women taken off Supporting Parent's Benefit.
(iii) Provide rehabilitation for women with disabilities which preclude them from the paid work force.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Our opinion on paper: That ever since the early seventies, high interest rates of staggering magnitude have made a complete mockery of justice, unparalleled in our time, resulting in the elimination of employment on a vast scale, in every phase of production causing house ejections, with mind effects and mental disturbances, leading to interrupted education, road toll and social disruption.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge politicians of all parties to nationally unite for the return of justice by using the powers vested in them to immediately and drastically reduce these destructive interest rates. Further and to this end a conscience vote is essential, if justice is to be served.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, M.P.-

That the continuing high level of tax avoidance and evasion is cause for grave concern for honest Australian taxpayers, and demands stringent and immediate action by the Commonwealth, noting in particular:
1. The latest estimate by the Australian Taxpayers' Association is that $7,000m a year is being lost in taxation revenue;

PETITION.TITLE: University of South Australia: Discipline of Modern Greek

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 4,292 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth:
1. Greek language and literature have a long and highly respected history, and Modern Greek is taught and researched in Universities throughout the world,

2. The increase in the number of students at schools and Universities who wish the opportunity to complete a full range of education by studying Modern Greek at University, Post Graduate and even doctrinal level,

PETITION.TITLE: Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament

SPEECH.SPEAKER: WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —The petition I present from 60 citizens of Australia was received by me during the parliamentary recess. The Minister for Communications referred to in the text is the former Minister for Communications and not the present Minister. I present the petition.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public respect for the Government and the institution of Parliament is diminished by the non-disclosure of pecuniary interests of Ministers of the Government.

That on 2nd August 1979, the Minister for Communications announced through the Parliamentary Press Gallery that he had agreed to repay in 3 instalments of $100 ,000 at 10 per cent interest the sum of $300,000 which had been misappropriated.

Your petitioners call upon the Senate to take steps to implement the recommendations on disclosure of the Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament, 1975, agreed to by Committee members of all political parties.

In particular, your petitioners call upon the Senate to restore respect for the Parliamentary system by seeking a declaration from the Minister for Communications as to whether he has made the $100,000 repayment due on February 1st 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Take legislative action to reduce and ultimately remove lead concentrates from motor spirit in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the previous South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, and his former Liberal Government for their total neglect of the State's ailing manufacturing industries and their failure to act to stop the job rot;

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Sir John Carrick, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and it follows a question that I asked yesterday. I now ask the Minister: Was Mr Arnis Verbickis, the Government Information Unit officer based in Melbourne, attached to the staff of Sir Phillip Lynch until Sir Phillip's recent retirement? Will the Minister give an assurance that Mr Verbickis has not been and will not be involved on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia in the by-election campaign for Sir Phillip's former seat of Flinders? For the reassurance of senators, will the Minister tender a statement of the duties performed on a daily basis by Mr Verbickis since the announcement of Sir Phillip Lynch's retirement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Government Information Unit officers come under the Minister for Administrative Services who is in another place. I do not have the details that have been requested. I shall refer the question to the Minister in another place and seek the information.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. Can consideration be given to attaching small warning lights to the sides of Australian National Railways locomotives operating in Tasmania as a safety measure to help prevent level crossing accidents after dark?

—Questions similar to this one have been raised in the Senate over the years. I myself raised a question along these lines in relation to level crossing accidents some years ago. I understand that there are considerable difficulties in regard to keeping lights clean, and that sort of thing. Nevertheless, it is time that the matter was examined again. I undertake to refer it to the Minister and to obtain an early reply for Senator Watson.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Is it true that a multi-million dollar fraud involving international airline tickets has been discovered whereby travel agents in Australia have been importing airline ticket coupons from New Zealand which, because of the exchange rates, are 30 per cent cheaper than the same tickets bought in Australia? The travel agent then fills in the ticket stating that the journey starts and finishes in New Zealand in order to give it legitimacy and consequently sells it at a cheaper price. Apparently, however, the fraud arises when the airline on whose ticketing the flight coupons are written redeems them in New Zealand and gets paid in New Zealand currency which is a lot less than the applicable fare level in Australian dollars. I now ask the Minister whether the travel agent involved is liable for prosecution and whether passengers who, knowingly or otherwise, participate in the scheme run the danger of being charged the full legitimate cost of the ticket or, alternatively, of being offloaded from their flight.

—This is the first time that this scheme has been brought to my attention. I have not seen reports of it before. There have been examples of this kind of activity in respect of various types of schemes along lines similar to those outlined by Senator Sibraa. I would need to check out the details. If Senator Sibraa has any further information as to the detail of the scheme and how it operates, perhaps he would care to supply it to the Minister. It seems to be one of those schemes which could be used in current circumstances, given the relative values of currencies between this country and others and the changes that occur from time to time. So, the best course is that I should refer the whole matter to the Minister for Aviation and seek an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the Government's survey of the experiences of young people entering the job market announced yesterday by Mr Macphee. Is the Minister aware that the shortage of jobs for youth in Tasmania is more acute than in any other State, as indicated by the greater percentage of Tasmanian youth, per head of population, who have never held a job? Will the Minister ensure that a close examination is made of the Tasmanian situation, either in the current project or in a separate survey?

—My attention has been drawn to the report referred to by Senator Walters. She is correct. There is a difficult employment situation for youth in Tasmania. The proportion of the youth labour force which has never held a job is 10.8 per cent, as compared with the national average of 4.8 per cent. On the other hand, there has been some preliminary analysis by the Bureau of Labour Market Research that suggests that Commonwealth youth programs have provided greater than average assistance to unemployed youth in Tasmania. Given the general position, I suppose that that is not surprising if those programs are effectively getting to the youth who require them. Two studies are currently being conducted which will also give insight into the Tasmanian youth labour market situation. There is a study on youth employment patterns in Australia and an analysis of youth placed in manpower programs over 1980-81. They may meet the purpose which the honourable senator sought in her question. I will refer the question to the Minister and ask him to keep an eye on the matter as those surveys become available.

—Did the Minister representing the Treasurer notice news items today that the Custom Credit Corporation Ltd has announced a record profit of $ 30.8m, a massive 26 per cent increase on the previous year? Does she agree that this was yet another in a series of huge profit gains by credit and hire purchase houses? Do these organisations charge effective interest rates as high as 30 per cent? In these circumstances does the Minister not agree that these businesses are fundamentally a pack of usurers shamefully exploiting a depressed and vulnerable community at this time? In view of the huge sums of money they transact, are not these Shylocks a major factor in the Government's failure to control inflation in this country? Is it a fact that the Government's surrender- -
—What exactly do you mean by 'Shylocks'? A religious connotation perhaps.

—I know that honourable senators opposite do not like the question . I mean Shylocks. There is no religious connotation whatsoever. I want to make that point clear to Senator Baume. I mean usurers when I say 'Shylocks'. Is it a fact that the Government's surrender to the banks over making more money available for housing will permit the banks to continue to exploit Australians through their hire purchase and other high interest charging subsidiaries? Will the Government, urgently, publicly investigate this huge area of community rip- off and take the necessary controlling action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the record profit that Senator Mason said was made by Custom Credit Corporation Ltd. In the final part of his question he asked whether the Government would urgently investigate the hire purchase sector of financing. I will refer that matter to the Treasurer for his comment at a later stage.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. I want to press one aspect of my question of the Minister. Does she not agree that these businesses are fundamentally a pack of usurers shamefully exploiting this community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question referred to one company, Custom Credit. The supplementary question, if that is what it was, referred to a group of people lumped together as if I am able to decide who else may be usurers. The question stated certain attitudes. Part of it referred to an investigation. I will refer that to the Treasurer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that there is growing concern among those interested in film culture in Australia about the way in which censorship is now operating in this country? While accepting that the problem stems from the fact that the censorship regulations make no distinction between commercial cinema and the genuine artistic interests of organisations such as film festivals and the Australian Film Institute, is it not true that the arrangements worked satisfactorily for some years under a 1975 agreement which admitted the festival films without censorship provided certain conditions, such as limiting screenings to subscribers and to over 18-year-olds only, were met? Has this fair and workable understanding been unilaterally abrogated by the Film Censorship Board, which now imposes tougher censorship restrictions on film festivals than it does on ordinary commercial cinemas? Will the inevitable consequence be that the Sydney and Melbourne film festivals will lose their formal international recognition-a devastating blow to the development of film culture in this country?

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister prepared to accept the political embarrassment of our two film festivals losing international recognition because of our unacceptable censorship attitudes, while film festivals in communist countries such as Russia and Czechoslovakia can meet the international film censorship standards? Will the Minister do his best to ensure that the censorship regulations are administered with sensitivity and common sense, qualities conspicuously lacking at the moment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perhaps the first time that anyone has suggested to me that the communist countries are a model of liberalism in their approach to the arts. I am sure that a whole generation of painters, poets and dancers will be terribly relieved.
—And writers.

—And writers, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle reminds me. I am sure that they all will be relieved to know that in the area of film censorship communist countries are in the forefront of liberalism. The Acting Attorney- General is aware that there is concern among people who are interested in film culture in Australia about the way that censorship is operating. That is a matter which arises from the fact that a number of films which were of interest to festivals have been subjected to censorship. It has always been the case that films which are to be shown at film festivals are subject to the same censorship rules as apply to other films. In other words, if they contain material which would be regarded as offensive generally, the fact that they are exhibition films does not make any difference.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Hamer said, there was an arrangement in 1975 that related to obtaining entry of films without undue delays but it did not involve any formal exemption from censorship requirements. In any event, because the matter has been one of concern-it is an area which is not solely one of Commonwealth responsibility because the States control what is exhibited in the States; the Commonwealth merely has control over importation-it is currently to be the subject of discussions between Commonwealth and State officials to see whether the concerns which Senator Hamer has raised can be met. I will ensure that the concerns expressed by Senator Hamer are drawn to the attention of the Acting Attorney-General so that he, in turn, can make sure that the matters raised are taken into account in those discussions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPORT OF SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation which was brought up in the Senate on 26 October. The Minister will be aware that there is great interest in this report in the industrial relations community. Can the Minister advise when we can expect a response from the Government in respect thereto?

—I agree with Senator Harradine that there is a high degree of interest, perhaps it is wrong to say in the report but in the general area which is dealt with in the legislation which is the subject of the report. That interest is evident in the industrial relations community. I have within the last few days discussed the response to the Senate Committee report with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee. He has indicated to me that he is giving consideration to the matters which have been raised by the Senate Committee and that, after giving consideration to that report, he proposes to bring the matter before the Government. I do not know precisely when that matter will come before the Government but I expect the delay not to be great. However, looking at the rest of this parliamentary session and at the rather heavy legislative load that we have, I would imagine that we would be unlikely to deal further with the report or with the legislation during the current sittings.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. With reference to action taken by the Commonwealth to prevent unfair trading in goods imported into Australia, how many dumping cases are currently before the Department of Industry and Commerce? How does this situation compare with the situation of, say, three months ago or 12 months ago? Have steps been taken to balance the staff available to deal with the number of claims requiring attention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is some mark of the concern which is felt about the state of manufacturing industry that the question of dumping and measures which might be taken against dumping have been raised on a number of occasions during the current parliamentary session. I have some information on that matter. I understand there are 68 cases on hand at the moment, with another 19 cases projected. That compares with 55 cases on hand three months ago and 51 cases on hand a year ago. So there has been some increase in the number of anti-dumping applications which have been brought before the Commonwealth recently.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of the resources, steps have been taken to make sure that adequate staff and resources are available. It is hoped therefore that no backlog will develop. The claims which are being made are across a range of subject matters. However, I do not think that is a matter raised by the question. There has not been a very substantial increase in number but, in any event, because there has been some increase, steps have been taken to look to the staffing situation required to deal with those applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen the article in today's Melbourne Age wherein the Senate of Roman Catholic Priests has condemned the Philippines Ambassador for statements he made concerning the Catholic Church in the Philippines? Is the Australian Embassy in that country acting in support of Father Gore, the Australian priest currently before Philippine courts? Will the Australian Government give consideration to the curtailment of aid to the Marcos regime while christian missionaries and others are denied basic human rights in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have given reports on Father Gore in response to earlier questions. There have been reports of charges against Father Gore. The Philippine authorities have advised our Embassy in Manila that reported plans to file murder charges are untrue. The authorities have also advised that, due to the absence in Manila of the case officer, there is some possibility of a deferment of the court hearing that is scheduled for 10 November. We are awaiting advice from the Embassy official who travelled to Kabankalan on 9 November. The Department of Foreign Affairs has kept in close touch with the parents of Father Gore. Our Embassy in Manila has certainly been active with regard to the rights of Father Gore and the reported charges.

ANSWER.PARA: The last question, relating to foreign aid and the withdrawal of our support, is a matter which I am not able to address. I will refer it to my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and seek a response. From the number of occasions that I have made comments about Father Gore, I think it will be obvious that our Embassy is active on his behalf. We have sought whatever reports are available and have kept in close contact with the case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for National Development and Energy noted an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald reporting in detail achievements of various Western European governments in preserving energy by burning thousands of tonnes of garbage? The article quotes a spokesman for Britain's Energy Department as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: We reckon that if waste-burning for energy was widely adopted, Britain could save the energy equivalent of 5 million tonnes of coal or about $425 million a year.

Can the Minister inform the Senate whether his Department has conducted any studies on this very efficient way to save energy and at the same time to solve the ever increasing problem of disposal of household waste?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a report in yesterday's Press on the use of garbage as a replacement for coal, oil or other fuels. My Department has a keen interest in alternative fuels. I am not aware of any research on garbage being undertaken in Australia but it is an attractive and interesting subject. I will direct the question to my Department, seek what information is available and also put the matter under study to see whether it would be a suitable research project.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and is supplementary to that asked by Senator Primmer concerning the general question of aid to the Philippines in the light of its treatment of an Australian national, Father Gore. I ask: Given the pattern of harrassment, planting of evidence, concocting of charges and indefinite detention by the military and its lackeys, of which Father Gore is only the latest victim, will the Australian Government immediately terminate any assistance to the Philippine military, which assistance is running at the rate of over $1,343,000 this year? Can the Minister explain why Australian taxpayers should fund even partially a corrupt and brutal military regime which thereby has more of its own money to spend on the suppression of the poor, the oppressed and the downtrodden of that sad nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Although this question has more detail than the one asked by Senator Primmer, again I am not able to respond on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I will refer the matter to him. I will draw his attention to the sentiments that have been expressed and seek a response from him with regard to the aid program. As I have said with regard to the particular instance, there has been active representation by the Embassy on behalf of Father Gore. As far as that matter is concerned, I am not able to take further the reports that I have already given on the general question. I will see if there is an early response that can be given.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education. I refer to an article in today's Australian in which it is stated that the professorial board at Monash University has agreed to limit the number of overseas students entering the first-year engineering course. It is doing that to make room for more Australian students. At a time when Australia should be training additional engineers, the number of engineering department staff at universities and colleges of advanced education is being reduced because of lack of funds. Will the Government look at this whole matter of the anticipated need for engineers over the next few years? If it is felt appropriate will it make a special allocation that is directed to be spent in the engineering and allied disciplines in the universities and colleges of advanced education?

—Although I saw this morning's Australian my attention was not drawn to the article referred to by Senator Townley. I will seek advice from the Tertiary Education Commission on the article and on any implications which flow from the decision which may have been made. I want to be able to examine the policy implications of such a limitation. I must say that this country does have regional responsibilities which include responsibilities in education. It is for that reason that we sponsor a large number of students in this country. We have a large number of overseas students who are here in a sponsored capacity on bilateral arrangements. I think their places in universities and engineering schools would be safeguarded. The difficulty seems to arise in relation to private overseas students. This is indicated particularly in the mail which comes to honourable senators in relation to private overseas students who are not sponsored and who are here under different arrangements. It is in relation to things like fees and places for these students that some of the difficulties and policy questions arise. I will put the article referred to by Senator Townley under study and let him know after I have consulted with my officers.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has recently gone back on a 1978 commitment not to alienate unalienated Crown land under claim by Aborigines? As the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act is a joint Commonwealth-Northern Territory agreement, what is the Minister's position in this matter? Will he give an assurance that he will do all that he can to protect the interests of the Aboriginal people in the Warramunga land claim?

—There can be no question that this Government will protect the interests of Aboriginal people as it has done in the past and in line with commitments which have been given by a series of Ministers. I am aware that the Northern Territory gave an undertaking which was for a prescribed period. It indicated a period during which it would not take certain action to alienate some areas of land. I think I am correct in saying that when that time expired the Northern Territory Government continued not to alienate land. It was at that time that negotiations were going on in relation to some matters concerning the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and possible amendments to that Act. My understanding is that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is still pursuing actively the question of possible amendments. To that end he is still negotiating with the Northern Territory Government and with the land councils. I would not like to see anything happen that would put those negotiations into any kind of jeopardy. I am not aware of the decision to which Senator Robertson referred, and which was the basis of his question, that certain land was proposed to be alienated.
—Has been alienated.

—Senator Robertson interjects that it has been alienated. I will have to get information from the Minister whom I represent in this place and seek his advice. I will make that information known to Senator Robertson.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Pastoralists in the Northern Territory are now destocking their leases and restocking with clean cattle in an effort to meet the deadline for tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication. I ask: In view of these endeavours, will further compensation funds be made available to continue this impetus if present allocations prove to be insufficient? With the increase in the Commonwealth contribution, can the Minister advise what amount has been spent on compensation in each year to date, and what is estimated to be spent this financial year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need to assure Senator Kilgariff of the importance of the campaign to which he refers. It would, of course, be a very significant blow to our export prospects if Australia did not eradicate brucellosis and tuberculosis. I know that Senator Kilgariff is not questioning the importance of what has been undertaken. The specific question of additional Commonwealth funds being made available in 1982-83 would have to be considered along with other matters concerning the Additional Estimates. I would have to refer that question to the Minister for Primary Industry for his consideration, in light of the apparent demand for additional funds for the campaign this year.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the amount that has been spent on compensation in each year to date, it is estimated that the Commonwealth's share of compensation for the Northern Territory in this financial year will be $1.576m. As at 30 September we had paid $87,000 or 16 per cent of that total amount. It appears to me to be fairly doubtful, on that indication, that we will need additional funds. I have a table which shows the figures for the national campaign on an annual basis from 1973-74 to 1981-82. Also, I have figures for payments from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory for the period 1978-79 to 1981-82. I seek leave to incorporate those two sets of figures in Hansard.
The Commonwealth contribution to compensation for the national campaign is as follows:
Payments from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory are as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The information for the years prior to 1978- 79, if required, will take longer to obtain due to alterations in funding arrangements.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. What statement can the Government offer the Australian community in response to the recent report of the United States House of Representatives Defence Appropriations Committee, which suggested serious doubts about the capacity of the F18 McDonnell Douglas Hornet to defend effectively naval vessels or to escort bombers launched from those vessels? What mechanisms of review does the Government intend to activate in light of the report, measured against its plans to purchase 75 Hornet fighters at an approximate cost of $1,785m? Finally, can the Government give an assurance that the Australian defence mission to Washington, headed by Air Vice-Marshal Newham, will be free to conduct a full and exhaustive examination of F18 capabilities without being restricted by existing Government policy and commitments in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the doubts in relation to the F18 to which Senator Ray refers concern an aircraft modified for flight off aircraft carriers . As such, it would have a different purpose from the one which it is envisaged would be operated by the Royal Australian Air Force. I understand that the chief difference between the aeroplane that would be used in the United States Navy context, and our own, would be in regard to the attachment of certain fuel tanks , which would not take place in the case of the Australian aircraft. For that reason, as I understand it, the kinds of considerations that have been mentioned in the report to which Senator Ray has referred would have very little application to the Australian aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: The other part of the honourable senator's question referred to the freedom of operation of our investigating team in the United States on questions of this kind. Of course I give the assurance that we will examine in very great depth questions as to the applicability of the aircraft for our use. These are matters upon which the Australian Government would need to be satisfied to the nth degree. Consequently, we will be taking every action possible in that regard. I acknowledge the concern that has been expressed in the media in the last day about the matter. I again emphasise that we are talking about aircraft in different situations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that the value of goods which can be brought into Australia by travellers returning from overseas has been fixed under the Customs Act at $200 for the last 19 years? Would the Minister not agree that there have been very significant increases in costs combined with a considerable change in the value of the Australian dollar during those years? For example, in recent times there has been a 20 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar with respect to the United States dollar. Will the Minister undertake to re-establish the duty free value of goods in this category in line with the original intention of the Act?
—No.

—Has the Minister for Social Security completed his review of the guidelines for field officers investigating single parents and possible de facto relationships? If so, will he release them so that members of parliament and welfare workers who are consulted by single parents can properly advise them of their rights and obligations rather than their receiving hearsay information which may be inaccurate?

—As I have previously advised the Senate, the question of those guidelines has been referred to a working party of officers selected from different parts of Australia. I am awaiting a report on its deliberations on them. The intention is to have a set of guidelines which can be used nationally in a very difficult area. I think those guidelines will be available, in any event, after 1 December. Parts of them may not be available because unfortunately there are some problems with respect to people attempting to defraud the Commonwealth. It may be that I will not release certain information because it relates to methods of detection. I will examine the request made by the honourable senator and see what can be made available.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs recall my question asked in the Senate on 19 August this year regarding allegations that Philippine women who have married Australian men, as a result of the activities of certain marriage agencies, have been beaten, given little or no money and have been kept virtual prisoners in their husbands' houses. Does the Minister know when the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will reply to my request of last August that the Australian Government consider legislating to require that these women be given, in advance of migrating to Australia, full information on their legal rights in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not recall the question. I think it was probably addressed to Senator Durack, who represented the Minister at that time. I note that the question was asked in August and that the response has not yet been received. I can only refer it again to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and seek an early response.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I have had reports from a number of pensioner patients who claim that they have been asked to sign blank forms at the end of a medical consultation and have not been given a duplicate copy of the record of the medical visit. As this could be a temptation to doctors to abuse the medical benefits system, I ask the Minister to take urgent remedial action to prevent this practice by issuing a directive to social security recipients not to sign blank forms for consultations and to insist on a properly completed duplicate for each medical visit.
—That is a matter which lies within the responsibility of the Minister for Health. I will draw the question to his attention. I know that he has the matter under consideration at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. Is it a fact that over 12 months ago the Rotary Club of Moruya carried out a feasibility study for a direct toll road between Canberra and the coast and submitted its proposals to both the New South Wales and Federal governments as a potential Bicentennial project? In view of the economic benefits and significant fuel savings that such a toll road would generate, has the Federal Government pressed the New South Wales Government to examine this project, or has the Wran Government taken the view 'there are no votes in it for me'?

—Once again we are indebted to Senator Reid for bringing to our attention matters of great concern to the residents of the Australian Capital Territory. Unfortunately, I have no immediate information on the road matter which she has raised, but I will refer the question to my colleague the Minister for Transport and obtain an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that the Bureau of the World Heritage Committee has requested the Australian Government to provide 'a statement of intent regarding the construction of dams on the possibility of extending the protected area of South West Tasmania and establishing a co- ordinated mechanism to manage this site'? Has the Bureau requested this statement of intent from the Australian Government? What arrangements have been made to provide a reply to the information requested by the Bureau? Who in fact has the responsibility to forward Australia's response on this matter? Will the answers be provided before the World Heritage Committee meets, I think in December or early February?

—Senator Button will know that I am not the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment; I only represent him in this place. I have with me some information regarding South West Tasmania and issues relating to it, but it does not cover the matters about which he has asked, which relate quite specifically to a statement of intent and the way that that will be responded to. It will be necessary to refer that to Mr McVeigh. I will try to get the answer within the time frame indicated by Senator Button.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR SERVICES BETWEEN MELBOURNE AND CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. It relates to the small number and unsatisfactory times of daily air services presently operating between Melbourne and Canberra and to the subsequent effect which this is having on access to the nation's capital. While I recognise that for economic reasons there is a need for rationalisation in the aviation industry, is the Minister aware that only four daily flights operate from Melbourne to Canberra and four daily flights from Canberra to Melbourne, compared with up to six daily flights from Sydney to Canberra and up to seven daily flights from Canberra to Sydney? Is the Minister also aware that the last flight available from Canberra to Melbourne departs at 5 p.m.? In view of the inconvenience caused to businessmen, parliamentarians and tourists travelling between Melbourne and Canberra, what reason is given for the appallingly small number of flights operating between Canberra and the southern States, especially when compared with the comparatively high number scheduled to and from Sydney?
—Not only the numbers but also the times.

—And the times; I do want to know about the bad times as well. Will consideration be given by the Government to ensuring an increase in the number of services available between Canberra and Melbourne and in particular to making an early evening service available to people wishing to commute from Canberra to Melbourne?

—I understand the situation is that timetables in respect of airline services between Canberra and Melbourne, or any other place for that matter, are subject to review by the Secretary of the Department of Aviation. But the schedules can be disallowed only in the event of there being safety difficulties. The Government is unable to consider schedules on the basis of public interest along the general lines that Senator Missen outlined in his question relating to the actual scheduling of flights. Of course, that boils down very largely to a question of operational judgment on the part of the individual airlines. Honourable senators would be aware that in recent times there has been an attempt to reduce the number of cancellations which have caused inconvenience to passengers in the past.
—TAA cancelled one yesterday from Hobart.

—I understand that this still does occur, but the airlines have been encouraged to rationalise their services as much as possible to provide a better service more closely related to demand. While the frequency question raised by Senator Missen in his question is also essentially a matter for the airlines to determine, it is something that could be brought to the attention of the Minister for Aviation to see whether he can use his good offices with the airlines to encourage a more rational time frame that may suit the services which Senator Missen obviously requires.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I was not in my question concerned only with the power of the Government or the Parliament to disallow; I was concerned with whether the Government will talk to the airlines to try to find a rational system whereby a proper service to the nation's capital can be provided. Will the Minister take this matter up with the airlines so that something better can be done?
—I indicated that I would refer that part of the question to the Minister and I will do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In the context of the Minister's guarantee when he was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and its reiteration by the present Minister, does the Federal Government's guarantee extend to the islands of Curacoa, Esk, Falcon, Eclipse, Brisk and Havannah as part of the Palm Island Aboriginal Reserve? If the answer is in the affirmative, what action is contemplated to ensure that these islands are not excluded from the deed of grant in trust to the Aboriginal community of Palm Island?

—As I understand Senator Macklin's question, it relates to the guarantees concerning the integrity of reserves for the purposes of the issue of deeds of grant in trust. I take it that is the correct understanding. The Commonwealth guarantee extended to the integrity of reserve boundaries. Clearly, I do not know the boundaries which make up the reserve of the Palm Island community. I know Great Palm Island is the main island, but how many of the surrounding islands are included within the reserve boundaries I am not able to confirm or deny for the honourable senator. As the question requires a specific examination of the boundaries of the Palm Island Aboriginal reserve and because it relates to the guarantee which we gave, I think the answer should be precise. I understand Senator Macklin's concern that he should understand the extent of the guarantee. I will undertake to find from Mr Wilson the appropriate answer for him.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Can the Minister indicate when that answer will be available?
—It is not an answer which will come from me or my office. I undertake to get it as expeditiously as I am able.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources aware that all petroleum supplies to the remote town of Weipa on Cape York are imported directly from Singapore by Mobil Oil Australia Ltd, as this method is cheaper than obtaining supplies from the company's sources in Melbourne, and that Mobil is the sole supplier to Weipa? As the direct importation of fuel from Singapore makes Weipa a port of entry, the Commonwealth fuel subsidy as determined by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority is only 1.5c a litre in Weipa compared to about 5c a litre in Mount Isa, Cooktown and other northern parts of Queensland. As the supply of petrol to the residents of Weipa makes the subsidy situation there unique, will the Minister consider making an exception to the rule by altering the standing of Weipa as a port of entry to afford to its 2,500 residents the compensation that similar remote communities are entitled to in the form of a full fuel subsidy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will direct the question to the appropriate Minister and ask him to give it consideration.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an organisation which calls itself People for Nuclear Disarmament and to a printed publication of this organisation called the PND Newsletter which seeks donations from the public to assist in the administration of the organisation. In the newsletter I refer to PND directs that the donations are tax deductible if made to the Australian Conservation Foundation and that they should be made with a request that they be used for the purpose of People for Nuclear Disarmament. Can the Minister advise the Senate why PND should indirectly receive the privilege of tax deductibility for donations made in this way? Will the Government take action to have the matter reviewed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am advised that donations made to an organisation such as People for Nuclear Disarmament do not qualify for tax deduction in terms of the specific provisions of the income tax law relating to gifts. Gifts to the value of $2 and upwards made to the Australian Conservation Foundation are, however, allowable as deductions under the gift provisions of the income tax law. Accordingly, provided that the Foundation is free to apply a gift of money in whatever manner it sees fit, subject to the limitations provided by its constitution, the amount of the gift will qualify as a deduction .

ANSWER.PARA: I am further informed that notwithstanding that a donor of money to the Foundation might express a preference for the gift to be directed to a particular activity, it is the general practice that no guarantee or undertaking is given by the Foundation that the donation will be applied in that way. The Foundation would be free to use such a gift for any purposes that it chooses, pursuant to its objects, and in these circumstances the gift would qualify for deduction under the relevant provision of the law. Senator Kilgariff has asked that there be some review of this type of indirect deductibility that is obtained by the organisation mentioned by him. I would refer that matter to the Treasurer, but, as I have said, the income tax law has the provisions as I have outlined them, and the Foundation would be free to use a gift made to it in whatever form it chose. If what has been stated by Senator Kilgariff in advertising from the People for Nuclear Disarmament is a fact, I shall see that the Treasurer directs his attention to that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister been given advice that pensions do not count as income when the Department of Social Security wants to refuse the payment of sickness benefit under section 108 (c) of the Social Services Act? If that is so, has the Minister also been given advice that pensions do not count as income for the assessment of amounts payable by way of repatriation or other social security payments? If he has not, can he explain the inconsistency in the definition of income for these two purposes?

—The advice that I have had with respect to section 108, which is the section of the social security legislation relating to sickness benefit, is that it is quite specific in its terms in requiring a loss of income due to illness. In other words, there is not a problem about the definition of income; there is a problem which relates to the reason for the income being lost. Unless the sickness was the cause of the loss of income, entitlement to benefit does not arise under section 108. I cannot see, therefore, that the point raised by the honourable senator in his question would apply. In other words, I do not think advice of the sort that he is suggesting that I might have received would be abroad. I shall check to see that there is no problem in the area that he has raised. But I think the fact is that we do not have a problem about whether something is income; we have a problem about whether income has been lost because of a specific cause.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. In view of the widespread disquiet in regional areas about big increases in telephone costs if the Government accepts the recommendations of the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia, will the Minister give an assurance that there will be no increases in the cost of communications in rural areas and outlying city areas as a result of any Government decision in this matter?

—Any Australians who live in rural areas and who are listening in to this broadcast will recall that the Government has tried to look after their interests and has tried to make sure that there are no significant cost increases to impact upon them-certainly none greater than there need to be. The question asked by Senator Button is one that can be answered only by Mr Brown, the Minister for Communications. I shall seek the answer from him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY: DUMPING OF MATERIAL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware that the Royal Australian Navy at Cairns, North Queensland, dumped a large number of chairs at the local council tip recently? The chairs were, apparently, in good order and were covered with either leather or good quality vinyl upholstery. Is the Minister also aware that a very large number-possibly up to 100-single and double inner spring mattresses and foam mattresses and some refrigerators were dumped at the same time? Is the Minister aware that the particular dump is an area in which scavenging is not allowed, but is he also aware that as soon as the Navy trucks departed the area, two vehicles came into the tip, loaded all the material, with the exception of three of four articles, and took it away? Does the Minister know that a very large order was placed by the Navy with a local furnishing firm for furnishing to replace the material dumped? I understand that the order placed with the furnishing company was in the vicinity of $70,000. I ask the Minister whether an immediate investigation will be carried out into this matter.
—I undertake to refer the question to the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to Senator Chaney as both Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. It concerns the sacking of another 500 people from South Australia's manufacturing industries this week and reports that unemployment in South Australia may reach 15 per cent early next year. I ask the Minister: What is the Federal Government doing specifically to assist Australia's manufacturing industries, particularly those in South Australia, at present? Does the Minister believe that the continual dislocation of our manufacturing industries and the increasing number of lay-offs require special remedial action on the part of the Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a considerable time now the Commonwealth Government has been drawing to the attention of employers and employees that there are certain things which they must do if they are to maintain employment in Australia. One of the things that we have sought from employees, through the trade union movement, and one of the things we have urged before industrial tribunals is the need for wage restraint. We have, for the same reasons, opposed the extension of shorter working hours. We have endeavoured to follow policies which will maintain Australia's competitive position. It is fair to say that over the last 12 months there was a succession of settlements and decisions which certainly were well outside the indicators which the Commonwealth Government had given as being appropriate to Australia's economic circumstances. The general economic policy of the Federal Government has been to try to maintain a situation that would bring about growing employment. We had very great success in that over some years, in the late 1970s and early 1980s. In the last six months in particular we have seen substantial disinvestment of the sort which is causing concern to Senator Foreman.

ANSWER.PARA: A range of additional things can be done by the Commonwealth. We were discussing in the Senate yesterday decisions which were taken with respect to temporary assistance for Kelvinator Australia Ltd. It remains true that this sort of action cannot amount to a general solution of the problem of employment in the industrial area. We can only maintain employment in that area if we can maintain competitive Australian industries. It is not just government that has a role in that; it is also the trade union movement from which Senator Foreman has come.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns the projected pilot scheme whereby users of private for profit day care are to be subsidised and for which $200,000 has been allocated in the current financial year. In which State or States is it planned that the project will be conducted? On what criteria will the participants, both parents and centres, be selected? For how long will the scheme continue before being assessed? Will such assessment be made available to the Parliament?

—I have recently made arrangements with South Australia for a pilot scheme to be undertaken in that State. That scheme will extend to a large number of commercial centres operating in the State. It will enable a subsidy to be provided for parents whose incomes would otherwise preclude their placing children in such centres. The pilot is expected to proceed during the latter part of this financial year and the early part of the next financial year. It will be operated by the State department. It will be subject to an evaluation by an independent evaluator. In the long term that evaluation undoubtedly will become a matter of public record. The object of the exercise, quite simply, is to see whether the standard of care available to some children can be improved by giving them access to a centre where perhaps informal arrangements presently apply. The success or failure of that pilot will, I am sure, be of very considerable community interest.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAXPAYERS' INCOME AND RETIREMENT PLANNING ASSOCIATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to advertisements which have been inserted in Brisbane newspapers by the Taxpayers' Income and Retirement Planning Association? One of the advertisements appeared on page 7 in the Brisbane Telegraph on 4 November 1982. Has the Minister's Department investigated the claim made by this Association, namely, that advice will be given on 'How to retire with $30,000, $50,000 $100,000 and still qualify for a full age pension and fringe benefits without artificially reducing your income'? If an investigation has been made into this Association's claims, will the Minister outline what basic advice was given?

—I am not familiar with the particular advertisement mentioned by the honourable senator. I suppose that any honourable senators who bother to read the plethora of papers which are produced specifically for the older age market will be struck by the very heavy emphasis in almost all of them on schemes for investment, on investment generally and on travel. I suppose that gives some indication of the market at which many of those publications are aimed. I will check to see whether my Department has examined that particular scheme. But there are a variety of ways in which arrangements can be made to circumvent the income test. Some of those, no doubt, are valid and some are invalid. I will see whether I have any specific information on the particular matters which are raised by the advertisement.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED THIRD GRAMMAR SCHOOL FOR CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education whether the Schools Commission 1982-84 triennial report advised the Government that there are problems with funding new schools in areas where government schools are under- utilised. Is it not, therefore, a misuse of scarce government funds that funds should be made available for a grammar school in Canberra at a time when nearby government schools are declining in pupil enrolment and closure of one is said to be imminent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wherever there are existing schools, the effects that the opening of a new school might have on enrolments have to be taken into account. This has been drawn to my attention by the Schools Commission and also by numerous people. It is not something which was discovered in the last report of the Schools Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the third grammar school in Canberra, honourable senators will be aware that the Government has decided to make available some of the funds from an existing vote to help with the capital cost of establishing the third grammar school. We did not allocate extra money; from the vote that was there for non-government schools we have approved that some expenditure be made on a third grammar school. The amount would be something like $250,000, or a bit more , in this financial year and about $800,000 overall.

The situation in the Belconnen area is that there is a demographic change going on. It is anticipated that enrolments will change. It is thought that the establishment of the third grammar school might bring one of the decision points for a high school in that area forward by two years. It will bring it forward probably from 1995 to 1993. That is the advice I have received from the ACT Schools Authority. The decision point that will be brought forward to that date is not the second decision point, which is one that has to do with closing facilities or reallocating them. It is the first decision point which would require a school to look at rationalisation of its resources as the numbers in the school come down below a level, which I think might be 400 or 500 pupils. I do not recall the exact number.

What has been missed in the debate, though, is the time frame. The fact is that the third grammar school will have no immediate effects upon high schools in the Australian Capital Territory and upon high schools in the Belconnen area. It is also worth reminding honourable senators of something of which they would be aware if they thought about it, that is, that a third grammar school would not be just a local school. It would not be a school which would serve just north Canberra or Belconnen. It would not be a school which would serve only the Australian Capital Territory. It would in fact have a regional function as it would be the only Anglican school of its kind within the southern half of New South Wales. It would have a very wide regional function.

For all those reasons, and after advice from the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, from the Schools Commission and from the planning and finance committee, it was my decision that we should proceed to fund the third grammar school to assist it with some of its capital costs. Whether the third grammar school is established, whether it comes into being, a school in the Belconnen region will reach one of those decision points in the mid-1990s. There is no way in which that can be avoided while the present population change and demographic movement goes on. It is wrong if the public debate assumes that that point could be avoided if the school were not created. It could not. If I indicate that the change will be from 1995 to 1993, I hope that puts in a different perspective some of the arguments that have been taking place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Button asked me a question regarding the Government Information Unit and specifically regarding the Government Information Unit officer in Tasmania. I indicated that I would seek information from the responsible Minister. I have done so and I have been advised as follows by that Minister: The matters raised by the Opposition have been investigated by the Minister for Administrative Services. He advises that Mr Montgomery has assured him that he played no role in the Liberal Party's campaign for the May State election. He has informed the Minister that his only contact within the Liberal Party was when seeking to make media arrangements for Federal Ministers whose itineraries may have included Liberal Party functions. That follows his normal practice in functioning as Press Secretary for the Federal Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I am further informed that he had contact with the then Leader of the Opposition's Press secretary. He also had contact with the then Premier's Press secretary. This also, I am informed, is normal practice. I am further advised that he maintains contact with the Press secretaries of the present Premier and the present Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Robertson asked me a question about the Australian Retirement Planning Foundation Ltd and whether that Foundation was receiving funding or assistance from the Department of Social Security. I indicated the personal involvement of a senior officer of my Department in his personal capacity as a Rotarian. I have made a check and the advice which I gave the Senate yesterday is correct. The Foundation is expected to be financed by corporate sponsorship. The Department has received no request from the Foundation or any statement to indicate that a request will be made to the Government for support. The Department will not be providing any staff or other assistance to the Foundation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Robertson asked me a question concerning a Warumungu land claim. I have been able to obtain some more information. The hearing of the Warumungu land claim commenced on Monday, 1 November, at Tennant Creek. Late in the afternoon of Wednesday, 3 November, counsel for the Northern Territory Government informed the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Kearney, that some of the blocks of land claimed had been alienated by the Northern Territory Government. These blocks were leased to the Northern Territory Land Development Corporation. They include parts of a stock route, water reserves and the Devil's Marbles Reserves. Only a relatively small portion of the land claimed is affected by this alienation.

ANSWER.PARA: The hearing of the claim was adjourned on the following day, 4 November, to 13 December, when legal argument will be presented concerning the consequences for the claim of the alienation of the land. The action was foreshadowed by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, in answer to a question in the Legislative Assembly on 14 October, when he said that his Government had always taken the view that land set aside for the passage of travelling stock, stock quarantine or any other public purposes should not be able to be alienated except by a deliberate decision of government. He regarded the position taken by the Central Land Council in this claim as 'untenable' ' and had instructed officials to put in train action necessary to ensure that these stock routes can be alienated and must retain their present status'.

The removal of stock routes and certain areas set aside for public purposes from availability for land claims was, of course, part of the package of amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act which we were discussing earlier this year and which have been the subject of negotiation. These amendments, if they are put into place, of course, would prevent much of the tension and dispute which surround claims such as this one. Finally, it is obvious that the resolution of the jurisdictional questions in this claim is a matter for the Aboriginal Land Commissioner. It is to him that we would look first for a ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Can the honourable senator give some indication of what the explanation is about?
—It is in connection with an article which appeared on the front page of this morning's Melbourne Age.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure this article was unintentional but it quoted a Mr Jim O'Neill, an organiser from the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 'We demanded proper negotiations, but they refused to talk to us, so everybody went on strike in protest.'

Sidchrome is headed by Australian Democrat Senator John Siddons. Mr O'Neill said: 'Senator Siddons makes a great play about democracy in his factory, claiming the door is always open, but the workers did not know anything about it .'

I believe this casts doubts on my personal integrity. The facts are that a senior executive of Sidchrome, of which I am Chairman, met the Works Council and shop stewards and discussed the need for either a four-day week or retrenchments . The executive then indicated that he intended to call a meeting of all the workers to discuss the proposal. Before this could be done an organiser from the AMWSU appeared and called an immediate half-day stoppage. It is thus completely incorrect to claim that the management refused to talk to union officials or the workers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator. I suggest to you that you may be transgressing Standing Orders slightly. As I understand it so far the personal explanation seems to relate more to a domestic matter than one in which you are related as a senator. Whilst you have been referred to in the Press as Senator Siddons, the matter, as you have related it in the Senate chamber, deals more with a domestic issue outside this chamber. I ask that you relate your personal explanation back to the chamber.
—The article refers to me as a Democrat Senator who makes great play of industrial democracy and then indicates that that is not going on. I feel that it is relevant to my integrity.
—You may carry on.
