—I had almost finished anyway, Mr President. I was saying that it is incorrect to claim that management refused to talk to union officials or the workers. Negotiations are proceeding. Honourable senators will be aware of my passionate advocacy of industrial democracy which I have preached and practised for over 30 years. Consultation with workers and unions is an important part of this process of industrial democracy and in this case it was not intended to be bypassed by management. It was not bypassed by management which impression the article may give.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to prevent, or reverse, the catastrophic drift into economic depression.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody disputes that the Australian economy has sunk into its deepest slump since the Great Depression of the 1930s which less than 20 per cent of the present population can actually remember. Moreover, it is sinking deeper into recession at an accelerating rate. For the month of September the unemployment rate was 7.4 per cent. Within this week there is no doubt that it will be higher and there is little doubt that it will rise to above 10 per cent by February of next year. Economic growth is negative. The economy is actually contracting for the first time since 1961. Again, most of the people now resident in Australia were not in Australia in 1961. According to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government, the Australian economy is the victim of external forces entirely beyond Australian control. That statement contradicts the unequivocal view given by the Prime Minister in 1975 at the ANZAAS conference, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature they would be saying, 'we can overcome'.

That is what the Prime Minister was saying in 1975. What he says in 1982 is that the deepest slump since the 1930s is caused by external forces about which Australia and his Government can do nothing. But, more important than another prime ministerial contradiction, it is not true that we can do nothing about it. Firstly, it is not true because the opportunities of the late 1970s were wasted. Australia was already deep in recession by historical standards when the present world slump set in. Secondly, although it is undeniably correct that external forces have some influence on the Australian economy, as they must in any trading nation, we are not helpless victims inexorably following the trail blazed before us by countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States of America. Indeed, we have not followed the United Kingdom and the United States. The Thatcher and Reagan administrations have almost doubled the unemployment level. But they have almost halved the inflation rate. Only the Australian Government, only our Prime Minister, has managed during his term of office to double unemployment and also push up inflation. That is the end result of seven years of Fraserism.

Since this Prime Minister took office, the number of unemployed people has risen from less than a quarter of a million to more than half a million and it is going up rapidly. The annual inflation rate was 12.1 per cent when he took office, the most recent annual rate recorded was 12.3 per cent. That is the end product of seven years of rhetoric about fighting inflation first. Inflation has risen. The number of unemployed has more than doubled. Interest rates, after a recent blip, are again at record levels-a fact which is a major contributor to the enormous fall in approvals for dwellings which figures for, for the month of September, released just today, indicate are 30 per cent below what they were 12 months earlier. A major slump in the building industry, as revealed by those approvals, has not yet bitten fully. Growth is negative for the first time in more than 20 years and for only the second time since the 1930s. The economy is actually shrinking.

Faced with that impending reality in July-anybody at all skilled in reading indicators could see that that was the reality that was looming up; it could be seen in July-the Government produced a Budget bereft of any economic strategy. It was a Budget full of gimmicks and shonky estimates. It was an entirely political document set against a four-month time horizon and the intention of a premature election. Our Prime Minister, given in July an opportunity to display real leadership, chose instead political opportunism as he has always done. The most irresponsible and opportunistic facet of all was probably his continual feeding of speculation about an early election when what the country needed was leadership, stability and some coherent policy to arrest the present decline and turn it backwards.

One of the gimmicks contained in the 1982 Budget was the proposal to ask the Reserve Bank of Australia to release one per cent of bank liquidity presently held in the statutory reserve deposits for the explicit purpose of lending to stimulate residential building. A majority of the Reserve Bank Board, which, over the years, has been a compliant tool of conservative governments, declined to comply. Whether that non-compliance can be attributed to a new Governor or to Mr Stone paying back the Government for ignoring his advice about the Budget, it happened. The Board refused to comply. For three months the question drifted in limbo. The Bank held its ground and the Government refused to issue the directive to the Bank which section 11 of the Reserve Bank Act explicitly authorises it to do. Meanwhile, the entire money market was destabilised for three months. If, in the considered judgment of the Government, that release was essential to policy and to revival of the building industry, it should have instructed the Bank immediately after the first meeting of the Board declined to comply with the request. Failure to issue that instruction constituted an abdication of responsibility by the Government and by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in particular. This is yet another indictment of that Treasurer who prevaricated for three years over taking action against tax evaders and prevaricated for three months over directing the Bank and still refused to grasp the nettle. He deferred the matter indefinitely.

It should be remembered that for three months in 1980 the money market was destabilised for what was roughly the reverse reason. On that occasion the Bank improperly succumbed to Government pressure to bear down on interest rates for purely political purposes-to get all the elections that were held towards the end of 1980 out of the way. The present condition of the Australian economy is not a passing aberration induced by a general world recession. Indeed, Australia , compared with the industrialised countries as a whole, has a seven-year record of failure, particularly in the latter half of the 1970s. From 1976 to 1980 inclusive-these are calendar years because the figures are taken from Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development publications which are recorded in calendar years-Australia's unemployment rate averaged 5.7 per cent, which was higher than the unemployment rate for the OECD as a whole at 5.3 per cent. It was more than double, indeed triple, the unemployment rate of Austria, more than double the unemployment rate of Japan and almost double the unemployment rate of West Germany. Our economic growth in that period, despite a relatively high population growth, averaged only 2.6 per cent compared with an OECD average almost one per cent higher, an average in Japan double that of ours , and an average in Austria and West Germany which was 50 per cent higher.

Since this Government has taken office, Australia has slipped on the table of per capita income from fourth position to twelfth position, and it is still sinking. In addition, for last year, and this year as well, if present indications continue-there is no reason to believe they will not-we will record a deficit on current account, that is, a deficit on the external account, of $9 billion. Australia's current account has more in common with that of a banana republic like Poland and Mexico than it has with what one ought to expect from a traditionally rich industrialised nation. This Government has had its chance. It has blown that chance. Australia could and should have entered the present slump with an employment rate of around 2 per cent instead of 6 per cent. It should have minimised the deterioration from 2 per cent to something like 3 per cent instead of the 10 per cent or 11 per cent which we will see early next year. Other countries have succeeded in doing that.

That, however, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle no doubt will remind us in about 10 minutes time, was in the past. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has said before: 'What of the future?'. That is a legitimate question. What can be done? Firstly, the Government might try telling the truth. The truth is that there is no complete or immediate remedy for seven years of mismanagement. But an expansionary fiscal and monetary policy, in particular of a type that is directed towards stimulating dwelling construction, house building, for reasons that I will explain later, and expenditure directed into other works will do a great deal. It will make a very significant contribution to arresting the present decline and turing it around. Yes, that is Keynesian economics. I know that it is not entirely fashionable to be a Keynesian but I leave the Government with the question: What Australian, given the choice, would reject the Keynesianism of Japan and Austria for the mongrelised monetarism of the United Kingdom, Australia or the United States?

It is correct that Austria and Japan have something to supplement the traditional Keynesian policies which they have followed throughout the second half of the 1970s and follow still. Traditional Keynesian expansionist remedies for economic recession have been supplemented by effective prices and incomes policies, as indeed have the management policies applied in all of those countries which have had satisfactory, indeed, under the circumstances, brilliant economic records throughout the second half of the 1970s. In all of those countries where inflation has been low, growth rates have been high, unemployment has been low and interest rates have been held at moderate levels, countries such as Japan, Austria, West Germany, the Netherlands and the Scandinavian countries, the common denominator is a prices and incomes policy. The empirical evidence flatly disputes the assertion that Keynesian remedies do not work providing the Keynesian remedies are supplemented by an effective prices and incomes policy.

In Australia, Federal governments have almost no coercive powers in the area of prices and incomes control. It is, therefore, essential that the government which attempts to implement such a policy has a great deal of moral authority, the commodity of which this Government is deservedly bereft. If the Government wanted to establish any moral authority-I suspect it is too late to do that-it should try feeding the truth to the public instead of the tricks and gimmicks which it has fed the public for seven years and with which the public was deluged in the last Budget. For these reasons-the tricks, the gimmickry and the shonky Budget-this Government has no moral authority. It has no moral authority for a number of other reasons, including the sequence of ministerial scandals and shifting prime ministerial standards which we have seen over the years.

The Prime Minister believes in nothing. He judges everything by ephemeral political convenience. All value judgments, and indeed truth itself, is to this Prime Minister, a matter of ephemeral political convenience. The Government has no moral authority because for five years it presided with a full knowledge of massive tax evasion. It responded belatedly and partially with retrospective legislation to recover part of the tax which had been evaded. That legisation has now been watered down in two very significant ways: Firstly, by giving the people who the Prime Minister identified as recipients of stolen money 12 months to pay it back and, secondly, by inserting into the original Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill new clause 3 (12), which exempts a whole class of vendor shareholders from the obligation to repay what the Prime Minister had said was stolen money. It is no coincidence that among the companies exempted by that clause is Tremog Ltd which was 60 per cent owned by Denis Horgan, the chairman of the finance committee of the Western Australian Liberal Party.

This Government has no moral authority because the Prime Minister allows the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) to retain a 4 3/4 per cent government housing loan, which the Deputy Prime Minister granted himself 18 years ago, 82 per cent of which has not been repaid. Any Prime Minister who allows to continue a situation in which his deputy has a 4 3/4 per cent government loan when everybody else buying a house is paying between 13 per cent and 16 per cent cannot expect to have any moral authority. This Government has appropriated, in the Bills now before the Senate, $1.5m-hidden in the Treasury estimates-for a Liberal Party election slush fund for political advertising in respect of an election campaign which the Government had planned to conduct later this month and early next month. It has given us a Budget full of gimmicks and tricks.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is taxpayers' money, is it?

—Yes, it is taxpayers' money. The Liberal Party does not believe in publicly funding the Australian Labor Party. It does believe in publicly funding Liberal Party political campaigns and hiding the fact that it has done so. It has given us a Budget full of gimmicks, tricks and rubbery estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government says that wage restraint is crucial to economic recovery. There is some truth in that. But the Government cannot expect to be taken seriously in advocating wage restraint when it has that sort of record, from which it refuses to resile. Unions will not impose discipline upon themselves unless they are shown an example by a government which has some moral authority, which this Government does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has proposed a matter of public importance. We have heard from Senator Walsh the usual selective quoting of statistics, and then a personal vendetta to finish.
—It was not quite the usual one.

— It was perhaps a little varied and not quite up to date, in view of some of the things that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has said recently. But if we are to discuss the present economic situation of this country let me state the other side of the story and some other facts which ought to be given. The Government recognises the downturn in the economy. A number of factors need to be taken into account when we look at the results that are self-evident in the economy. Economic activity overseas has been weak over a prolonged period. It was inevitable that this would have a significant impact on Australia. We were able to avoid the main effects of that economic downturn for a very much longer period than were most comparable countries. But the prolonged weakness in overseas demand, the softening of energy markets and high interest rates have had an impact which cannot now be avoided by Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic difficulty on the domestic side of our economy has been an excessive growth in wages which has been well in excess of price increases. Unless that is recognised, we cannot even start to talk about the Australian economy. Over the 12 months to the June quarter the average weekly earnings of male employees increased by 16.4 per cent, whereas the consumer price index increase was 10.7 per cent, and 12.3 per cent over the year to the September quarter. I do not think anyone disputes those figures. If male wages increase by 16.4 per cent as against 10.7 per cent for the same period-or 12.3 per cent for the year to the September quarter-one realises that that wage overhang must have a serious effect on employment prospects. The prime need is to correct the excessive wage levels that have been developed, in order to restore employment and to protect the employment that presently exists.

The policies of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Opposition, which are based on the maintenance of real wages, are a recipe for continuing deterioration of the economy and worsening unemployment. It ill becomes the Opposition to propose matters of public importance without addressing itself to the central points that need to be accepted. The Government is doing what it can to urge and encourage wage restraint in every forum in which it can do so. In the Budget that is at present before the Senate many indications are given of the Government's concern to encourage wage restraint. Assistance, in a number of ways, has been provided to enable the family situation to be improved and encourage the wage restraint that is so essential.

Economic recovery depends on overcoming inflation and establishing a domestic economic environment conducive to growth which will enable us to take advantage of an overseas recovery when it occurs. This requires steady, not stop and go, policies, not some of the extravagances that have been outlined from time to time. Perhaps a little later I can refer to those mentioned by Senator Walsh. The honourable senator mentioned some unemployment statistics and compared Australia with some overseas countries. But if we are to look at the present situation we should compare Australia's figures with those for the latest months in a number of countries. We should compare Australia's rate of 7.4 per cent unemployment for September with the 10.4 per cent figure of the United States for October; with 2.3 per cent in Japan for August-the latest figure that I have -with 8.2 per cent in West Germany for September; with 9.1 per cent in France for August; with 12.8 per cent in the United Kingdom for October; with 8.7 per cent in Italy for July; and with 12.2 per cent in Canada for September. Those figures are the most recent that are available. We should compare Australia's rate of 7.4 per cent with a rate of 10.4 per cent in the United States, 12.8 per cent in the United Kingdom and 12.2 per cent in Canada. In other countries, with the exception of Japan, the figures range between 8 per cent and 9 per cent. That is the comparison that we ought to have in front of us-not selective figures for Poland, Austria and other countries with which we would not seek to compare our economy.

The principal cause of unemployment in Australia-I do not hear this freely acknowledged-continues to be increases in real wages and labour costs which have been in excess of labour productivity growth and the domestic inflation rate, which is well in excess of inflation rates abroad, leading to losses in international competitiveness. We have had a slump in profitability and, as I said earlier, the prolonged international recession. The Government's policies for combating unemployment, particularly those incorporated in the present Budget, ought to be recognised. The only basis for a sustained recovery in employment lies in the adoption of consistent policies aimed at winding down inflation, correcting the imbalance that has emerged between excessive real wages and reduced business profitability, and providing the scope for a sustained expansion of the private sector of the economy. Policies to this end include the maintenance of monetary policy aimed at bearing down on inflationary expectations and the conduct of an exchange rate policy with a view to resisting inflationary pressures, subject to the need to maintain a satisfactory external balance.

We ought to be looking to give support for a decentralised and deregulated wage fixation system which allows scope for wage entitlements to be more directly related to the economic circumstances of particular industries. To ignore that is to ignore the peril that lies ahead of those who presently have employment and to ignore the difficulties of those who are seeking employment. There must be continued emphasis on manpower and training policies aimed at improving the flexibility of those people who are seeking employment to have the widest range of employment opportunities ahead of them. I do not know why we have to continue to debate this matter. We have said from so many different points of view that there was a marked turn round in the Australian economy in 1981-82 with growth in the second half of the year substantially slower than in the first. For anyone to suggest that that has not been acknowledged or stated is to ignore the many occasions on which that has been officially stated.

The preliminary estimates of our national income and expenditure show that real gross domestic product grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 0.7 per cent in the second half of 1981-82, following growth of 3.7 per cent in the first half year. Real non-farm GDP grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 0.2 per cent in the second half of 1981-82, following growth of 2 per cent in the first half year. The preliminary national accounts estimates for the June quarter, which should not be given undue weight, suggest a strengthening in growth, with non-farm GDP estimated to have grown by 0.9 per cent in the quarter . On the other hand, labour market indicators have shown continuing weakness. In the September quarter employment was 0.3 per cent below that in the September quarter of 1981. Since June total employment, however, has remained generally stable. The figures I have just cited have been given officially in Government papers. To suggest that there is no revelation by the Government of the state of the economy seems to me to be somewhat absurd.

For the period immediately ahead, the prolonged weakness in activity abroad, together with continuing low profitability and a relatively high rate of inflation at home, will constrain economic policy options and impose limits on the pace of domestic economic recovery. The key to lower inflation, improved international competitiveness, enhanced confidence and higher business profitability lies in the achievement of a much lower rate of increase in labour costs than has occurred in recent years. Until a much greater degree of wage restraint is achieved, high inflation, low economic growth and high unemployment are inevitable. I think, as was said by one of my colleagues today, that that sort of situation is not something that can be addressed by government alone. It is a matter of employers, employees, unions and governments recognising these difficulties in our economy and working together to overcome them and achieve much greater employment opportunities.

Wage increases have played a major part in the downturn. Real wage levels remain much too high for any prospects of recovery, but there are various indications of a greater awareness by employers, employees and unions of the damaging effects of excessive wage increases and a willingness to accept lower wage outcomes in order to help maintain employment. Here again, one would like to hear more on this matter from the trade unions. I think individual employees and employers recognise that they need to have a greater awareness of wage restraint. One would like to have some leadership on that approach. The abandonment of wage indexation and the adoption of a more decentralised bargaining approach should facilitate more realistic wage outcomes in the future . We all hope that that will be so. There was some mention of our overseas balances. Foreign capital inflow contributed to an overall balance of payments surplus of $376m in the September quarter of 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —Poland did that for 15 years.

— I inform Senator Walsh that that was the first surplus in a September quarter since 1972. Private capital inflow in the September quarter of 1982 was $2,069m, double that recorded in the September quarter of 1981. This indicates continued overseas investors' confidence in the Australian economy. Official reserve assets at the end of September 1982 stood at $8,396m compared with $4,495m at the end of September 1981. Again, those are statistics which should not be ignored. The climate in which the 1982-83 Budget was framed was one of international recession. That is still the position. Export markets have shrunk. The high interest rates are hurting many Australians and are causing a number of projects to be shelved. Our economic growth has faltered. These statements were made at the time the Budget was introduced in August. The difficulties are inherited from a number of sources, but some of the factors are local ones. For the year 1981-82 the rate of inflation of 10.7 per cent was almost 2 per cent above the figure for 1980-81 and some 4 per cent above the average of our major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners. As I have said, wage increases in excess of productivity gains caused Australian industries to be less competitive. In 1981- 82 average weekly earnings rose by about 14 per cent. That is against the figure I cited earlier for the adult male wage increase.

SPEECH.PARA: The widespread drought, which has not yet been mentioned, will continue to effect the economic fortunes of Australia. This is a serious drought and one that is causing enormous hardship throughout rural Australia. There is little prospect of rapid world economic recovery. It is unrealistic to expect that there will be a major recovery in the Australian economy in the very near future . The Government, in framing the Budget, endeavoured to balance two major considerations: Firstly, the recognition that present economic conditions are causing hardship to many Australians and, secondly, the need to maintain an economic strategy which is responsible and which effectively addresses those economic developments which have contributed to our present situation. The Government has aimed to provide relief, assistance and incentive within the confines of a responsible economic policy. While this will result in an increase in the size of the overall Budget deficit this year compared with last year, the Government is confident that that deficit can be financed in a non-inflationary manner.

Principal features of the Budget have had a great deal of discussion, but in some cases still need some explanation. I do not think there is much need now for an explanation of the personal tax relief and the other assistance that was specifically designed to give maximum help to Australian families, especially those on lower and middle incomes. The tax relief was provided on the basis that there would be wage restraint. It is understood that with the tax cuts in the Budget wage restraint can be exercised. Families will now have more in their pay packets and it is hoped that wage restraint will result.

The Budget also provided interest relief for people who are paying off their homes. There was a shift in the Budget towards capital works expenditure, including a special roads program which will have beneficial economic consequences throughout Australia. The Budget also provided industry assistance initiatives, announced in July, which are aimed at making Australian industry as competitive as possible, particularly export oriented industries.

There was increased assistance in the Budget for pensioners. There was the introduction of a new family income supplement to help certain low income families. There was an increase in job training opportunities and other help for unemployed people. The Budget provided for some increase in indirect taxation and a modest broadening of the indirect tax base. Those measures represented very conscious decisions by the Government at the time of framing the Budget, recognising the economic circumstances of 1982-83. The reductions in personal income tax do not need to be stated in detail because most people are already enjoying the effect of those in their weekly pay packets. Senator Walsh mentioned the statutory reserve deposit release which was mentioned in the Budget and on which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) made an announcement last night. The Treasurer commented:

Since the time of the Budget housing finance through traditional lending sources has continued to become more readily available. This has been due in part to some improvement in the deposit taking experience of home lenders, particularly the savings banks. In fact, there are some indications that there may not be sufficient eligible applicants to meet the lending targets of some banks implicit in the commitment given to the Government last March that there would be an increase of $400m in the money to be made available for housing.
Since the time of the Budget there has been a significant increase in liquidity in the banking system.
The September quarter of 1982 has seen a significant surplus of private sector foreign exchange transactions, largely due to heavy buying of Australian securities by Japanese institutions.
The Treasurer went on to say:
In these circumstances-
The circumstances of liquidity in the economy at present-
the Government has decided to defer for the time being its request to the Reserve Bank to effect an SRD release of 1 per cent or some $300m.

The Treasurer commented that he had discussed this matter with the Reserve Bank and with the trading banks, and had a commitment from the trading banks that subject to a sufficient deposit intake and a sufficient number of eligible applicants, they would wish to increase the figure for the year commencing in March 1983 to $500m. That is in contrast with the additional $400m which they are lending in the 12-month period to March 1983. The Government will monitor the situation and if demand does increase and more money for housing is required over and above that now to become available the Government will not hesitate to proceed with the request to the Reserve Bank contained in the Budget Speech. Those are the facts. The position is not as was stated by Senator Walsh.

Senator Walsh mentioned that the Opposition would have an expansionary fiscal and monetary policy, expenditure on other works and a prices and incomes policy. The statements that have been made by the Opposition with regard to how it would approach economic management contain nothing but a series of reckless, irresponsible and deceptive proposals, designed mainly to appease its power base , the leadership of the trade union movement, and other bodies to which it feels it ought to be making some statements or arrangements. I go back to the national conference of the Australian Labor Party in July 1982. It is timely to recall what Mr Ferguson, the Deputy Premier in the New South Wales Labor Government, said:

'Friends, if and when we get a Labor Government, if we adopt some of the policies that have been espoused here and are in our Platform, international capitalism will take away our AAA ruling anyhow and if we are in a position where we have got to worry and please internationalism to retain our AAA rating, then we do not deserve to be in Government.'

Some of the alternative policies put forward by the Leader of the Opposition give concern to the Government just as all those financial comments that were made following the alternative 1982 Budget of Mr Hayden and the bag of tricks that he also announced on 26 October were cause for concern. The Australian Financial Review stated:

This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing but unemployment and inflation on a larger scale than we have now, and the prospect of further involuntary devaluations of the Australian dollar as we are locked into a devaluation/inflation spiral.

If that is the bag of tricks that came through from Mr Hayden in October, it is probably time that Senator Walsh stopped bringing forward these proposals and looked at what the reaction to the policies of the Opposition as a whole has been. He should discontinue bringing into the Senate matters on which he undertakes these tirades. He does it only so he can have a forum in which he can engage in the personal abuse which he seems unable to resist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — For the benefit of those who are listening to this debate, the Senate is discussing a matter of public importance introduced by Senator Walsh, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to prevent, or reverse, the catastrophic drift into economic depression.

Despite the claims made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), there are signs that the Australian economy is in the worst condition it has been in since the Depression. I noticed that the Minister seemed to blame the unions for all the troubles that we have in Australia. In fact, she said that the unions and the workers were to blame because they had pursued a policy of high wage claims. I do not buy the argument of the Minister but even if one does buy that argument one should remember that the unions must act in this way. They must try to obtain justice for themselves and to maintain their level of real wages because this Government, the government blaming them, is the government that abolished the Prices Justification Tribunal. If we do not have a Prices Justification Tribunal, there is every reason for the unions to try to get what they deserve. It is not up to the unions to take the lead when a government abolishes a tribunal such as the Prices Justification Tribunal.

I mentioned earlier that there are signs that the economy is now the worst that it has been since the Depression. Like most honourable senators I did not experience the Depression but I can remember well that my father, who was a building worker, did. He told me many stories of the troubles that he and his fellow workers had during those times. When he was telling me those stories he did not think that I would have to live through a similar situation in Australia . Unfortunately, it looks as though we are now heading along that road towards a depression. That road is being plotted and charted by this Government through its inaction to do anything about the economic direction in which we are heading . No longer can many families be certain that they can continue to pay their mortages. Their interest rates are far too high for the wages being brought in, in the cases where people have jobs. Their mortgages are not like the mortgage mentioned by Senator Walsh a little while ago. I refer to the mortgage of Mr Anthony. His housing interest rate was set at 4 3/4 per cent. He has a government home loan with an interest rate of 4 3/4 per cent, to be repaid over 45 years. How would the people who are having trouble paying their mortgage like to have an interest rate like that? It is despicable that one of the Ministers in this Government has such an interest rate over such a long period for a housing loan when families in Australia cannot afford their mortgages because the interest rates are too high, they are out of work or both.

No longer can families be sure that their sons and daughters will be able to join the work force when they leave school. Too many students are going through school for 10 or 12 years with the ambition of getting out into the work force but are finding out that when they leave school there are no jobs for them. How sick must they think society is when it treats them like that. What does the Government do in the meantime? What it does-it stated that it would do this-is to maintain its present course. It continues its policy of blaming unions. It continues its policy of fighting inflation first, and it cannot even do that with any degree of success. The policies that it says it will pursue are the very policies that have taken Australia into the mire. Why continue with them when they have brought Australia into the situation it is in at the moment? Why does it not admit defeat? Why does it not admit that it has made a mistake, change direction and reverse the decline that it has caused to the Australian economy?

This decline in the economy has manifested itself in a number of ways. One of the ways that we can clearly see is the number of unemployed in society. A little over 12 months ago, in September 1981, 391,100 people were unemployed in Australia. That figure of 391,100 was far too high but in 12 months from September 1981 to September 1982 this figure increased massively by 29 per cent. Last month we were told that there were over half a million people unemployed in Australia. The Australian Bureau of Statistics stated that 504,800 people were unemployed. In fact there was a 10 per cent increase in the month from August 1982 to September 1982. In other words, unemployment is increasing rapidly in Australia. I understand that the October figures are to be released tomorrow. I am fearful of what those figures will show. Perhaps that is the reason for the Government deciding that the House of Representatives should rise tonight for the summer recess.

According to the September figures, 7.4 per cent of our work force is now unemployed, but no action is taken by this Government, a government which in 1975 pledged that it would provide jobs for all who wanted to work. It is worth mentioning also that the work force is decreasing. In other words, the number of people actually unemployed is probably not the true indication of the number of people in Australia who would like to work if they were given the opportunity. Of the total population looking for work, the participation rate in September 1981 was 61.7 per cent. In other words, 61.7 per cent of the population wanted to be in the work force. By September this year that figure had decreased to 61 per cent. So we have not only an increasing number of unemployed but also a decreasing percentage of our population looking for work. Many people have opted out of the work force. They realise that the possibilities for work are so slight that they might as well not continue looking.

The decline in the economy for the whole of Australia that I mentioned is also apparent in the State that I represent in this chamber, and it is probably even more marked there. In September 1981-just over 12 months ago-55,300 people were unemployed in Queensland. In September this year that number had increased to 74 ,600. These figures probably do not mean much at first blush but if one realises that there has been a 35 per cent increase in the number of unemployed in Queensland, it gives an indication of the decline in that State. The participation rate in Queensland is falling as well. Over the same period it fell from 59.9 per cent to 59.6 per cent, so people are also opting out of the work force in Queensland. It is not difficult to understand these unemployment figures if one reads the daily newspapers. They contain articles which bear the sorry tale of business in ruin. I will give a few examples. An article appeared in the Courier-Mail 13 of August 1982 headed 'Truck builders close doors'. The article stated:

The bad news on the corporate front continued yesterday with the announcement that the White Motor Corporation (Australia) Pty Ltd manufacturing plant at Coopers Plains, Brisbane, had closed 'until further notice'.

The article went on to state that this meant that only 70 employees would remain out of 280. The Age of 24 August 1982 contained an article headed 'Hartley Computer to be sold next week'. The article stated:
Next week, after a four-month struggle to clear its debts, one of Australia's biggest computer manufacturers, Hartley Computer, Brisbane, is to be sold by tender.

The Hobart Mercury of 28 August contained an article headed 'Builder forced to liquidate'. It told the story of a builder in Hobart who went into liquidation after creditors met the previous day. The Australian Financial Review of 31 August contained an article headed 'ANZ Bank, Citicorp call in the receivers at Protean'. It stated that Protean (Holdings) Ltd was having difficulties which caused the banks to call in the receivers. The Adelaide Advertiser of September contained an article headed 'Coin dealer goes into liquidation', it related a story about an Adelaide coin dealer who had gone into liquidation owing $200,000 .

I could go on but I would like to mention one case which was mentioned by the previous speaker, the Minister for Finance. A heading in the Australian of 2 October 1982 states 'Drought forces $235m company into receivership'. It contains a story about International Harvester Australia Ltd. Certainly, the drought is creating some of our problems. Certainly, there are a number of problems within Australia's business sector. The point I would like to make, which Senator Walsh made when he introduced this matter of public importance, is that very little, if anything, is being done to remedy the situation in which Australia finds itself. Naturally, as firms go into liquidation or receivership, as I have just outlined, jobs are lost. Again, we can go through the newspapers and find time after time stories about how jobs are being lost not in twenties or thirties but in hundreds. Obviously, we are facing a calamitous position in Australia and action must be taken by the Government.

On 16 September the Government announced that over $350m would be made available for drought aid throughout Australia. The drought in eastern Australia is certainly a national disaster and some aid must go to this sector, but so too is the employment situation a national disaster. So too is there a massive decline in the viability of business. Therefore, if the Government can provide funds for drought relief, why does it not also provide some funds for unemployment relief? It must do this because we will be soon faced with school leavers who will want to join the work force. I mentioned earlier that school leavers go through school full of enthusiasm with the prospect of entering the work force but, unfortunately, many of them now facing that prospect will not find jobs. Shortly, 200,000 school leavers will attempt to join the job market in Australia. Without some increased government assistance many of these young people will become disillusioned with society. In my State of Queensland an additional 30,000 school leavers will soon be looking for work. The unacceptable level of unemployment in Australia is costing us dearly. It is costing us dearly in lost production, in assistance for those who are thrown out of work, however meagre some of that assistance may be, and in the social disruption that it is causing to those who are out of work and their families.

Before concluding I make the point that one of the actions of this Governmet after it came into power was to stop the collection of local unemployment statistics. Many of us know that statistics used to show unemployment in regional areas in Australia, but no longer are these available and no longer are we able to pinpoint areas of exceptionally low or high unemployment so that we can plan accordingly. Statistics should once again be collected on a local basis . Recently I heard someone say that when the person over the road is out of work we have a recession but when oneself is out of work it is a depression. The way our unemployment statistics are increasing at present we are clearly headed for a depression. It is up to this Government to do something other than to maintain its present course, which has put Australia into this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all acknowledge that the world today is indeed facing a difficult economic situation but I do not think the debate on the Australian economy is enchanced at all when an Opposition speaker refers to our Government plotting and charting the road to depression. I wish to examine the three basic reasons which have given rise to this economic downturn in Australia. There are international implications in the Australian recession. So far as Australia is concerned, the remarkable thing is that it took this country so long to move into the unfortunate state that we now temporarily face. A second factor is the widespread drought throughout Australia. The third factor is internal.

SPEECH.PARA: To imply a lack of government action in the subject of this discussion is the height of stupidity. One has only to look at the pre-Budget implementation measures, those in the Budget and finally, measures taken since the Budget. We have to recognise the seriousness of the international difficulties. Australian producers have been faced with declining prices for most agricultural produce and minerals. Australia relies very heavily on products from mining and agriculture to meet its balance of payments commitments. One of the difficulties which Australia has to face is a deficit of about $9 billion on current account. A further inflationary factor is that there has been an effective devaluation, which, between August 1981 and October 1982, amounted to about 18 per cent.

Some of the international problems affect Australia in a major way. The downturn in the international economy has seriously affected our export trade in commodities. I give one outstanding example-the coal industry. The stabilisation in world prices for oil in real terms, which were effectively falling, had a restraining effect on certain decisions of other countries in relation to the importation of Australian coal. I mentioned earlier that it took Australia a fair while to reach our present economic state. This is highlighted by statistics from the organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which indicate that from 1978 to the end of last year the real rate of economic growth in Australia, as reflected in total production, gross domestic product and so on , was twice that of the average of the OECD countries. They are some further international problems that we have to face-for instance, problems with balance of payments, having high interest rates to attract capital inflow to meet the deficit.

The severity of drought is realised, when we recognise that 90 per cent of New South Wales farms, 60 per cent of farms in Victoria and 40 per cent of farms in Queensland have been affected by drought. This severity of the effect of the drought has a major effect on the economic condition of our nation. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates that there will be a drop of well over $1, 500m in the net value of rural production this year unless there is a break in the drought almost immediately. But the Opposition's criticism has been that our Government has done nothing about help. Our Government has introduced a massive fodder subsidy costing up to $320m. The fodder subsidy operates in respect of fodder purchased from 1 September 1982 at the rate of 80 cents per sheep per month and $8 per head of cattle per month. When it is recognised that about 14 million cattle and 93 million sheep are involved one gets some idea of the scope of the problem of this Government's generosity and its concern for the people affected by drought. It is nonsense to imply that this Government has done absolutely nothing.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition there is also a substantial interest subsidy on eligible debt which covers both eligible new and existing debt. The farmer pays the first 12 per cent and the Commonwealth picks up the excess. It is wrong to say that we have not taken measures aimed at stimulating consumption-type expenditure. We have aimed to put money in the pockets of individuals. Look at some of the Budget measures. The tax-free threshhold was increased by $400. The standard rate of tax was reduced from 32 per cent to 30 per cent. The level at which the 46 per cent tax rate applies was increased from $17,894 to $19,500. Pensioner benefits were raised and there was a whole host of measures affecting disadvantaged individuals and sole parents and the unemployed. So we do have a social conscience. That refutes the interjection a while ago about what we are doing for ordinary people.

SPEECH.PARA: As to our attitude towards imports, it is fashionable to criticise our tariff policy, but that policy is one of the most open in the world. Because it is so open, many people tend to criticise it. However, perhaps it is opportune, at a time of some economic downturn, to give consideration to reintroducing Australian preference. The Government should consider reintroducing the former Australian government preference to assist Australian manufacturing industry. One of the unfortunate victims of the downturn has been manufacturing in Australia. The re-establishment of Australian preference would be a good way to help to make Australian industry competitive. In the event of some industries being forced to close, we have to recognise that additional costs would be incurred in the form of unemployment benefits, which are not real stimulants to the economy as is manufacturing. If measures such as the restoration of preference could be taken, we may save a number of industries and prevent lay- offs.

Australian industry is facing a number of hidden costs. Perhaps this is the time to evaluate some of its problems. The payroll tax involves a cost of one job in 20 of the work force. Is this appropriate? I address these remarks to State governments as well, because they have a responsibility in this payroll tax area. I sometimes believe that employers are asked to contribute far too much by way of the scope of workers compensation liabilities. Many of the costs and problems that have been encompassed within the workers compensation parameters should be more directly attributable to social welfare rather than as a direct cost to the manufacturing sector. Maybe this is the time for a review.

Some people in our society are saying that because of the severity of youth unemployment, new measures may have to be taken. It was not the Government's fault that the unions pushed for such very high starting rates for juniors, young boys and girls just leaving school. It is a tragedy that junior rates have been forced up to such an extent that, effectively, it pays employers to employ married women who have experience. We all know the high costs of employing young people-some costs are incurred through their inexperience. This is one of the tragedies of our time. Someone must be bold enough to say that we have to have a realistic approach to youth unemployment, because if these young people cannot get a job within two or three years of leaving school, their chances of ever entering the work force in this competitive climate will be difficult.

A number of other people have been suggesting that to help the young unemployed we should, perhaps, introduce some form of national service along the lines of that which has been applied in Switzerland, where the emphasis has been on service to the community. Perhaps this can be investigated at an appropriate level in Australia. Some of the best brains in this country could be directed to educating people in socially desirable work-type projects. This would enhance the ability of people to get jobs and it would benefit the community. One of the big problems in the world today is that the manufacturing capacity exceeds demand for manufactured products. Increasingly, multinational companies have tended to go into low-cost countries and produce for a world market. In such circumstances the goods are sent to developed countries, such as Australia, effectively at dumped prices. I believe we should be looking at this matter of imports.

One of the tragedies of our time is that the Third World has failed to develop according to the expectations of the 1970s. The debt structure of the Third World is giving rise to many problems experienced around the world at present. We see the possibility of major banking institutions failing and countries reneging on their debt obligations. We have failed on an international basis to raise the standards of living sufficiently within Third World countries so that they can utilise the goods and services which the world can offer. I think politicians have to set an example of restraints, then we can ask people on wages standards of living to forgo penalty rates for, say, working on Saturdays, overtime and that sort of thing so that a greater number of people can enter the work force. But we, as parliamentarians, should offer something. There is wide criticism in the community about the generosity, for example, pension scheme for parliamentarians. Perhaps we should further examine that area. We have spoken at great length in this chamber about tax rip-offs and overpayments to certain sectors.

One of Australia's major problems is that wage costs are exceeding productivity gains. Until that relationship is put in proper perspective we will experience problems. For example, the average weekly earnings for male employees increased by 16.4 per cent whereas the consumer price index increased by 10.7 per cent over the last 12 months.

Let us now look at the good news. The fortnightly bulletin issued by the management consultants W. D. Scott and Co. Pty Ltd, points out that W. D. Scott believed that price inflation had peaked. The good news was that it believed that the statistical ballooning in the inflation rate for the September quarter would be removed by December. It believed that the recession had materially eased wage pressures and forced absorption of cost increases across a wide spectrum of business and that many industries had been able to pass on some of those increases. It said that international export and import prices were rising very slowly compared with the domestic price levels. That is good news for Australia. It said also that excess of stocks, predominantly of imported finished goods, were being actively liquidated with price concessions. It stated also that consumer expectations probably had swung towards inflation reduction. After analysing all those factors its conclusion was that by the end of 1983 the Australian inflation rate could be down to 8 per cent. It believes that this would improve our international competitiveness and would be the start of a sustained period of inflation reduction. I believe that this would be long term good news for our Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I normally listen to Senator Watson with some anticipation and interest because he seems to be one of the few Government senators opposite who have some sensitivity to the problems of the manufacturing industry. He disappointed me greatly in the remarks he made. He seemed to be much more concerned about sheep and the Government's efforts in the agricultural area than worrying about the Government doing something to alleviate the problems of the unemployed workers of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating 'the Government's failure to prevent, or reverse, the catastrophic drift into economic depression'. The Australian Democrats believe that Australia's manufacturing industry is at crisis point. Thousands of workers have had to accept a four-day working week. Thousands more will probably soon be faced with the alternatives of a four-day week or losing their jobs. Over the next three months we face the Christmas parliamentary recess. The Government will not be able to do anything to alleviate this critical problem until the Parliament resumes some time in February. We believe that some action has to be taken now before the Christmas period. The market is dead at a time when it should be picking up for the normal Christmas shopping spree.

After very careful consideration the Australian Democrats are advocating a short, sharp shock to the economy to halt the slide into depression and to help to overcome the very worrying trade deficit. The overseas deficit on current account last year was $9.1 billion. Australia will face international insolvency within a few years unless we face up to this very critical problem. Therefore, the Australian Democrats are advocating import restrictions as the only initiative now open to the Government-import restrictions in the form of import quotas. We say that they have to be introduced with urgency. In many cases imported goods can be replaced by products from efficient local manufacturers. It is reasonable that industries which are competitive with imports should be protected. We believe that industries in which productivity can be improved by the introduction of high technology should be temporarily protected from import competition. Such a policy should be seen only as a temporary measure. It should not be imposed for longer than three years. We are suggesting this initiative to give industry a breathing space in which to restructure and so allow time for new industries to provide sufficient job opportunities for full employment. As I said, the Australian Democrats do not advocate this measure lightly.

For the last 18 months the Australian Democrats have been imploring the Government to change direction. We have pointed to the need for a modest and selective stimulation of the economy. We have suggested that the Government should get industry representatives together to try to work out a few long term objectives and to make clear to industry the sorts of enterprises that the Government wishes to encourage in this country. We have said that there is need for some long term indicative planning. The Government has to make choices. We cannot have everything. If we choose more of this we have to choose less of that .

The Australian Democrats have advocated that the Government has to stop tightening the economic screws. We have pointed out that billions of dollars are being lost in potential output and that living standards are falling dramatically. Over the last three years the Government has adopted an economic policy which has been remarkably consistent. It has been a policy of creating domestic surpluses and paying scant regard to a critical deficit in our balance of payments on current account. We have heard a lot recently about the Government's new Budget. The facts of the matter are that despite the much heralded tax cuts, taxes, expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product, are still up. Because of the Government's stubborn refusal to change direction, the economy is now in a tailspin. The time has come for the Government to abandon the thought of bailing out in the form of a snap election, to get back on to the flight deck and do something about the situation. If it does not, I believe we will face this catastrophe before the new year is far gone.

The Australian Democrats are advocating import quotas on those imports that can be replaced by efficient local industry as an emergency measure. We are not a free trade party. We are not a protectionist party. We certainly do not believe that inefficient industry should be protected behind tariff barriers. As a party , we can go along with the last Industries Assistance Commission report which pointed to very large discrepancies between the levels of protection for our industries, some in excess of 60 per cent. On the other hand we have the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd with tariff protection levels of only 5 per cent. This large disparity is unnecessary, it is unfair, and we are all for the Government, through the IAC, addressing the problem. But we cannot expect to implement a more rational approach to protection while we have these levels of unemployment.

Senator Haines, the Democrat senator from South Australia, has been pointing out repeatedly, particularly over the last six months, the critical problem facing manufacturing industries in South Australia. Now, of course, it is becoming very obvious that unless the Government acts now the whitegoods industry and the car industry in South Australia face a catastrophe. In essence, we are saying that the time has come for a major new initiative by the Government. The present economic situation is due to the fact that the economic initiatives which could have been adopted over the last three years have not been adopted. The approach has been remarkably consistent, one of tight money, tightening the economic screws, a disregard for unemployment until we now have to look for emergency measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you get the Temporary Assistance Authority to do the discrimination for you between efficient and non-efficient industries?

—Yes. I gave notice of a motion today that we debate in this chamber a reference to the Temporary Assistance Authority. The law of the land is that before government can act it has to consider a reference from either the IAC or the TAA. Therefore, it is critically important that reference be given to either of these authorities. We suggest that the reference go to the Temporary Assistance Authority because it would probably have a lighter work load and could come up with a report more quickly.
—It would still be a matter of months though, wouldn't it?

—It would depend on the urgency with which the Government addresses the problem. That is entirely in the hands of the Government. Both the IAC and the TAA report to the Government. They are both instrumentalities of the Government and the Government can ask for a quick report, I would imagine, if it were called for in an emergency.

SPEECH.PARA: The critical and appalling problem of youth unemployment has been raised. In the few minutes left to me I also want to draw the Senate's attention to this problem. The youth unemployment problem has to be solved now, not in six months or 12 months time. We have to do something about it immediately. Young people are looking for work. They are applying for jobs up to 40 times and they are being knocked back up to 40 times. We cannot expect that sort of situation to continue without it damaging permanently their outlook and their personalities. We have one of the highest youth unemployment rates in the Western world. What can be done about it? The Government could ask industry and union representatives to get together to make one work station per enterprise available, to be worked on a roster basis to give young people an opportunity at least to get some experience in the work place on a permanent basis, while they look around for permanent work or while they seek to continue their part time studies. This is one practical approach to youth unemployment that does work. I have seen cases in which young people have worked on a two hour a day roster basis over a considerable period. They have kept to the roster times very carefully and it has not been any great hardship to an organisation to make one work place available on this basis.

I make this last point. Debate has raged in this country between free traders and protectionists. It has been a very interesting debate. For many people it has been an armchair debate. The time has passed when we can debate this matter any longer for the simple reason that last year we had a $9.1 billion deficit on current account. We are spending money with gay abandon. If we continue to do that, we will go broke. The sheer economic facts of the matter are that we cannot afford any longer to spend $9.1 billion a year on imports. Certainly we cannot afford to spend that sort of money this year when the Government knows that its export revenue, particularly from primary production, will fall dramatically; when it knows that its export contracts for coal and iron ore to Japan have been cut dramatically; when it knows that its revenue will fall dramatically. We must do something about our level of spending. That is an economic fact of life. It is as clear as a family saying: 'Well, we have some money to spend today but we do not care what happens tomorrow'. That is exactly the position the Government is in in relation to its external deficit.

Of course, there is a lot of confusion when we talk about deficits. We should make it clear whether we are talking about an external deficit or surplus or an internal domestic deficit or surplus. They are really two quite separate things. I am pointing now to the external deficit and saying that we do not have the money to pay for the level of imports; so that sooner or later we have to do something about it. How much better to sit down and plan the strategy now and make reference to the IAC or the TAA on the basis that we have to reduce our level of imports. Then we can solve two problems at once. We can solve our critical unemployment problem and we can solve our critical balance of payments problem on current account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to Senator Siddons with some interest. I have noted his suggestion that on the one hand the Government is spending too much money at present, and on the other hand that it is necessary for the Government to assist manufacturing industry to get out of its problems. That is fair enough. The Government recognises the need to assist manufacturing industry. There are many ways in which that can be done. I have said for a long time that manufacturing industry should have been encouraged over the years to increase its productivity through improved technology. I certainly think that we have spent billions of dollars in the past on artificially supporting industry over many years. Perhaps we are now paying the price for that. We may well have been better advised over the years to have encouraged industry, through tax incentives and research and development programs, to help itself.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not to deny there is a problem at present within that sector of our economy. Certainly the Government is looking at imports. That is the commonsense thing to do in this situation. I noticed that Senator Watson, despite what Senator Siddons said, was talking about Australian preference in manufacturing industry. He demonstrated his interest in that area also. It is about time that we all realised that Australia is under the influence of an international recession. It is probably the worst world-wide economic downturn since the Depression years. That is quite clear. We recognise that. Every government in the world, irrespective of its type, is experiencing the same difficulties. Everyone, except, apparently the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, recognises that we are under the influence of a world-wide depression . In the Treasury publication Round Up of Economic Statistics for October 1982 it is stated:

Economic activity in the major industrialised economies remains depressed. The major seven OECD countries have been in recession since the first half of 1980 making it the longest recession in the post-war period. In contrast, the international recession following the 1973-74 oil price rises was of less than two years duration although it was considerably deeper than the current recession.

If the Labor Party seeks to criticise this Government in its efforts to come to terms with the international recession we need only to recall the success of its administration from 1972 to 1975. It is very important for people to remember how Australia suffered under that Administration, when the inflation rate reached about 18 per cent, an all time record, and also unemployment hit an all time record. That Administration also managed to expand vastly our social welfare program so that our Government has to spend in that area about 31 per cent of the $48 billion appropriated in the current Budget. Members of the Labor Party should be the last ones to criticise the Government for its economic management. The downturn is recognised by nearly everyone as a fact of life. Only last Thursday in an editorial in the Australian Financial Review dealing with Australia's manufacturing industry it was stated:

The duration of the recession is largely dependent upon the reflation of the US economy, to state the obvious. The switch in the supply-side economic proposals of the Reagan Administration and the initial tentative signs that the worst may be over provides some hope. But the recent jolt to the falling interest rates locally tends to indicate either that the direct influence of US rates is now weak or that the money market is expecting any falls to be only short-lived. More likely a combination of the two.
Of course, in a recent speech, the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) said:

The world today is experiencing the most difficult economic conditions it has seen for a very long time. No amount of political argument-of which we've seen such a lot in the past few days-can disguise that fact. Words like 'crisis' and 'catastrophe' come easily to the lips of those who seek to describe the current condition of the world economy. Not since the Great Depression of the 1930s has the downturn in the world economy spread its tentacles so widely and so deeply. With all kinds of nations being affected-strong nations and weak; rich nations and poor, capitalist democracies and communist dictatorships. The world is suffering the worst unemployment it has ever seen.

That is very true and it was borne out recently in a discussion on that subject that was held at the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association meeting in Nassau. All the countries demonstrated the same problems and in that discussion we tried to find some solutions to them. Australia certainly has to restore its international credibility. At last the trade union movement in Australia is starting to realise that it also has a responsibility in this area. It is at last resisting the urges of its militant left wing agitators to cry out for more and more. If we can get that message to flow right through the whole trade union movement, it will be a great thing for Australia. It will secure the jobs of its members and ultimately it will enable industry to pick up to a degree where further industrial expansion may be able to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to buy the goods?

—That is another thing. I think people will buy goods from us if we can ensure that those goods are able to be delivered in the international market on time. That is another area where the trade union movement must examine itself. The situation is unacceptable. No government can put up indefinitely with a situation that keeps our goods on the wharves of Australia or on ships lying off shore for up to two months or longer. It is no wonder that people overseas are looking elsewhere to purchase their raw materials. I assure the Senate that our goods on the overseas market have customers. It is up to us to ensure that we service those customers in a much more effective way. I believe that is an area where the trade union movement can help the government and its fellow workers in restoring economic prosperity to Australia. The current downturn is a fact of life throughout the world. As a major exporter, Australia is intricately linked to other nations' economies and, as a result, downturns in other countries are bound to have a marked effect here.

SPEECH.PARA: What an Australian government can seek to achieve is an enactment of responsible policies to lessen the impact of the economic downturn. This is what the present Government is doing. The Government has taken extensive action to help meet the difficulties facing the economy and the community. In March the Government's housing package provided additional assistance to home buyers, with particular assistance to those having real difficulty maintaining repayments and with extra help to low income families seeking to become home buyers. At the June Premiers Conference we increased the tax sharing grants by over 16 per cent . We gave borrowing freedom to electricity authorities throughout Australia and extra borrowing authority to other semi-government authorities, large and small. Extra funds were provided for State borrowing programs, especially in housing.

In recent times other measures have been taken by the Government as a result of the Budget. From 1 November personal income tax dropped. The tax free threshold rose by $400. A home loan tax rebate has become available. The amount that a taxpayer with dependent children can claim for a dependent spouse, daughter- housekeeper or housekeeper has risen. The sole parent rebate has risen. Family allowance payments have increased. Those measures have been and will be of assistance to the families of Australia.

Obviously, in the terms of Senator Walsh's motion, the Australian Labor Party believes it can do better. A number of weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden) presented his alternative Budget. By examining that we gain some idea of how a Labor government would deal with the current economic downturn being experienced world-wide. Mr Hayden came up with artificial job schemes which are estimated to cost something like $1 billion. He came up with increased government spending on capital works although the present Government has already done that. I endorse that element because I believe that capital works programs should be entered into and that this Government ought to proceed very strongly along that path to ensure that power stations are built around Australia. That is a vital necessity in New South Wales and Victoria. Capital works such as coal handling facilities, water storage facilities and so on should be proceeded with . All things that are necessary for future national development ought to be proceeded with. But Mr Hayden said that there should be more tax cuts on top of the $2.9 billion that have already been allowed for in the full year by this Government in this Budget.

Mr Hayden's alternative Budget would require a deficit of at least $4.5 billion . His alternative Budget was replete with vague, uncosted generalisations which amounted to the inevitable socialist response to economic difficulties-spend more money. On 27 August this year the Age described Mr Hayden's efforts in the following terms:

And in all the twists and turns that Mr Hayden's economies have undergone since he won esteem as Treasurer in 1975, the one constant appears to be a belief that the voters can be fooled, that the hard options can be fobbed off, and that it is unnecessary for a party preparing for government to have a credible economic policy.
On 29 October, the Adelaide Advertiser editorial, referring to the same subject, stated:

Mr Hayden's own recipe for economic survival-by stimulating spending through tax cuts or higher benefits, by increased capital works spending, by freezing State Government charges, by capital grants to provide jobs and by maintaining real wages-is unrealistically expansionary in the present climate. There is no knowing where Labor would find the money for such schemes, and no guarantee that Labor could persuade the unions to curb wages.
A Labor government would be bound by the ALP platform. The people of Australia would do well to note Labor's overall objective which states:

The Australian Labor Party is a democratic socialist party and has the objective of the democratic socialisation of industry, production, distribution and exchange to the extent necessary to eliminate exploitation and other anti- social features of these fields.

That is quite clear. The Labor Party would nationalise industry. It would run the country into tremendous difficulty. The Labor Party has a record of dismal failure. The Opposition accuses us of failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tonkin's failure?

—And what about our friend Mr Bannon who has just been elected to lead the South Australian Government? He has said that he will support the uranium mining at Roxby Downs. But to my knowledge there is no existing contract . He will be bound by the ALP's dictatorial attitude on uranium which states that the Government will honour only existing contracts. The Labor Party does not want uranium enrichment to occur in South Australia, which will deny 1,800 jobs-1,000 during construction and 800 during production. Those are the things that we will now have to put up with in South Australia. In the next three years we will drop back to what occurred in the dismal 1970s in South Australia when Mr Dunstan was Premier. That Government did nothing about productivity or expanding industry or developing South Australia's resources. All it worried about was Monarto which was a failure and a waste of $17m. We now have a nice Festival Theatre to commemmorate the activities of that disastrous Government in South Australia. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
