DEBATE.TITLE: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION (MANAGEMENT OF ORGANIZATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill relates to two important areas of the affairs of federally registered organisations of employers and employees. The first area concerns the fitness for office of officers of those organisations or of individuals who aspire to office. The second area involves the use of the financial resources of such organisations to make loans, grants or donations.

These provisions take account of and develop recommendations made in the report by the Royal Commission into the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation (The Winneke Report). The Royal Commission was established in 1981 and reported to the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments in May of this year.
The Report of the Royal Commission identified serious shortcomings in the affairs of the Federation and in the conduct of certain of its officers, about which I do not propose to speak now.

I need only inform honourable senators that these matters, which have been widely reported and achieved considerable notoriety, led the Royal Commission to make certain recommendations as to action to be taken by the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments.

One recommendation was for the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to be amended to disqualify an officer of an organisation who was convicted of an indictable offence involving an abuse of that office, from holding that or any office in the organisation, and for that person to remain ineligible for such office or offices for a period of five years.

Another recommendation was made for an amendment to the Act to provide that the funds of any registered organisation, or any branch, should not be applied in the granting of loans to any officer or member of the organisation or branch unless the terms and conditions upon which the loan is to be granted have been fully disclosed to and approved by the membership of the organisation or branch in general meeting.

Both of these recommendations highlight the need for the honest administration of registered organisations. These bodies play a vital role in Australian society. It is plainly against the interests of the community and the members of registered organisations if their administration is not competent and honest.

The Government does not doubt that by far the majority of registered organisations are honestly run, but not only the Royal Commission into the Builders Labourers Federation but also that into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has shown that there is an urgent requirement for legislation to combat corruption in the management of registered organisations.

In framing this Bill, the Government has had regard to the longstanding prohibition in the Uniform Companies Acts on certain persons managing corporations. Similarly, the requirements in that legislation about loans to directors of companies and certain other individuals have been noted by the Government.

While the Government does not consider that a close comparison can be drawn between companies and registered organisations, nonetheless the community and the members of these bodies are entitled to expect an equally high standard of integrity to be set for those who are entrusted with the management of their affairs. Indeed, the Royal Commission into the Activities of the Builders Labourers Federation in making its recommendation concerning disqualification also drew attention to the standards required of company directors in this regard.

So, as I have said, this Bill contains provisions based on those contained in the co-operative companies legislation which disqualify certain persons from being involved in the management of a corporation. I would, in this regard, draw the attention of the Senate particularly to sections 227 and 562 of the Companies Act 1981. The policy in relation to these companies provisions is under consideration in the context of the planned exposure draft of the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983. It is hoped that the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities will later this year agree to this exposure draft being made available for public comment.

The Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown) has directed his Department to ensure that when the public comments on the exposure draft are being examined, consideration is given to the question whether the companies provisions need any amendment so that, as far as possible, they cover the same range of offences as those set out in proposed sub-section 132F (1) contained in this Bill and to the question whether any other adjustments would be desirable to the companies legislation to bring it into line with the relevant provisions of this Bill.

I should also inform honourable senators that this present legislation has been the subject of detailed discussion with the members of the National Labour Consulative Council and takes account of their most helpful observations.

Let me outline the Bill for honourable senators. The Bill will disqualify a person from holding office or being eligible to become a candidate for election or to be elected or appointed to an office within any organisation unless a period of 5 years has elapsed since he was convicted of an offence of a specified type or released from prison for the conviction as set out in clause 4 of the Bill by a proposed new section 132F. The categories of offences are:
(i) an offence involving fraud and dishonesty punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a period of not less than 3 months;
(ii) specific and serious offences against the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and Regulations;
(iii) an offence in connection with the formation, registration or management of an association or organisation other than those covered by (ii) above; and

(iv) any other offence involving the intentional or reckless use of violence towards another person or the intentional or reckless causing of death or injury to another person or the intentional or reckless damaging or destruction of property.
The first three of these categories are derived from the Companies Act. The fourth arises from our consideration of what Royal Commissioner Costigan had to say in his various reports.

The Government recognises, of course, that there is a wide range of activities which will come within the scope of these categories. There have to be opportunities for convicted persons holding or seeking office in organisations to have what they have done measured against the holding of or standing for office. Accordingly, the Bill provides an office holder or a candidate for election or appointment to any office who has been convicted of one of the classes of offence I have referred to with the right to seek leave from the Federal Court of Australia to continue to hold office or to be eligible for election or appointment. If the Court grants the application, the applicant will not be disqualified under the legislation. Where the Court refuses the application, the disqualification will continue to operate but it may, if the Court thinks fit, be reduced to a period less than 5 years. There is provision in the Bill to enable the disqualification provisions to be enforced in the Court on application by the organisation, a member of the organisation or the Industrial Relations Bureau. The Bill will permit certain financial assistance to some individuals concerned in leave and enforcement proceedings before the Court.

The Bill will not apply to existing office holders who committed an offence before the date on which the Act comes into operation. It will apply to all office holders who commit a prescribed offence after the Act comes into operation unless within 28 days after being so convicted the office holder seeks the leave of the Court to continue in office.

All persons who have been convicted of a class of offence such as I have referred to, whether before or after the commencement of the Act and who wish to become a candidate for election to an office within any organisation, or to be elected or appointed to an office within any organisation will come within the scope of the Bill unless a period of 5 years has elapsed since that conviction. Such a person will be able to seek the leave of the Court to become a candidate for election or appointment to office. Where the leave of the Court is sought, the Court will be empowered to:
grant the person leave to continuee in office; to become a candidate for election or be appointed to office as the case may be; or
refuse leave to that person to continue in office or to become a candidate for election or be appointed to office as the case may be; and
if the Court thinks fit, specify a period of less than 5 years during which the person concerned may not seek election or be appointed to or hold office.

Criteria to guide the Court in dealing with cases before it are set out in clause 4 of the Bill by a proposed new section 132E. They are modelled on pronouncements by the Courts in this country when they have been called upon to deal with similar types of cases arising from the operation of companies legislation. I turn now, Mr President, to what the Bill contains about the making of loans, grants and donations by organisations. There are already detailed provisions in the Act and the Regulations designed to give persons having a genuine interest access to certain information about decisions taken by organisations to make loans, grants and donations. However in light of what the report of Mr Winneke, Q.C., brought forth, the Government has decided that these provisions do not go quite far enough. And, as I have said, we have taken note of and developed a recommendation which Royal Commissioner Winneke make on this subject. The upshot is that, by the provisions of the Bill, all loans, grants or donations of $1,000 or more will have to be approved by the committee of management of an organisation or branch, as appropriate. Moreover the Bill requires that the rules of organisations provide for the committee of management concerned to satisfy itself before it makes a loan, grant or donation that it is in accordance with the rules and, in the case of a loan, that, in the circumstances, any security is adequate and repayment arrangements are satisfactory.

Consistent with the provisions in the companies legislation, the requirements relating to loans, grants or donations will not include anything done by the organisation to provide a person with funds to meet expenditure incurred or to be incurred for the purposes of the organisation or the purpose of enabling him to properly perform his duties as an officer of the organisation.

Details of all loans, grants or donations of $1,000 or more will have to be filed annually with the Industrial Registrar along with the other financial returns an organisation is required to file. However an organisation will be able to file these details of loans, grants or donations separately. Consistent with norms of privacy, when an organisation certifies that a loan, grant or donation has been made to relieve a member or a dependant of a member from severe financial hardship it will not be necessary for the organisation to include in material it files with the Registrar the name and address of the member or dependant.
Finally, Mr President, details of all loans, grants or donations filed with the Registrar will be available for inspection by a member of the organisation.

Mr President, this is responsible and reasonable legislation. It is legislation which, I believe, the community expects. It is legislation which any self- respecting organisation will welcome. Organisations run competently and honestly have nothing to fear from it. It will protect a high standard of administration in organisations. I want to emphasise that the legislation does not single out the trade union movement for attention. The Bill applies equally to organisations of employers registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act .

It is unfortunate to say the least that the behaviour of some notorious trade union officials may have done a grave disservice to the reputations for honest administration enjoyed by so many other officials of organisations in this country. However the members of organisations registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are entitled to have protection against untoward activities that might be engaged in by officials. At the same time, as I have pointed out to the Senate, there are safeguards in the Bill to protect the individual officials of organisations.

The Bill is certainly not intended as a reflection on the probity of the great majority of hard working officials of employer and union bodies in this country. Such officials should not see it as an adverse reflection upon them any more than the great majority of company directors should see similar provisions applying to them as reflecting upon their integrity.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for implementation of proposals put forward by the Australian Wheat Growers' Federation and the Australian Wheat Board for variations to the existing wheat marketing and pricing arrangements embodied in the Wheat Marketing Act 1979.
Overview

In June of this year the Minister for Primary Industry announced that the Government had agreed to proposals by the Australian Wheat Growers' Federation aimed at improving the efficiency and flexibility of AWB operations. The proposals empower the Board to operate on wheat futures and financial futures markets, to establish financial reserves, and to introduce options in arrangements for the payment of the Guaranteed Minimum Price (GMP). They also cover machinery aspects of the existing arrangements.

The Bill also accommodates a proposal put forward by the Australian Wheat Board , in the context of current severe drought conditions, that the Board be empowered to import and market domestically foreign wheat, should the need arise . Additionally the Bill enables the AWB to act on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to secure foreign wheat for Australia's food aid program.
The opportunity has also been taken to introduce modern standard provisions into the Wheat Marketing Act relating to disclosure of interests by members of statutory bodies.

The existing marketing and pricing arrangements rely on complementary Commonwealth/State legislation and each of the States intends to amend its legislation to put the revised arrangements into effect.
The revised arrangements will apply for the 1982/83 season, beginning on 1 October 1982.

The marketing of Australia's wheat will experience particular difficulties in the period ahead. The drought has drastically reduced the national crop and will compound the difficulties of the Board in supplying the requirements of food aid ; the regular and major markets that have been developed over past years; and the domestic needs for human consumption, industrial usage, feed compounders, and for feeding of livestock in drought affected areas. The revised arrangements , particularly the authorising of the Board to import wheat and to hedge transactions on futures markets will give it increased flexibility in its complex marketing task.

The wheat marketing and pricing arrangements to apply beyond the 1983-84 season are currently the subject of inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission, which is expected to report by 30 September 1983. Experience with the revised arrangements embodied in this Bill will be taken into account in considering new arrangements which might apply beyond 1983-84. Consideration will also need to be given to the views expressed by other interest groups, notably the Flour Millers Council, concerning the appropriateness of existing arrangements including existing domestic pricing arrangements for wheat for human consumption .
I now turn to the specific proposals encompassed by this Bill.
Futures Operations
The Bill will empower the Board to hedge wheat and financial transactions on futures markets thus enabling the Board to secure price assurances for its unsold wheat.

The Government accepts the view of the Australian Wheat Growers' Federation that the Board should be authorised to hedge on futures markets at this time. The authorising of the Board to hedge transactions on futures markets will enable it to use a marketing mechanism that is accepted in international commercial trading of grain. Experience has shown that the hedging of transactions on futures markets facilitates grain trading.

Under the proposed arrangements the Board will be able to hedge on wheat futures markets, currency futures markets, and financial futures markets to protect its wheat sales and also its commercial borrowings used to finance payments to growers.

However, I emphasise that the Bill carefully defines what is meant by hedging purposes in order to preclude any suggestion of speculation on futures markets. It also provides that the various types of futures transactions will be subject to separate guidelines approved by the Minister for Primary Industry.
Reserves

The Bill enables the Board to deduct moneys from the proceeds of the sale of wheat and wheat products and create reserves that can be used for specific purposes, consistent with the powers of the Board under the Act.
The Board will be required to disclose the details of each reserve in its financial statements which will be published in its annual report to Parliament.
Provisions have been made in the Bill so that the Government's financial liability under the Guaranteed Minimum Price arrangements will not be increased as a result of deductions made for reserves.
Advance Payment Arrangements

Under existing legislation the Board is required to pay the Guaranteed Minimum Price to growers on delivery of wheat at the beginning of the season. As growers may not always wish to receive that payment at that time the Bill provides for deferment of all or part of that payment until later in the season.
Payment of the advance payment to growers will be on the basis of arrangements worked out between the grower and the Board, subject to equity being preserved between growers.
Any additional costs arising from the optional payment arrangements will be excluded from the excess commercial borrowing cost reimbursement arrangements.
Allowances and Charges

The advance payment made to growers on delivery of the wheat consists of the Guaranteed Minimum Price adjusted to take account of quality allowances and certain transport, handling, and storage charges. These allowances and charges can vary significantly between growers and States and appropriate deductions for individual growers can be difficult to determine at the beginning of the season.

Accordingly, the Act is being amended to ensure that provisional and final adjustments can be made for these charges and allowances and that the full amounts will be brought to the account of individual growers.
Finalisation of Pools

Presently the Board is obliged to hold wheat against the season for which it has been received until its ultimate disposal. This can delay the finalisation of a season's pool and impair the efficient management of the Board's operations . The cost cannot be justified on equity grounds when the volume is small.

The Australian Wheat Growers' Federation has proposed that when the stock of wheat held in respect of a season is reduced to a residual level the Board should be enabled to transfer it from one season to another.

The Bill provides that the Board should only transfer residual stocks from one pool to another when it has priced the wheat and such a transfer could not potentially cause or add to a call on the Government's commitment under the Guaranteed Minimum Price arrangements.

The Minister for Primary Industry will be taking up with the Board the desirability of it determining and announcing each season its policy in respect of the residual stock which is intended to be transferred to a later pool.
Redeliveries

Sales of wheat by the Board for stockfeed use are provided for under Section 26 of the Act. It is proposed that the section be broadened to enable growers to take redelivery of a quantity of wheat delivered by them during the season at a price determined by the Board.

The price charged for the redelivered wheat will be equitable between growers and will be based primarily on recovering the guaranteed minimum price plus any adjustments for quality and storage and handling costs. The redelivered wheat will only be able to be used for stockfeed purposes and may be of a different quality to that delivered initially by the grower.
Remuneration of Authorised Receivers
The AWF has proposed that the existing legislative provision be removed requiring the Board to negotiate agreements on the rates of charge with its authorised receivers for services they provide.

Accordingly, it is proposed that the Act be amended to provide for the Board to make payments on the basis of rates determined by the Authorised receiver in each State and in accordance with the remuneration agreements in force at the time.
Approval of Progress Payments

The Bill also removes the legislative constraint that advance payments by the Board, other than the initial advance, be approved by the Minister. Should the occasion arise where growers are dissatisfied with the rate at which progress payments are made then the appropriate course of action will be for the Minister to take up any representations with the Chairman of the Board.
Consistency of Season and Accounting Year

The AWF has proposed that the Board's accounting year be brought into line with the crop year. The Bill provides that the accounting year be brought forward three months from 1 December to 1 October which will be consistent with the ' season' used in other sections of the Wheat Marketing Act 1979.

Following on from this change it is intended that the Board's annual report be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry by 31 March of each year instead of 30 June, unless a later date is approved by the Minister. In the next reporting period there are likely to be practical problems for the authorised receivers and the Board in fitting in with this new schedule, and it may be necessary for the Minister for primary Industry to extend the Board's reporting period.
Authority to Import
The Bill enables the AWB to import and market domestically foreign wheat, should the need arise.

Any specific proposal by the AWB to import wheat will need to comply with quarantine restrictions and will also be subject to my approval under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Requests will be considered on a case by case basis and an import need will have to be substantiated.

The domestic marketing of Australian wheat is subject to the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 and any foreign wheat marketing on the domestic market will need to be consistent with the provisions for Australian wheat especially in respect of pricing.
Agency for ADAB

In the context of the current reduced wheat supplies, the Board will also be empowered to act on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to secure foreign wheat for Australia's food aid program. The Board's expertise will be used in negotiating shipments of foreign wheat direct to Australia's food aid recipients.
Conclusion
The amendments contained in this Bill arise essentially from proposals put forward by the Australia Wheat Growers' Federation and the Australian Wheat Board.

The revised arrangements take account of changed circumstances for the marketing of wheat since the current five year plan as introduced in 1979. These proposals, especially in respect of imports and hedging, will assist the Australian Wheat Board in its complex task of marketing the Australian crop to the best advantage.
Experience with the revised arrangements will be reviewed in the context of consideration of wheat marketing arrangements beyond 1983-84.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: In the latter moments of the last day on which these estimates were considered, a number of questions were raised. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer to a question asked by Senator Robert Ray and a lengthy answer to a question asked by Senator Haines.
Leave granted.
The answers read as follows-
Answer to question asked by Senator Robert Ray on 9 November:

Movements and fluctuations in tribunal sittings cause considerable daily peaks and troughs in the workload of each CRS office. It is neither practical nor economic to staff any office to meet the peak workloads and in order to give tribunals an assured and timely transcript service, the Commonwealth Reporting Service has had a system of transferring work from the larger to the smaller offices in operation for nearly three years. To avoid delays and difficulties caused by day-to-day erratic transfers, the practice of transferring transcription for certain appropriate jurisdictions was introduced early this year and not in August as suggested. This practice also enables the employment of an appropriate level of staff and a better use of accommodation, equipment and supervision resources in the smaller offices to which work is transferred.

To conserve reporting resources, it is Government policy to encourage tribunals to limit their demand for transcript and to leave as much as possible of their proceedings untranscribed. However, for the year 1 July 1981 to 30 June 1982, of the tapes originating in Victoria that were transcribed by casual typists, 20% was sent interstate and the remaining 80% transcribed in Melbourne. For the calendar year to date, those percentages have been 30% and 70%.

The re-distribution of work will not mean that, on average, individual typists will be employed to any lesser extent in Melbourne than in other offices. Although the previous practice of transcribing at the point of origin resulted in individual casual staff at some offices being employed at consistently higher levels than at present, that does not in my view oblige the CRS to continue that system.
Answer to question asked by Senator Haines on 9 November:

In the course of yesterday's consideration of the Estimates for the Attorney- General's Department, Senator Haines asked some questions as to why action to obtain payment of income tax-I gather in relation to companies stripped of pre- tax profits-had not been taken under nominated sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act.
The sections referred to were section 26A, which I have taken to be a reference to paragraph (a) of section 26, and sections 166, 167, 170 and 201.

I first of all make the point that decisions about these matters are ones for the Commissioner of Taxation in the exercise of his responsibility for the administration of the income tax law. The answers that I now give are therefore ones that are based on advice to me from the Commissioner.

Paragraph (a) of section 26 includes in a person's assessable income profit arising from the sale by the person of any property that the person acquired for the purpose of profit-making by sale, as well as from the carrying on or carrying out of any profit-making undertaking or scheme.

In the Commissioner's view, there could be no basis for using paragraph 26 (a) to make a vendor-shareholder in a pre-tax profit strip case liable for the company's unpaid tax or, at least in the ordinary run of cases, for any personal tax arising from the vendor-shareholder's connection with the company. The Commissioner believes that paragraph 26 (a) is of little, if any, relevance in this area.

The other sections referred to by the Honourable Senator are of a machinery kind to do with the making and amendment of assessments and the recovery of assessed tax. They do not create liabilities to tax so can only be of assistance where there are other provisions of the income tax law that make the persons concerned liable to income tax in the circumstances. As to section 201, which seems to confer powers of collection where tax is in dispute, the Acting Chief Justice of the High Court has as recently as a couple of weeks ago, in a case involving Peter Clyne having indicated that it does not in practice have that effect.

I trust that these further comments will be of assistance to Senator Haines. If , having heard me, she wishes to pursue the matter further, it would help me to answer her questions more fully if she would give me some additional detail, particularly of the precise circumstances that lie behind her queries. If she were to do that I would have the matter looked into and a fuller response given when the proposed Recoupment Tax legislation is being debated in the Senate.

The first is the series of inquiries into the communications system in which this Government is engaged. I refer particularly to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal inquiry into cable television and radiated subscription television services and to the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Communications Services in Australia, which includes the Australian Telecommunications Commission. First of all, I would like to establish whether it is a fact that the Government proposes to set up a task force, which would include not only members of the Public Service but also representatives of private industry, of some 60 people, to examine the implications of the Davidson inquiry? How will that time for public response relate to the work of the task force if that task force goes ahead?

These matters have to be resolved with some firm decision making based on the issues involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you repeat that? I was distracted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not venture into the confusion of obstetric terms, as to whether or not one mismanages gestation. I am advised that a departmental task force of some eight people has been established, none of whom are outsiders. I think it is true that it has a three-month time fuse for the lodging of submissions. Reference was made to the period of one month regarding the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I understand it is true that that time has expired. A task force is to be set up to inquire into cable television. The final question related to the percentage holding in the satellite. That is a policy matter on which no decision has yet been made and therefore I cannot comment on it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) said that eight people have now been appointed or seconded from the Department of Communications to constitute a task force to look into the recommendations of the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia. Is it not a fact that advertisements were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette for membership of a task force of 60 people to look into the recommendations of the Davidson inquiry? If it is not a fact, is it not true that such a task force was sought to be established in relation to the various inquiries into telecommunications or communications? What has happened to that proposal? The other matter I raise concerns the Minister's declining to answer the question about the satellite on the grounds that it is a matter of government policy. I did not ask what the Government policy was. I asked: What has led the Government to re-examine this matter and is it a fact-I am not asking what conclusion the Government will reach-that the Government has been led to re-examine the matter because of a lack of commitment to invest in and use of the satellite?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may surprise the Senate to hear that I am not an avid reader of the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I am advised by officers of the Department of Communications that there was an advertisement in the Gazette but as far as they understand no size was mentioned for the committee. Certainly the figure of 60 people was not included. If that is contrary to Senator Button's understanding, we can get it checked. As to the other matter, I am not aware of any reconsideration. The matter is before the Government and I cannot comment on it.

—I wish firstly to respond to something said by Senator Button. I was not frowning at the use of the word 'gestation' but the use of the word 'mismanagement'. I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) in relation to Aussat Pty Ltd, a matter which Senator Button raised. It concerns the amount of capital which will be raised publicly. It seems to me that whether the Government holds a 51 per cent or a 49 per cent shareholding, and the significance of that shareholding, depend upon the range of private capital. If, for example, there is only one other shareholder the question of a 51 per cent or 49 per cent shareholding is absolutely vital. If there were two other shareholders it would not be quite so vital. If there were many thousands of shareholders-if the public were involved in the shareholding-it seems to me that it would not matter if the Government held only 30 per cent of the shares in the organisation. If any proposals which were being put forward by the government nominated directors were not satisfactory to at least 50 per cent of the public shareholders I suggest that the proposals would not be worth while. In that event it would be quite reasonable for the Government shareholding to be relatively insignificant. It could be as little as 30 per cent or perhaps 33 per cent in order to block winding up resolutions which may be able to be put through. Apart from that, it seems to me to be insignificant whether the Government is holding 49 per cent or 51 per cent of the shares depending upon the range of public shareholding. It is for that reason that I ask the Minister whether he can tell us whether there will be wideranging public shareholding in Aussat Pty Ltd or whether it may be limited to just a few shareholders, perhaps very large companies or banks or even multinationals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates committee hearings last year I posed a series of questions about a telephone connection to Mr Nixon 's holiday home at Cape Conran. I received an answer last year which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980-81 the standard connection fee of $120.00 was paid from Division 490-2, item 03, administered by the Department of Primary Industry.

I followed that matter up again this year. Unfortunately, I was not able to attend the hearings of the Estimates committee dealing with the Department of Communications due to my attendance at other committees. Senator Walsh interjected and asked: What does the Department of Primary Industry meet in relation to the Minister's electoral office telephone? The reply was:

All telephone charges in relation to the Minister's telephone in his electoral office are met by the Department of Administrative Services. The Department of Primary Industry is required to meet all costs in relation to telex and facsimile services.

I want to know now from the Department of Communications what it cost to lay the cable to Mr Nixon's holiday home at Cape Conran. I understand the cost could be in the vicinity of $10,000. I could not pursue that matter during the Estimates committee hearings but I did say I would pursue it in the Committee of the Whole . I now pose the question: What was the cost to the taxpayer to lay that cable to Mr Nixon's holiday home at Cape Conran in Victoria?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers indicate that they had no forewarning of this question. It is not possible for them to give that kind of information at the moment. We will seek the information and let the Senate have it.

—That is not a very satisfactory answer because I have floated this question around for two years. It is strange to me that the Department of Communications has had no forewarning that there is some concern in the community about this telephone connection. Even though the question was posed to the Department of Primary Industry, surely that Department , in supplying the answer to the question asking whether it had picked up the tab for the connection, must have had some communication with the Department of Communications to find out about the telephone connection. It seems very strange to me that the officers now say that the question came without warning. As I said, it is a matter which has been floating around for quite some time. I have said in this place on many occasions that it is just about impossible to follow up all these leads when two or three Estimates committees sit at the one time. I cannot run from one to the other if I want to do my job properly. If the information is not forthcoming I do not know how I will pursue the matter further. Perhaps I will suggest that the appropriations for the Department of Communications be postponed-as we had to do last year in a similar case in order to get some information-until a later hour of the day. I am sure it will take only a quick telephone call and we will be able to get the answer. I suggest we postpone the appropriations for the Department of Communications until a later hour this day to see whether we can get the information.
—Senator McLaren, do you wish to move a motion?
—No, I am making a suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before that happens, with the best of good will, it is not good enough to say that it is very strange that officers do not have the information. The officers of the Public Service are people of high quality and objective judgment in their work. What they have said to me is that since they have not had a question asked of them, whether at the Senate Estimates committees or prior to this, they do not have the specific information here. I put it fairly to the Senate that that is an honest and completely understandable answer and it does not beg the kind of emotional connotations that have been raised.

SPEECH.PARA: What is more, Senator McLaren must know that I said: 'I will get the answer'. In other words, there is nothing strange about that. Because we did not have forewarning of it I shall get the answer. I suggest that there is no need for postponement. I shall get the answer as soon as possible and give it to the Senate. Whenever an honourable senator has a question, if he would like to put it up, we will undertake to get the answer. But I do not want any reflection at all, direct or indirect, against officers of the Public Service, because they do their job very well indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I spoke a few moments ago I think that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) was being distracted by one of his colleagues. I spoke about Aussat Pty Ltd. I asked the Minister whether there is any indication that the Government is thinking of broadening the shareholding of Aussat Pty Ltd to include a substantial slice of the public or whether the Government is considering only some restricted shareholding. I mentioned previously that in relation to the percentage of shareholding of the Government it is of vital concern to know whether there is to be a broad-based shareholding or whether it will be a limited shareholding. If a large spectrum of the public in general were to hold, say, 40 per cent or 50 per cent of the shares, or even 60 per cent, it would not really matter that the Government did not hold a majority of shares in that organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the Senate. I understood that Senator Lewis was making a comment rather than putting a question. My understanding of the matter is that whilst the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) has had in his mind all sorts of possibilities, there is no focus on a particular possibility at present.

—I state at the outset that at no time did I want to condemn the officers of any department. I have always found them to be quite co-operative. I think that my remarks were taken out of context. Having asked these questions over a period, I found it strange that the other Department had not communicated with the Department of Communications about my concern about the cost. I shall take it that it has not done so. I shall pursue that matter with the Department of Primary Industry to see whether it has had communications with the Department of Communications about the topic that I have been pursuing. If the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) can give me an undertaking that I shall have that answer before the Parliament rises, I shall be happy to accept his undertaking. But often we are told here that answers will be provided and this is one of the reasons why this thing keeps cropping up. The Minister may recall that I put a whole series of questions here about the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and that the only way in which I could get an answer was to get a motion through the Senate-after a notice of motion was carried-so that we could force the answers out of the Government. I do not want to have to go to that extent on this matter . I accept the Minister's undertaking that he will provide the answer, and I hope that it will be done very expeditiously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise briefly an issue that arose in Estimates Committee B. It is not a new issue for the Senate but, nevertheless , I think that it should be raised, if only briefly. It is the subject of junk mail. This matter has been raised on several occasions in the Senate and in other places. In the course of the Estimates Committee some questions were asked about it and there was an indication that an inquiry was under way into a number of matters in relation to Australia Post and that this, too, would be considered . From the answers that we got I am not sure that it would be a very thorough investigation of junk mail.

SPEECH.PARA: I, and possibly others, have received correspondence from at least one organisation which is involved in the distribution of the so-called junk mail. The junk mail to which I am referring is unsolicited articles, whether they come in an envelope into ones letter-box, or in pamphlet form, in folded newspaper form, or however.

For some time a number of people have been annoyed by the fact that their letter-box has become cluttered with these items. However, more and more people are becoming upset by it, because what used to be a minor irritation-two or three pieces of paper maybe weekly-has become a positive avalanche. The reason it has become an avalanche is revealed in the letters that I have received from people who are commercially involved in this exercise. They claim that this is a very effective way of communicating to the public in general what goods or services are available. I am aware that surveys have been done in recent times which indicate that this is a quite effective form of advertising-more effective than some of the old and more traditional forms of advertising. So, clearly, people who have goods or services to advertise are being persuaded to use this method.

Of course, it is not only commercial operators who use this means of distributing information. Australia Post itself makes money out of the distribution of unsolicited material which is placed in letter-boxes, on the basis of a contract of some sort. I am a little disturbed that the report that might cover this matter is being undertaken by those who are fairly close to Australia Post. I am not suggesting that they would produce a dishonest report; I am suggesting that there is little opportunity or reason for them to produce a very negative report. As I have said, for some time people have complained about junk mail--

TALK.START.PARA: —What would a positive report be, Senator? Could you incorporate that in your speech later? I would be interested.
—I am sure that you will tidy up my speech, Senator Button, whenever you feel ready to do so.
—Oh no.

—Very good. Perhaps I may continue on the subject. For some time people have expressed annoyance about the fact that unsolicited articles are placed in their letter-boxes, basically on the ground that they do not want these articles. However, such is the volume of junk mail now that it has become a positive danger to the property of the owner of the letter-box. It is without doubt an advertisement to any would-be burglar as to whether or not people are at home. The police exhort people from time to time, but especially in the summer holiday period, to make sure that they cancel newspaper deliveries and the delivery of milk and that they make arrangements with the post office for the retention of their mail at the post office for a period. However, no one can make an arrangement to keep other articles out of their letter-boxes. For example, I live in a block of home units. All our letter-boxes are grouped in a square brick edifice next to the footpath. When I return to Brisbane from Canberra at the end of a week it is very apparent which unit in the block is the one which has been unoccupied during the week. It is my letter-box, clearly marked according to number, which is the one which is stuffed with these pamphlets and advertising material whereas other residents who are home at the time can clear their boxes. It should not be suggested that anyone who is absent from his or her home for any period needs to ask others to clear the letter-box. The simple point is that this material has no business in the letter-boxes.

SPEECH.PARA: Some citizens are making available stickers which can be affixed to their letter-boxes saying that they do not want unsolicited mail articles. However, those stickers have absolutely no force in law. They have no standing so far as anyone delivering these articles is concerned. I have been informed by people who have bought such stickers and placed them on their letter-boxes that they still receive the unsolicited articles in their boxes. The reason they receive them is that people who are paid to distribute these articles are paid according to how many they distribute. The less the distance they have to walk to distribute them the better. When they know that there is no sanction they ignore such a notice on someone's letter-box. There is nothing constraining them from putting articles in it. I have been informed by some people also, that when they have seen people putting articles into their letter-boxes, despite the signs, and have asked for them to be removed the requests have not always been acceded to. Invariably such requests are not acceded to.

Clearly government action is necessary on this matter. When I raised this matter with the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) he indicted that there were legislative difficulties. Where there is a will there is a way. If the Government decided it wanted to stop this practice to protect the property of householders then it could do so. At present under the law if anyone wants mail delivered to a certain address, let us say his private address, he is obliged to provide a receptacle for that mail. If it is not provided the mail will not be delivered to the address shown on the postal articles. If people are required by law to provide letter-boxes in which the Post Office can place properly addressed stamped articles then I do not believe it would be very difficult for someone to find a way of devising a by-law or something similar which would require that only articles of a certain type went into letter-boxes.

By the way, I do not take the totally extreme view that all unsolicited articles should be prohibited from private letter-boxes. I am aware that a number of people in the community appreciate receiving advertising material. I suggest that the Post Office should print and make available a sticker of a standard size which people could place on their letter-boxes. If the sticker were ignored then a penalty could be incurred. Those who want to receive advertising material-people who are interested in what this week's specials are at Woolworths or K-Mart stores-are given the option of receiving this material. It gives others who do not like receiving such mail or who are afraid of the consequence to their property if they cannot prevent such mail being deposited in their letter-boxes the option of preventing its delivery. I believe what I suggest is possible.

I urge the Government to consider this matter. From evidence given at hearings of Estimates Committee B I am not satisfied that this matter is being considered seriously through the report procedure about which we heard. If no strong recommendations or if, indeed, no recommendations are put forward in that report -it was not clearly indicated to members of Estimates Committee B that there would necessarily be any recommendations in relation to this matter-then I would like the Government to consider it as a matter of urgency. Every year at Christmas time-the Christmas holidays are not far away, I am sorry to say-we have a spate of burglaries throughout Australia when people are away on holidays . I would be very interested to know-perhaps the police can do some sort of pilot study in some of the suburbs of our cities-how many people who discovered that their homes had been burglarised when they returned from holidays had taken action to cancel their newspaper and milk deliveries and to have their mail withheld but had letter-boxes jammed to overflowing with this type of advertising indicating that they were on holidays.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge and I am sure the Government acknowledges that the matter of junk mail and its consequences is of some importance. I will make sure that the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) has his attention drawn to the comments made by Senator Martin today. My understanding from the officers of the Department of Communications is that the Minister has expressed to his Department his concern about junk mail. He has asked the Department, in concert with Australia Post, to examine the problem to see what can be done. He understands that there are some legislative difficulties. He is looking to see whether they can be overcome. I think the important thing is that I pass on the comments that have been made today and ask the Minister to study them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to turn to another matter which falls within the purview of the Department of Communications-the Special Broadcasting Service. I refer to the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs review of the Galbally recommendations for 1982-83 and the suggestion that an amount of $650,000 for support for ethnic broadcasting over public radio be expended. I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) whether it is a fact that the Institute of Multicultural Affairs, for some reason, does not concern itself with Aboriginal matters and that of the $650,000 appropriated for ethnic broadcasting some $52,000 has now been extracted, as it were, for the purposes of Aboriginal broadcasting? Is that not inconsistent with the recommendation of the Institute of Multicultural Affairs? Has not the sum of money available for ethnic broadcasting, as that Institute recommended, effectively been reduced by that amount to $598,000?

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the work of the Special Broadcasting Service, I would like the Minister to tell the Senate, if he can, what happened to the special migrant advisory panel which was to be set up to advise Channel 0-28 regarding program matters. Did the Government first indicate that it was to be established in May 1981 or thereabouts? Was the panel to be established under the chairmanship of Mr Frank Galbally, the Melbourne criminal lawyer? Why has that panel not been established? Has it anything to do with Mr Galbally's involvement with the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? Does that have anything to do with the fact that the panel has never been set up?

Another matter I wish to raise is slightly different. It relates to captions on television for the hearing impaired. Did the Government in 1981, during the International Year of Disabled Persons, announce that one of its special initiatives would be to provide captions on television for the hearing impaired? Was $650,000 appropriated in that year for that purpose? If it is a fact that that sum of money was appropriated for that purpose as a gesture in the International Year of Disabled Persons, why has the Government in fact done nothing about this matter other than successfully push the unfortunate Australian Broadcasting Commission into providing that service? What is the current state of the proposal to provide captions on Australian television for the hearing impaired? Is it a fact that the Government has now appointed a further inquiry into the matter with the possibility that the $650,000 spent in the International Year of Disabled Persons has effectively gone down the spout? If it has appointed a further inquiry, why has that been necessary? Is it because the Government is a little timorous about leaning on the commercial networks in Australia to do what their counterparts in the United States did voluntarily in providing captions on United States television for the deaf?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) asked a series of questions. His first question concerned the sum of $650,000 out of which he said an amount of $52,000 was earmarked for Aborigines. The advice I have from the departmental officers is that the Budget decision specifically earmarked funds for Aboriginal broadcasting. The second question related to the establishment of the advisory council of the Special Broadcasting Service I am advised that the membership is currently under consideration by Cabinet. I know of no reason why Mr Galbally, whose excellent work in the migrant field has been commended by migrants generally, should have any connection at all to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I stress that Mr Galbally has been widely commended throughout the whole of the migrant community for the work that he has done. I hope that that would be acknowledged in a bipartisan fashion by all in this Parliament, as it is in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: As to captioning for the hearing impaired, I am advised that the Government funded the establishment of the Australian Caption Centre in the International Year of Disabled Persons. It has subsequently funded the Australian Broadcasting Commission service and is now discussing the terms of reference of an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal into the provisions of this service by commercial television stations. The commercial stations can use the services of the Australian Caption Centre. If one looks to the Estimates of the current year , one will see that an amount has been earmarked in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the advisory council to Channel 0-28, I should like the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick), in view of his answer, to tell the Senate why, if it is a fact that that proposal was announced in May 1981 and was greeted with wide acclaim by Cannel 0-28 viewers and ethnic communities, it has taken nearly 19 months for the Government to appoint the members of the panel when it was able to anounce the chairman of that panel in May 1981. Why can it not find two or three other people to sit on the panel if it could so easily appoint the chairman in May 1981?

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I should like to pursue the question of captioning of television programs for the deaf. I ask the Minister again: Did not the Prime Minister of this country in 1980, when he was making a big thing of the International Year of Disabled Persons and a big fellow of himself about what this Government would do for the disabled, announce that the Government would see that captions were provided on television for the hearing impaired in Australia? I seek to pursue why it is only the Australian Broadcasting Commission which will offer this facility. Why is there now a need for an inquiry? Why is the Government, two years later, mucking about trying to get terms of reference to an inquiry into why the commercial networks should provide this facility? Why, in view of that specific undertaking, has nothing happened? Is it that the Government is just not prepared to lean on the commercial networks to see that this service is provided for disabled people in Australia? I make the point that it was not necessary for any government to lean on the networks in the United States of America; they voluntarily did it. If the commercial stations are not prepared to provide this service in Australia, why does not the Government do something about it instead of setting up yet another inquiry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two questions raised. Senator Button has reverted to his question on the Special Broadcastling Service advisory council and has made comments about the delay. He has sought to make some comment about the delay being associated with Mr Galbally. I remind Senator Button that on the one hand he is talking about a delay of a year or more. On the other hand he is talking about the Costigan Royal Commission report that is only a few months old; so the two cannot be considered together. The basic delay has covered a longer period than that. It has been due to deliberation on the general composition and structure of the council. Recently the Government has decided to expedite this matter and there should be an announcement soon. But I make the clear point that whatever the other reasons for the delay, they had nothing to do with either Mr Galbally or with the Costigan Royal Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the captions for the hearing impaired, the Australian Broadcasting Commission will begin a closed caption service in this year. The commercial stations have not agreed to participate in that service because of concern over technical matters. The additional funding sought this year will maintain the Australian captions centre until the ABC service begins. However, I stress what I have said, that is, that the Government is pursuing this matter in terms of the commercial stations. It has set up an inquiry and will persist in endeavouring to ensure that the best possible arrangements are made with all television stations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) for his answer about the Australian captions service. I hope I will not have to be asking about it next year. Insofar as I was pursing the question of delay in relation to the advisory panel on Channel 0-28, the multicultural television station, I asked why this panel, which was announced in May 1981 under the chairmanship of Mr Galbally, had not been appointed. The Minister has now given an answer. But of course it is an unsatisfactory answer to me because in the course of giving his answer he tried to suggest that the delay could not have anything to do with the Costigan Royal Commission because that report was published only two or three months ago. But I ask the Minister whether he is not aware that within weeks of the announcement by the Government that it would appoint Mr Galbally as chairman of this committee and appoint the committee, Mr Galbally was featuring in all Australian newspapers as a witness before the Costigan Royal Commission and being asked why he put $11,000 in the boot of his Mercedes Benz after a court hearing, a sum which had not been, in the view of the Commission, properly accounted for. I am merely seeking to make it clear to the Minister that I did not confuse the issue. It is not a question of the publication of the Costigan report. It is a question of whether the delay has occurred because of Mr Galbally's involvement before the Costigan Royal Commission. I am not suggesting that the Costigan report has found anything reprehensible about Mr Galbally. He does rate a chapter, I admit. But the question is whether the delay was occasioned by his appearances before that Royal Commission and evidence which was a matter of public knowledge about the time that the Government made this particular announcement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing to add to what I have said. Certainly I had no knowledge that the appearance of anyone before a Costigan Royal Commisson would have any influence upon what a government would do. There were many people who came before--
—It didn't with Harry Miller, did it?

—I would have thought that the Australian Labor Party would have learned by now the danger of simply picking up names and dropping them. Mr Hayden and his followers fell on their face very badly by picking up names in the Costigan Royal Commission. They were very busy picking up names but now they are a little ashamed that Mr Cain is quite happy to appoint people who were named in the McCabe-Lafranchi report and Mr Wran is quite happy to be associated with the chairman of the Public Service Board in New South Wales. The name dropping exercise, I suggest, was the most futile and time wasting one that the Labor Party has ever embarked upon. It turned and it bit the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I can say only that I was unaware of any such connection. I am not aware that the Government had any such knowledge and the answer I gave about the delay is the one that the officers from the Department advised me. Furthermore, I am advised, and it is within my knowledge, that the Government intends to proceed in the early future to establish the advisory council.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) for his lecture about how we should conduct ourselves. The point I seek to make is simply this. This committee was promised in May 1981. It was a very popular promise and it has concerned many ethnic communities that the promise has not been honoured. There is nothing new about that with this Government. But the point I make is that there is widespread speculation that this is the reason why the committee has never been appointed. If Senator Sir John Carrick wants to say that I should not mention Frank Galbally's name in this place because of some specious view that he has about the niceties of politics, that is fine. But we are concerned about the appointment of this committee. That is what people involved with the running of Channel 0-28 and its suggested benefits to ethnic communities are concerned about. That is all I seek to establish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask some questions about a particular matter concerning Telecom Australia. I doubt whether I will be able to receive answers tonight but it may be possible for the answers to be obtained during the dinner break. If not, I am hopeful that they will be provided to me at some time in the near future. When I was a young teacher-in fact before I was 21 years of age-I received a transfer to go to a school at Gallangowan. At that stage I did not know where Gallangowan was so I took out the preference sheet that we used to have in schools. I looked it up and it stated: 'Gallangowan, 35 miles from Goomeri by coach'. It was a very old preference list and it did not really mean by motor coach. It gave an indication that it was a very isolated area and when I arrived there I found that, indeed, it was quite isolated. By road it is 35 miles from Goomeri and 36 miles from Murgon. Those are the two closest centres.

SPEECH.PARA: A little while ago I had the opportunity of revisiting Gallangowan. It has not changed much since I was there. It is still very isolated and, in terms of telephone connections probably even more so than it was in those days. Years ago when I was there people could, at a pinch, travel about five miles to the local exchange to make a telephone call. But now the local exchange has been removed because subscriber trunk dialling has come to the area. So there is no local telephone for the people at Gallangowan. I suppose the only major improvement since I was there as a teacher is that electricity is now available through the area. I remember that when I was there 20-odd years ago we made efforts to obtain a public telephone for the settlement. Those efforts were not successful. Some time ago a public telephone was introduced into the place. However, when I went there a few weeks ago I was astounded to find that the public telephone had been taken out. The public telephone box was still there but the telephone had been removed. I understand that it was removed because a new telephone had to be supplied as a result of the introduction of STD in the area. Telecom apparently decided that the telephone was not warranted. It took out the old telephone but did not put in a new one. I subsequently wrote to the State Manager for Telecom about this matter. I would like to read to the Senate his reply because I think it is pertinent to the matters that I raise. The letter read as follows:
I refer to your recent inquiry about public telephone facilities at the Gallangowan Forest Reserve.

Although Telecom recognises the need to provide public telephones as widely as possible throughout the community, priority must be given to locations where the usage will be sufficient to at least partially compensate for the high installation and maintenance costs involved.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about the tiny settlement of Gallangowan in south-east Queensland and how, after some time, a public telephone had been installed at the settlement. But when subscriber trunk dialling facilities were provided to the area the phone was removed and a new telephone was not installed. I outlined that this is an isolated place which needs a telephone. Before the suspension of the sitting I was reading a letter that I had received from the State manager of Telecom Australia after I had written to him about the removal of the telephone. I will read that letter again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to your recent enquiry about public telephone facilities at the Gallangowan Forest Reserve.

Although Telecom recognises the need to provide public telephones as widely as possible throughout the community, priority must be given to locations where the usage will be sufficient to at least partially compensate for the high installation and maintenance costs involved.

In the case of the Gallangowan Forest Reserve, a thorough survey which was carried out before the area was converted to automatic working, revealed that only limited use had been made of the public telephone facility during recent years. The survey also showed that the Department of Forestry employees and their families, rather than the travelling public, made most use of the facility .

Despite sympathetic consideration of all the circumstances, therefore, it was not possible to justify the additional cost of replacing the Gallangowan public telephone with an S.T.D. type when the area was converted to automatic working on 9 June 1982.

I understand that the Department of Forestry recently decided to lease an S.T.D . type coin telephone for the use of their employees at Gallangowan. These S.T.D . units are presently in very short supply but in recognition of the relative isolation of the area, one will be made available for installation within six weeks.

I make two comments about that letter. Firstly, it said that a survey had revealed that only limited use had been made of the public telephone facility during recent years. It is possible that only limited use was made because there are about 80 people living at the settlement. But I was informed when I was there a few weeks ago that, because of the isolation, the coin box was not emptied very often and that the phone was out of order for some time because the coin box was full. That would have something to do with the limited use being made of the public telephone. When that happened the residents had to go to the forestry office or the forestry ranger's residence or the school to make their telephone calls. It would not need a survey to show that Department of Forestry employees and their families used the telephone rather than the travelling public as stated in the letter because very few members of the travelling public go through Gallangowan. They would have to make a detour of several kilometres off a main road to get to the settlement. It appears therefore that the people of Gallangowan will have a public telephone. They will not have a public telephone because Telecom Australia will reinstall a public telephone in the box that was left after the telephone was removed, but they will have a telephone because the Department of Forestry will install that public telephone after having leased it from Telecom Australia.

I wanted the departmental officers to obtain information, but because the Senate suspended its sitting for dinner it will probably be hard to obtain that information tonight. I am hopeful that the Minister will ask officers of the Department of Communications to provide answers to these questions. Firstly, how much will the Forestry Department pay for the lease of the telephone? Who will retain the moneys for calls made from the public telephone once it is installed? Is Telecom not interested in providing public telephone facilities for people in isolated areas? It seems strange that there was a public telephone in that area and when the changeover to STD facilities was made it was removed. If it had not been for the Department of Forestry offering to lease a telephone the facility would not have been available. I saw the telephone box when I was at Gallangowan and it was intact. There seemed to be wires which could be connected to a telephone. It did not seem to require anything to be done other than for the telephone cabinet to be installed. Is it the policy that in settlements like this, where there are few people and where there is a telephone which is changed over to STD, the telephone is removed or is it policy that in a forestry settlement such as this it is up to the State Department of Forestry to install and supply a public telephone? Finally, where else in Queensland does a similar situation prevail? Where else in Queensland is a public telephone leased by one of the Queensland Government departments rather than supplied by Telecom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers heard what Senator Colston said prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner but they were not able to obtain the information that they believed he was seeking at that time. Having heard the questions they will undertake to contact Telecom Australia and get an early reply for Senator Colston. I noted the questions with regard to moneys that will be received for calls and the other things that were mentioned relating to the leasing by the State department and so on, and also the inquiries about other isolated areas in Queensland. I hope Senator Colston will accept my assurance that we will contact Telecom and get a reply as early as possible. I think that is as far as we can take it at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we leave the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Communications, I have some further comments to make. During the recent hearing of the Senate Estimates Committee B concerning proposed expenditure for 1982-83 for the Department of Communications, some honourable senators expressed interest in the progress of the 1981-82 annual reports produced by the Department of Communications and the statutory authorities encompassed by the Communications portfolio. Before outlining the position regarding the progress of these reports I would like to mention that the Minister for Communications ( Mr N. A. Brown) has taken a specific interest in the preparation of the annual reports within his portfolio. Shortly after his appointment the Minister requested his Department to convey to the statutory bodies within the portfolio his concern to see that annual reports were tabled promptly.

He has since received information, as have I, on the satisfactory progress of the production of the 1981-82 annual reports for the Department of Communications and authorities. In all instances it is anticipated that the 1981 -82 annual reports, or interim reports where necessary, for the Communications portfolio will be tabled during the current session of Parliament. Extensive details on this matter relating to the Department and each statutory authority have been made available to the Senate Estimates Committee and I believe that should resolve any matters of concern individual senators may have in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an item in relation to the Australian Theatre Board's allocations to various theatre companies around Australia and, in particular, to the Popular Theatre Troupe in my State of Queensland. The funding of that troupe by the Theatre Board of the Australia Council has been continuous for the past eight years, but recently an announcement was made that as at 30 December of this year funding would be cut. Under normal circumstances, of course, the troupe could reapply for funding by next February. But since it is a fully professional body and obviously has continuing commitments to both staff and actors, this hiatus in its funding, even if it were successful in having funding restored next year, would mean the destruction of the troupe. The fact is that in Australia there are no unsubsidised professional theatre companies. Indeed, theatre companies require a subsidy either by way of Federal or State government grant or grant from private enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: The subsidy for the Popular Theatre Troupe had been under review during the whole of last year. The reasons given by the Theatre Board were a high turnover of actors and administrators, a lack of artistic innovation, and the fact that it had no alternative funding. The last reason is not unexceptional, since the nature of the productions of the Popular Theatre Troupe could be expected in most cases to be antithetical to the State Government, which is not necessarily entirely sympathetic to such didactic theatre.

From my knowledge of theatre companies around Australia, it would be very difficult to substantiate, even on an objective basis, a denial of funds on the ground of a high turnover of actors and administrators. Fairly obviously, the low level of the troupe's funding meant that it was exceptionally difficult, financially, to keep it operating at a viable level. Hence, the cost to the people involved was often the sacrificing of their career.

I believe that the Popular Theatre Troupe has made a solid contribution to theatre in Queensland in regard to its written material, its productions and its generating of what has been recognised in other States also as a worthwhile theatre of social criticism. Of course, it is well known that the productions of the troupe tend to have a political bent that is not acceptable to the government of the day. I expect that exactly the same view would be taken whether if the government were a National Party, Liberal Party or Australian Labor Party government. A theatre of social criticism is not readily acceptable in my State of Queensland but I would have thought that it be one which the Theatre Board would have seen as worth supporting and continuing to support.

Unlike stable theatre companies of the conventional kind, the troupe's performance of drama in such places as prisons, factories, hospitals, schools, handicapped persons' institutions, workers' clubs, mental institutions, alcohol rehabilitation centres, conferences, senior citizens clubs and, of course, the street itself shows that it has been willing to provide theatre for the citizens of my State and other States in places in which the more conventional theatre companies do not undertake that task.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did it get from the State Government?

—I am coming to that, Senator. Until the Theatre Board announced that it would cut off the Popular Theatre Troupe's funds, its program for the next year had been mapped out. It included the provision of drama at institutions such as I have mentioned. The State Government has not, in the eight years of the Popular Theatre Troupe's existence, supported it by way of financial grant except in those cases in which the troupe undertook a particular program as part of normal school theatre operations. The point I raise is that in the past few years a number of decisions taken by the Theatre Board have later been reversed by the Government through its providing increased funds.
