I hope that the Government will be able to indicate its intentions and state whether the Theatre Board's decision in this case was prompted-as we were told last year when funds for a number of theatre groups in Queensland were cut off- by lack of finance. Can the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) indicate whether that is again the case in regard to Theatre Board allocations around Australia, or whether some other reason can be advanced?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin's speech is a very good example of what concerns me about our present system of arts funding. The Australian Theatre Board was set up to distribute the available funds, taking into account the quality of the company, the quality of its productions, its fund raising efforts in other areas, the amount of local support it can raise and its audiences. This is a very detailed assessment and one which needs to be decided by professionals. It is not an easy task. Whenever funds to a body are cut off, it will have a thousand reasons why it, rather than some other body, should be funded.

SPEECH.PARA: What must not happen, in my view, is for the Parliament or the Cabinet to be involved in these decisions. The job of the Government and this Parliament is to decide what sort of funds we should allocate to the Australia Council and, through it, to the Theatre Board. The professionals are able to weigh all the factors and the competing demands for funds and it should be left to them to decide. Disgruntled people should not be able to come to the Parliament or to the Government and expect redress. We should tell them-as I think Senator Macklin has told people who have contacted him-that the decision has been made by the Theatre Board. If they have further arguments they should be put to that body. They should not go to the Government or to the Parliament to have that decision reversed. That is the very negation of the system of arts administration set up by successive governments-an arms length system which involves establishing a body such as the Australia Council with experts in the various arts fields to undertake decision making.

Although this does not affect the Popular Theatre Troupe at all-it falls directly under the Theatre Board-the way in which the present Government has departed from the arms length principle in a number of areas is a source of worry to me. I refer to the way in which specific arts grants are made to the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet Foundation and the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust orchestras. This is very undesirable. I spoke at length about it in the Senate last year and find myself obliged to say almost exactly the same things this year. I have spoken to successive Ministers about it in the interval but so far there has been no change. It is highly undesirable and very damaging to the arts for these sorts of direct negotiations to be conducted with Cabinet. Members of the Cabinet, with the best will in the world- they are in no sense arts experts-are making arbitrary decisions without professional advice on what allocations are to be made to a particular body such as the Ballet, the Opera or the Trust orchestras. What we must do is implement our principles with regard to the decentralisation of arts funds and the arm's length principle.

I now turn to individual items in the estimates which should, in my view, come under the Australia Council and should not be directly decided by the Cabinet. The first item is Artbank, which is part of division 330. Artbank was established three years ago to co-ordinate all government art lending and to acquire works of art for placement on hire in public places. This year its allocation is $430,000. That is all very well, but the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council has an identical role. Surely it should be the body to decide whether out of the available arts funds $430,000 is appropriate for this function. By approving the estimates we are pre-empting a decision of the expert body which we have appointed. I think this is quite wrong. I would recommend that this function be brought back under the Australia Council. As I understand it, Artbank comes under the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Therefore, it would not be possible for the Australia Council to make a grant to its own parent department. I think the simple answer would be to abolish Artbank and turn that function over to the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council.

Another body that should come under the Australia Council is the Australian National Gallery, which was opened recently. The Gallery is now completed. It has a budget this year of $15.4m for administration, including $4.667m for acquisitions. The balance between what is spent on the Gallery and what is spent on other areas of the arts, again, is a matter of expert judgment. The decision is made arbitrarily-I have no doubt after due thought -by Cabinet. I do not think that Cabinet is appropriately qualified to make this sort of judgment. Nothing can happen before 1988, because the forward commitments for acquisitions by the National Gallery must remain, but after that I think the Australian National Gallery should come under the Australia Council and should receive its funding in competition with alternative ways of spending on other art forms. One very great advantage of that is that acquisitions form a sort of buffer that can be used by the Australia Council. If the Council has a temporary restriction on its funds, with salaries being the main component of the companies which it supports, it has no buffer. Acquisitions of the National Gallery could be delayed or advanced and provide a financial buffer to make the working of the Australia Council funding more efficient.

The votes which I particularly dislike all come under the Australia Council Act . Having set up the Australia Council, we might think that it had discretion to spend its funds in the way in which it chooses. That is not the case. The Council is directed to give the Australian Ballet Foundation $1.772m. It is directed to give the Australian Opera $3.692m. It is directed to give the Elizabethan Theatre Trust orchestras $3.032m. Those are not discretionary decisions by the Australia Council. It is ordered by Cabinet-as far as I can determine, on no professional advice-that that is the appropriate amount to go to those bodies. I find that very disturbing indeed. There are other defects which I will come to in a moment. The only areas of discretionary expenditure by the Australia Council are allocations of $20.017m for general support for the arts and $5.087m for administration. Large chunks of its grant are pre-empted and directed by the Cabinet without proper professional consideration. I do not consider that an acceptable way to give support to the arts in this country.

This situation poses a number of problems. The first is-I do not suppose honourable senators on the other side of the chamber would attach too much importance to this-that it is contrary to the platform of the Liberal Party. We have, in our platform, an expression on the arts that particular judgments should be made by those having specialist knowledge. I do not think anyone would pretend that members of the Cabinet have specialist knowledge in the field of the arts. The second problem is that it is bad administration to have these arbitrary decisions made by people without professional knowledge, and it is bad politics. We may think in our early days in politics that it is wonderful to be a latter day Medici giving out funds for the arts but, in fact, it is terrible politics because for every grant that we give we make one friend and 10 enemies are made. That is bad politics in anyone's terms. We should give the responsibility to the Australia Council, let it make the decisions and let it take the objections. If Senator Macklin had an objection about the Popular Theatre Troupe, he would go straight to the Australia Council and not the Government. The Australia Council would make the decision as to whether the Theatre Troupe was an appropriate body to be supported.

Perhaps the most serious objection to this method of funding is that it damages the bodies which it is supposed to favour. For instance, the Australian Ballet has been an artistic disaster area for several years. There are serious structural problems with the orchestras-one in Sydney and one in Melbourne. The Australian Opera must be the only major opera company that changes its orchestra when it goes from one city to another. This is a ridiculous procedure. There are serious problems regarding relations between the Australian Opera and the regional operas. The trouble is that with a method of funding directly from Cabinet to these organisations no one is in a position to take the necessary sorting out of administrative action to make these organisations function sensibly. We have given away the power of the purse. No one is in a position to exercise it. I think this is a very serious defect in our arts administration. Last year I said that I would, and I was ready to do it, move a request for an amendment to the estimates to bring all these separate directed votes back under a one-line appropriation, giving the discretion and the responsibility where it should be-that is, with the Australia Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the Ballet and the Opera.

—The Ballet, the Opera, the Trust orchestras, administration and general support for the arts should all be lumped together and a single vote given to the Australia Council. It would make the decisions, it would take the responsibility and it would get the criticism. That is how it should be. Actually, I have the request here but I will not distribute it because I fear that it might be carried. If it were carried it would pose a serious structural problem for the Government. I have had substantial words of support on this side of the chamber. I think that a majority of people on this side of the chamber would support it. I hope that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) have noted that. I fear that the Opposition, not out of principle but out of mischief, might also support it. That would cause very great difficulties because, as I think we are all aware, the House of Representatives is getting up tonight and may not sit again this year. The money available to the Government is rapidly diminishing and I think that to delay the passing of the Appropriation Bills over a relatively minor issue such as this would not be acceptable. Nevertheless, to the people involved in the arts community this is a very important issue. Last year I fired what might be called a blank shot. This year I fire the live shot across the bows. I give notice now that next year I will fire to hit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the discussion that went on last year about Senator Hamer's proposed amendment to reincorporate the three separate lines to which he referred into the total Australia Council budget. It was a measure which we supported but which, as I understand it, Senator Ryan felt the Australian Labor Party was not quite ready to support last year. I gather that Senator Hamer has chickened out again this year simply on the grounds that the House of Representatives is rising for the remainder of this year. This means that at least, the Liberal side of this chamber is bowing to House of Representatives blackmail.
—More mischievous than principled, I would say.

—I do not know that honourable senators opposite can even spell the word, so there is not much point in discussing the matter-and I am not referring to the word 'mischievous'. I am not going to bow to the little lecture that Senator Hamer issued in the general direction of these benches about whether we should or should not take up a particular issue for a particular theatre company. I remind Senator Hamer, as piously as he reminded us of certain issues, that we are senators representing particular States and if an organisation in a State is threatened, and that threat could affect the education and the entertainment of in the vicinity of 30,000 school children, we would be derelict in our duty if we did not take up the cudgels either directly by representation to the Australia Council or indirectly via this chamber to it. I am wielding the cudgel tonight on behalf of the Little Patch theatre company which was established in 1972 by Morna Jones, who unfortunately, died early this year, a death which, removing as it did the artistic director, precipitated some of the problems which arose later in the year. She established the company specifically to provide entertainment and education to young people through theatre. In 1977 it became a general grant company. As one of our newspapers noted early in October of this year, the Little Patch theatre company received a $48,000 grant last year. On 30 September this year it was informed that the Theatre Board had withdrawn the grant. The Director of the Theatre Board, Mr Michael Fitzgerald, said from Sydney that other companies had stronger claims to the limited funds available. I acknowledge Senator Hamer's point, that because of the line division limited funds are available to the Australia Council. Notwithstanding that, the Theatre Board felt that it had to take money from existing companies because it had no flexibility. It seems somewhat draconian to take away the entire grant from one of the few organisations in South Australia that was providing educational and entertaining theatre to school children. Senator Macklin raised the question of the Popular Theatre Troupe in Queensland. As I understood it, he said amongst other things that it had been refused funding because it had a high staff turnover and it had received no other funding.
—They took the lot.

—As Senator Keeffe said, the Board took the lot from that group, too. Clearly that is not the case with the Little Patch. It had received private funding from the Brighton Lions Club, the Brighton City Council, the State Government and the Department of Community Welfare. It also received one-off grants from the State Government's Department of the Arts, and the Education Department of South Australia has continued to provide a seconded teaching position at the Little Patch. Clearly it has the support not only of various private organisations in South Australia but also of various State Government departments. As far as I am aware there has not been a high staff turnover in the Little Patch. It employs five full time staff who, according to the administrator, have been specifically chosen because of their multiple skills. There is a writer-actor-puppeteer, a musician-actor-puppeteer, a technical person who also does acting and puppeteer work, an artistic director and an administrator-secretary. Unfortunately these people have been placed in a rather unstable situation, as the Department of the Arts in South Australia has told them that no money is available for them before this time next year and the Australia Council has told them that, whilst they may resubmit, any application will not be looked at before a special meeting to be held in February. That means that the company will have to get yet more private funding, since no State funding or Commonwealth funding is available before February, or its staff cannot be maintained. It does seem a shame that simply because the originator of the company, its original director, died earlier this year and was replaced by someone who, I point out for Senator Hamer's particular interest, had the approval of the Australia Council but was found to be not adequate, not to have the personality to deal with the sorts of things required by this particular theatre, the Theatre Board has decided that it cannot get their act together sufficiently to warrant funds.

SPEECH.PARA: This theatre company was established in the beginning of the 1970s by Morna Jones simply because of the belief that many adults were unaware of live theatre and would therefore be unlikely to encourage their children to attend live theatre. She believed that those school children should be given the opportunity of coming into contact with something which was both educational and entertaining, which would then lead them to a love of the theatre and would take them on to an adult lifetime of enjoying professional productions, and for that matter amateur productions. It seems a shame that this innovative theatre, which was directed at a specific audience with specific aims-exactly the sort of people to which Senator Hamer was referring-and which had a particular sort of staff, after a decade of providing entertainment through 300 performances a year , catering for some 30,000 children each year, should be forced to fold up simply because the Theatre Board has seen fit to cut its grant. I suggest that it is my role as a senator for South Australia, notwithstanding the fact that Senator Hamer sees the decisions as being the sole preserve of the Theatre Board on the grounds that it has some highly constituted, intuitive claim to being omniscient in this regard, to step in on behalf of this organisation and not to say that Parliament should keep at arm's length from theatre funding. I ask the Australia Council through this chamber at least to consider reallocating money to the Little Patch theatre before February of next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to support what Senator Hamer had to say in relation to the principle of arts funding. I supported Senator Hamer on the last occasion he raised this subject. I appreciate the difficulties we have been put into in terms of time this year mainly because the House of Representatives has held up the Senate's program and we have had a late passing through to us of the Appropriation Bills. They are practical difficulties. I am pleased to get an indication from the Opposition that perhaps this year it has moved some distance towards the thinking of Senator Hamer and me because certainly it was not of that mind when this matter was raised in the debate on the Appropriation Bills last year. I certainly hope also that the Government will take note of the matter and reconsider this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to debate the ins and outs of the Popular Theatre Troupe or the organisation about which Senator Haines was concerned. I just reiterate that the purpose of the Australian Council is arm's length funding for artistic groups. When the Theatre Board, which has on it qualified people who have a well known set of criteria for determining funding to organisations, makes a recommendation it may be a sorry state of affairs according to some honourable senators, that they cannot debate and change that decision in the Senate. They must realise that the other side of the coin is one that they should applaud; that is, that politicians should not decide where this type of funding is to go. The fact that the Popular Theatre Troupe was not to receive any funding for 1983 was something I knew of only after the Popular Theatre Troupe informed me of it. Whilst it has been alleging that this has happened for political reasons, I do not think it has any justification at all for that. Certainly it has had its altercations with the State Government but that has not affected its Federal funding. I am obliged, as on previous occasions, to accept the ruling of the Theatre Board as to the priorities of demands of theatre groups for public funding.

Two items that I want to raise in a separate way relate to matters that arose in Estimates Committee B. I asked a series of questions in relation to grants in aid to certain organisations when we were considering the estimates of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I asked about the priorities that determine the level of funding for certain organisations, the criteria that government uses to draw its conclusions independently and I also asked for an indication of what importance is given to the public or group activities of certain organisations. Two organisations I was particularly interested in at that stage, and still am, were the National Council of Women of Australia and the Country Women's Association.

In the response that came in printed replies, which were recently tabled in the Senate, my questions have not been answered. I am given a description of the method of consideration of grants and of all the grants in aid groups that were listed in the Estimates. They are divided into two groups and a description is given of the way the different groupings of organisations are treated. My questions on priorities and criteria and the importance attached to public or group activities of organisations have not been answered. I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) whether that information can be provided.

My reason for asking those questions was this: Amongst the groups referred to in the written response, are group B organisations which include the two women's organisations I have referred to, as well as some other organisations. I do not want to suggest that any of these other groups should have got less, but what I am about to say might give some indication of why I was interested in criteria. For example, the National Council of Women of Australia which is an organisation which speaks for over one million women in various women's organisations in Australia, receives for 1982-83 exactly the same grant as it received for 1981- 82, and that is the breathtaking sum of $8,000. The Country Women's Association which, I would hazard a guess, is the largest women's organisation in Australia and a very significant one, received also for 1982-83 the same amount of money as for 1981-82, and that was the astonishing figure of $3,500. I have to say that those figures are puzzling. One wonders what the Government thinks an organisation such as the National Council of Women of Australia could possibly achieve with $8,000. It would obviously achieve more than it would with nothing, but very little more. In fact it receives next to nothing. Certainly one wonders what sort of a contribution to the Country Women's Association is $3,500.

The latter organisation does a great deal of essential good works in the community, works that would not be done if that organisation were not doing them . It takes a particular interest in providing facilities to assist children in very isolated areas to have access to schools. It has had various projects that have had a very strong health bent. At one stage it raised very large sums of money so that hospitals in country areas could have provided to them technical equipment which meant that information on heart patients could be transmitted instantaneously to specialist hospitals in capital cities, and assistance in diagnosis on the basis of the information transmitted could be sent back instantaneously to those country hospitals and to the country town doctors who were attempting to help patients needing immediate assistance in those towns. That is just one example of a number of extremely worthwhile projects that the CWA has involved itself in. It provides a vital service in our country towns in remote areas. The women in that organisation, working in their own individually modest way, provide essential assistance to the social fabric of our country areas.

Against the appropriations to those organisations, I contrast the amount of $ 400,000 granted to the Surf Life Saving Association of Australia. This is a very worthwhile association and I was one who last year pressed for some increased assistance. The grant last year was $330,000, so the Surf Life Saving Association has received an increase. The Royal Life Saving Society Australia receives in 1982-83 $200,000 as against $110,000 in 1981-82. So some organisations have received substantial increases and are receiving substantial sums of money. I would not suggest for a minute that any of the money going to the Surf Life Saving Association or to the Royal Life Saving Society should be taken from them and given to another organisation, but I have to query as strongly as I can those pitiful sums of money that go to the National Council of Women and the Country Women's Association, both of which are doing very worthy work. I suggest that the CWA, is doing work equally worthy of those other two organisations which receive very substantial sums of money. I reiterate what I said at the beginning of my speech, they were the reasons for my asking questions about priorities and, the criteria and importance that is attached to the public or group activities of organisations in this category. I reiterate that I have not received an answer to those questions although I have received a description of the administrative way in which the determination on the amounts of grants for those organisations is handled.

I also want to speak briefly on another matter that arose in relation to the estimates for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I asked a series of questions in relation to a superannuation scheme that is being set up for employees of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. I received a quite detailed answer. I cannot and would not attempt to go through all the details but I think the Senate should know some basic facts about the proposed superannuation scheme for this Authority. I shall read just one section of the reply. It states:

Employee contributions will be mandatory; staff members may elect to contribute at the rate of 2.5 per cent, 5 per cent or 7.5 per cent of annual salary. Employer contributions will be made at the rate of 15 per cent of salary for staff other than a limited number of senior staff whose appointments are subject to the approval of the Chairman, for whom the proposed rate of contribution is 20 per cent of salary.

That is, to put it mildly, a very generous superannuation scheme. For employee contributions of 2.5 per cent, 5 per cent or 7.5 per cent employer contributions -that is, contributions from public funds-will be at least 15 per cent and possibly 20 per cent. I had heard that this Authority was setting itself up an extraordinarily generous superannuation scheme. Those facts support that. Whilst I am not going through all the details of the answer, I am not in any way not doing justice to the answer that was given to me by leaving out all those other details. The Authority will obviously be only a short lived one. As I understand it will exist only until 1990, and what will happen then to the contributions? The position of anyone on leaving the Authority is perfectly adequate and satisfactory and it would be so if the contributions by the employer, that is, the public purse, were a lower rate. The answer also contains the following information:
The finer details of the scheme are still being considered by officers of the Department of Finance and the scheme has yet to be approved by the Minister for Finance.
I urge the Minister for Finance to take a long time approving this scheme and to be thoroughly satisfied that it is a proper way to be treating public funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments about the Australia Council and to reflect somewhat on the comments of Senator Hamer. I am not certain whether Senator Hamer was here-perhaps even Senator Martin was not here-when the Senate took up the debate on the Australia Council and the problems that the Australia Council posed early in its establishment. If I recall correctly, what Senator Hamer proposes was the method by which the Australia Council operated. It received a sum of money, some $20m, and further to that, another $3m, I think, to administer the $20m. Some of us considered that $3m to be an enormous amount for administrative costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite a number of criticisms arose in the Senate, both in committees and in the Senate as a whole, concerning the Australia Council and its operation in its early years. One of the main points was that the Australia Council, in its operation, opened itself to a wide range of criticisms in that it extended patronage in a rather elegant and elitist way, a patronage which seemed to direct the moneys made available to it in directions which suited the administrators of the Council. The patronage exposed itself in a variety of ways . The abuses were substantial. I think that the abuses eventually led, perhaps unfortunately, to Dr Battersby being moved to one side. That was to be regretted . But the Australia Council took upon itself the role of being patron of the arts, with all the problems and the abuses which followed.

It was not very encouraging to hear, in the committees of the Senate and in the Senate as a whole, about the manner in which moneys were used and misused, about the extremely lengthy lunch hour working parties, about the opening nights with extensive guest lists, about patronage to important people and patronage to some senators. I remember in particular patronage to a former senator, Senator Davidson, who happend to be chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, which was carrying out an investigation of the Australia Council. To our horror, we found that he was a guest of the Australia Council at an opening night, and the costs of that were met out of the funds of the Australia Council. The area of abuse was substantial, to the point that the Senate determined that there should be some supervision. I think that the Government came to that conclusion and restructured the Australia Council.

If there is now some itemised accountability on the part of the Australia Council which enables some political supervision to take place, it is as a result of what occurred in those early days, and what will again occur if what Senator Hamer proposes comes to pass. So I suggest that we are here not just to sign the cheques, as Mr Mollison expects us to do. I say that because he took a similar approach-that we were just philistines; we had no idea; it was an area in which we had no talent at all; we had no instinct in any of these directions; we just signed the cheques. We objected strongly to that patronising attitude of the members of the Australia Council and the members of the Australian National Gallery Council.

That is what I think led to the desire to have an accountability of funding. It was not suggested that we should enter into the area of direct gifting, but it was important that the Parliament should determine certain policy matters. One of the policy matters was that funding should be directed in such a way that it flowed to the very roots of the community; that ordinary people gathering in ordinary places to participate in cultural pursuits should be encouraged and assisted. A sum of $20m was not given merely for the purpose of supplying funds to the great organised companies so that those of us who are better able financially and perhaps by way of some educational background could enjoy what they have to present. I believe that it was not the Parliament's intention that the funds should be so directed as to be limited only in this particular area, as they appear to be now and as they increasingly appear to be.

I now come to support Senator Macklin and the Popular Theatre Troupe. It is a small, grass-roots group which has become, more so at some times than at others, expert in political satire. Its members give us the benefit of their wit and their sharp criticisms. Some of that wit and criticism no doubt hurt the Bjelke- Petersen Government, and in particular that part of the Government which Bjelke- Petersen represents. So, what happened to the Popular Theatre Troupe as a result of its satirical activities? Going back several thousand years, ancient artists and dramatists were superb in this field. These young artists, in their own way, were carrying out something similar, cutting to the very heart of certain political problems and hurting politicians, as they needed to be hurt from time to time, especially in Queensland.

So, what has happened in Queensland? Instead of the Australian Council continuing its support, in spite of criticisms from Queensland and the action of the Department of Education in Queensland in banning this group from various schools, instead of persisting to fund, the Australia Council withdrew the total funding of the group. The Council withdrew it for a reason which I find places that group completely at the mercy of the Bjelke-Petersen reaction, because what the Council did was to say: 'This group has no local funding and, because it has no local funding, we do not fund'. So immediately the group was placed at the mercy of Bjelke-Petersen, because his Government will not fund. In no way will it fund the Popular Theatre Troupe. In no way will it allow that group in some way to contaminate the minds of young school students. So the group is banned from the State schools by the Education Department in Queensland-but not, incidentally, from the private schools, to which it is still invited.

However, because the group received no local funding, the Australia Council did not fund. So when the group says that this was for political reasons, in a way that is correct. The Australia Council has not appreciated the fact that the banning of this groups' activities in Queensland is a political act, and that is why the group gets no funds, and because the Australia Council then refuses to fund it plays the game of Bjelke-Petersen. I am suggesting that while the Australia Council takes decisions of this sort then there has to be some participation by this Parliament. Taking into account the record of the Australia Council and its accountability not only financially but also in relation to policies which it applies, I think we should insist on some participation by this Parliament. I am not suggesting that we should open up the area so that politicians can impose their political weight in order to influence funding in a particular direction. All I am suggesting is that we cannot free the Australia Council from the supervision of this Parliament. Its record shows that we cannot do that. Its action in refusing to fund the Popular Theatre Troupe seems to support what I am saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Georges misunderstood a couple of points I was making. First of all, there is no question that the Australia Council should not be under the supervision of Parliament in regard to its expenditure. It is subject to ordinary audit requirements. We are entitled to ask any questions we like about what it is doing and why it has done it. Senator Georges appears to me to agree that we should not try to tell the Australia Council that it should support a particular organisation in a particular way. If he feels that way-I understood him to say that with regard to the Popular Theatre Troupe although the appeared to contradict himself two or three times- then certainly I agree with him. This suspicion of the Australia Council is a worry. It has led to the problem I referred to earlier. The Government was also suspicious. I understand the Government felt in 1967-77 that the Australia Council was trying to underfund the major national ballet and opera companies as a means of blackmailing the Government into increasing funding for the arts. Whether that was true or not I do not know. That was five years ago. We now have new members of the Australia Council and it has a new structure. Every member of the Council and every member of its boards has been appointed by his Government. I think this Government, at least, should be able to trust the Australia Council .

SPEECH.PARA: It is proper for the Government to give such directives as it likes. Rather than saying that the Australian Ballet should get so much money or the Australian Opera should get specific grants what the Government should do if it wishes is to issue a directive, for example, that the first priority for the Australia Council should be to produce a national opera company of international standard and a national classical ballet company of international standard. That is the sort of directive the Government should give if that is what it wants. That is much more appropriate than giving a specific grant for a purpose. In practice that means that there is no proper check on the funding; it is not looked at for padding; and, there is no accountability by that company for its performance to anyone who is capable of assessing its performance. Maybe we should establish a national drama company. I note that one company in Sydney has declared itself a national drama company. There may well be a case for establishing a national drama company although such a decision should not be made unilaterally by the company itself. These days the ordinary professional funded company cannot take on plays with large casts; they cannot afford to. Maybe there is a case that we should fund one company in Australia that could put on any play that might be reasonable on an Australian stage. That would be a national company. It would not necessarily have to travel but it could be a centre of excellence in that field of the arts. Again, if that is what is required, that would be an appropriate directive for the Government to give to the Australia Council. What it must beware of though is direct political interference in particular grants to particular organisations. That is what I oppose. That is what I understand Senator Georges to oppose too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have followed the debate both on the radio and in the chamber with some interest for some time. For reasons of principle rather than mischief I agree very much with the contribution which Senator Hamer made earlier this evening. Of course, the real point of debate between Senator Hamer and Senator Haines is whether honourable senators have any subsequent rights, if one likes, to raise particular matters and express their opinions about them. Of course they do.
—I accept that.

—As I understand it, that is not the point that Senator Hamer was seeking to make. I was also very interested in Senator Georges' retrospective about the Australia Council. I hope that by next year's estimates he will have forgotten that particular chapter of history and moved on to something else.
—I was reminded about it. I have not said a word in years about it. That was a little bit unfair if I might say so.
—I was here.
—Yes, but I have not said anything since.

—I remember the occasion. Senator Georges has earned his money tonight. In any event, I think it has been a worthwhile and profitable debate. Next year Senator Hamer no doubt will be in control of his own destiny on this question. We will see what support he gets then.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address a few remarks to another area of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, and particularly to certain very important environmental issues which face Australia at present. They include salinity in the River Murray and the general question of land degradation in Australia. Some 55 per cent of the arable land in this country is subject to land degradation of one form or another. They are the sorts of issues which are ongoing, which concern the environment and which concern those engaged in primary industry and so on. I hope we can discuss them further during the estimates of the Department of Primary Industry. They are very important issues in Australia. Governments ought to be doing a little more than they are to alleviate those problems.

The most popular issues in environmental terms at the moment are the future of the Great Barrier Reef, the question of rain forests in Australia and the future of the wilderness area of South West Tasmania. We have been very critical of the time which this Government has taken to declare in full the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. But we do not have any quarrels in principle with the Government over its expressed intentions in relation to the Barrier Reef. The Barrier Reef is one of Australia's greatest natural assets. It is on the World Heritage List. It has enormous potential not only in terms of its intrinsic natural beauty but also in terms of its potential as a resource for Australia. The Australian Labor Party is very anxious to see much greater progress in the declaration of the full marine park. However, we are more currently concerned about the Government' s apparent reluctance, for what I can only assume to be rather sordid political reasons, to adopt the same attitude towards the South West region of Tasmania as has essentially been adopted by the Commonwealth Government towards the Great Barrier Reef. That, of course, involved the question of whether the Government is prepared to have some disagreements with State governments in relation to matters which involve the national heritage of Australia.

I think in a sense the Fraser Government has shown courage in some respects-for example, in respect of Fraser Island-in determining a stance on an important environmental issue contrary to the wishes of a particular State government. We argue that the obligations of the Federal Government in relation to South West Tasmania and the proposed dam on the Franklin River are obligations which a national government should assume for very good reasons. Essentially, those reasons spring from the unique nature of the region and the anticipated inclusion of that region on the World Heritage List-a listing which the present Government supports, the Opposition supports and, I am certain, the Australian Democrats support. The Opposition thought that certain consequences and obligations would flow from that expressed intention in relation to South West Tasmania.

In a sense, this is an important political debate which should be joined not only by people on the mainland of Australia but also by more people in Tasmania. The position of the Tasmanian Government is that it is exclusively for the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian people to determine the issue. Of course, I fully understand that position. Tasmanians should not normally be told what they should do in respect of their future plans for the development or otherwise of their State. But unfortunately there are far more important issues involved in this question than that.

What the current government of Tasmania is in fact saying is that it recognises that there is an enormous economic problem in this State. I am glad that it recognises that there is a problem. I am not sure it realises the full extent of it. It is an enormous economic problem, a problem which involves very high levels of unemployment in Tasmania and, in a sense, the daming of the Franklin River has become perhaps a symbolic solution for Tasmanians to that problem of unemployment. Because the problem of unemployment is so great, the issues relating to the environmental value of the area have been overlooked except by the Tasmanian Government Tourist Bureau. It still advertises in its office windows in Collins Street, Melbourne, 'Come to Tasmania, Australia's last wild region'. The Tasmanian Government is quite prepared to make a quid out of mainland tourists while it can by attracting them to South West Tasmania, and 27 per cent of its tourists go to the South West area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it tell them to hurry up?
—That is precisely the point.
—They go to Strathgordon, by and large, which is the hydro development.
—It is a pity you do not know what you are talking about.
—I am quite sure they go there. I have interjections from two Tasmanian experts. But the Tasmanian Government's figures indicate that 27 per cent of tourists go to the South West region--
—That is right, to Strathgordon.
—Of course they do. But it does not matter, Senator.
—It is a pity that you do not know what you are talking about.
—They go to Lake Pedder.
—If you knew what you were talking about, it would sound much better.

—Do not get excited, Senator Walters. I am not saying they would not go there if the whole island were dammed, but the point is that this is a claim made by the Tasmanian Government by way of advertisements to attract tourist dollars, and that is a very good thing. Of course, what the Government in Tasmania, which if I may say so Senator Walters rises like a whale to defend, is in fact saying is that the damming of the Franklin is the solution to the many severe economic problems which Tasmania has. Effectively, that is what is being said. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) might be able to help us and tell us whether the Department of National Development and Energy has again made revised assessments of the energy needs of Tasmania--
—The present needs?
—Present and future needs, Senator.
—How far into the future would you like to go?

—The present needs, as the honourable senator knows, are declining every day and the estimates of the Department of National Development and Energy have declined in the last year. If the honourable senator does not know that, she ought to.
—That sound like Labor planning to me.

—Senator Walters should ask Senator Sir John Carrick at Question Time tomorrow what the estimates are; she will get an answer from her leader which I am sure will be a very honest answer. I know he is very concerned about this issue. But the mythology of the Tasmanian Government and its troglodytic followers is that at some time in about the 1890s-in the 1990s; that was a freudian slip-because Tasmania has an excess supply of energy, industries will rush to Tasmania and the unemployment problem will be solved. Anybody who knows anything about the potential and actual industrial development of Australia--
—You had better have a chat with Ken Wriedt.
—I have had a chat with Ken Wriedt as long ago as yesterday.
—Order! Senator Button, I would ask that you direct your statements through the Chair.
—You ask me to direct my statements through the Chair? I am having questions fired at me.
—I will protect you if you do.

—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I always look forward to being protected by you. I go back to the point I was trying to make before I was interrupted. The fact of the matter is that there is declining demand for energy in Tasmania. If it is seriously believed that in Tasmania in the 1990s there will be a rush of blood to the head and industry to Tasmania which will be consuming high quantities of energy and that the employment problem in that State will then be solved as a result of that process, I want very seriously to challenge that assumption. If we look at what is happening in manufacturing industry in Australia as a whole, let alone Tasmania, we will see that over the last 15 years there has been a decline of employment in manufacturing industry from something in the order of 28 per cent to 19 per cent. Any industries that are likely to be established in Tasmania in the foreseeable or long distance future will be industries which have minor or relatively minor consumption of energy compared with those industries that are now based there, industries that are closing, such as the Tasmanian Electro-Metallurgical Co. Pty Ltd, Comalco Ltd, which is closing its smelter day by day as it closes down the pot line, Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd, and so on. Those industries are reducing demand.
—Comalco wanted to expand recently.
—Do not confuse him with facts. His mind is made up.

—I say to Senator Walters in a great spirit of charity that I want her to try to follow this debate because she will be right in the middle of it in a couple of years time. If she listens now to what other people are saying she might be better informed. I do not say that what I say is necessarily right. I do not expect the honourable senator to believe that. The point is that I do not think the honourable senator should have a closed mind about the issue because the question of South West Tasmania will be debated on and on. I hope that the honourable senators Government will come to a responsible decision in relation to this matter. It is a mistake for a State to spend a billion dollars effectively in pursuit of mythology about employment. That is what it is because one cannot--
—Have you convinced the Labor Party down there?

—No, we have not. The Federal Government and the Tasmanian Government are united in idiocy about this issue and they are wrong. That is the point I am seeking to make. I am hoping, because I believe that the Federal Government is taking more and more of a responsible attitude to this question as time goes by, that we can have a serious debate about it without trying to score political points about the fact that the Labor Party in Tasmania holds a different attitude from the national Labor Party. I think that it is important that we debate the issue in that context.
—Words like 'idiocy' do not help.

—I am sorry, it is too strong a word, Senator. It would not apply to the honourable senator. The point I seek to make is simply that for thousands upon thousands of Australians who live on the mainland of Australia, the question of South West Tasmania is appropriately in their consideration an environmental one. I would say to those people on the mainland of Australia who are concerned about this matter as an environmental issue that for Tasmanians it is not so much an environmental issue; it is an employment issue. I think people on the mainland of Australia should recognise that. Insofar as many Tasmanians tend to regard it is an employment issue, all I would argue is that I think they are being mislead.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to join in the debate this evening but the contribution of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) makes my entry into this debate mandatory. He, as Leader of the Opposition, was talking about a matter of great importance and great significance to my State and, indeed, to the nation. I do not take the view that the question of South West Tasmania is one for the State of Tasmania only. I believe that it is a very important question indeed. I agree with Senator Button that consideration of these matters ought to take place in an environment free from political point scoring. Yet what have we had over the past 20 minutes? We have had a political point scoring speech. I do not know whether Senator Button was point scoring against the Gray Government or the Wriedt Opposition but they both copped it and everybody in Tasmania copped it. I believe it is for me to stand up and defend some of the people who have been under attack.

SPEECH.PARA: Persons such as Senator Button cannot have it both ways. He, the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and some members of the Liberal Party supported the establishment of a select committee to inquire into the South West . The Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania is in fact undertaking that inquiry. I did not support the establishment of that select committee because I was under the impression, having studied the documentation, that the various inquiries that had been undertaken had established certain incontrovertible facts. Of course, there have been changes in the economy since then and those changes have affected some estimates of the amount of power that will be required within the foreseeable future. But surely the responsibility is on the people of Tasmania to find the power that is required for the industries which employ the bulk of labour in the State of Tasmania? For anybody such as Senator Button to try to enact a reverse onus of proof angle is totally unfair. The onus of proof is well and truly on the likes of Senator Button and those who take a head in the sand approach to employment in Tasmania to say how the power will be generated for the industries that now employ the bulk of people in that State.

I do not leave aside the environmental question. It is a very important question to which I have certainly addressed my mind over a period and been concerned about. Again, how is that environmental question to be solved? Is it suggested by Senator Button, the ALP, the Democrats and some of the Liberals who are a bit queasy about this matter that Tasmanians do not care for their environment? If that is the accusation, I hurl it back into their teeth. The fact is that Tasmanians, particularly those who are involved in the South West, are very concerned about the environment. Senator Button had one of his facts correct. According to Tasmanian Government Tourist Bureau figures, 27 per cent of tourists go to the South West. Where do they go? Twenty-seven per cent of them do not raft down the Franklin River. The 27 per cent go to the hydro development in Strathgordon.

If Senator Button is suggesting that the new road that is being mooted for South West Tasmania will bring another 27 per cent of tourists to the South West , I do not necessarily go along with that. I am concerned about the environment also. But if figures are to be bandied about like that, let us analyse them and see where those 27 per cent of tourists go. I imagine that the majority of them go to see the enlarged Lake Pedder. When we are considering job opportunities, tourism and the like we have to ask ourselves whether those 27 per cent of tourists would go to Lake Pedder if Lake Pedder were as it was 10 years ago. I saw Lake Pedder as it was at that time. It was a marvel. It is a marvel now. It has been opened up to a much larger group of people for their enjoyment.

On the question of the nomination of the South West to the World Heritage List, I wonder whether the Opposition and Senator Button-I am sorry he is not here- will support Senator Mason's World Heritage (Properties Protection) Bill. I say this because I know that Senator Mason will speak after me. If they do, they had better look at what other forms of heritage will be trampled on if that sort of legislation is supported.

Central to a consideration of these issues is the responsibility of the democratic processes to determine what the current generation wants to be done with a particular area, let alone what a future generation wants done with it. Of course, it is important to know what the current generation wants and to decide what is best for and what can be preserved for future generations. But that must be done by people who are answerable to the people of Australia, not by some sub-committee of a committee of the United Nations with residency in Paris. That is ludicrous. But that is where the Opposition is heading with regard to questions of world heritage if it supports the Bill being brought forward by Senator Mason. I have considerable reservations about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —About the economic aspect?

—I have a number of reservations. The onus of proof must be on those who are now saying that the decision of the Tasmanian Parliament is not correct. The onus of proof is on the people who are challenging the almost unanimous decision of the Tasmanian Parliament-the House of Assembly and the Legislative Council. If that decision is challenged, the onus of proof is on those who challenge it to say how we in Tasmania will be provided with the power for the industries which now provide, and which in the foreseeable future are likely to provide, the main sources of employment in that State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Button did not mention is probably more important than the mistakes he made. He did not mention the referendum that was held in our island. He did not mention the subsequent election that was held in our island. He did not mention that, living in our island with completely clean air, we as members of that community are not prepared to forego our hydroelectric scheme for a coal-fired one. This is what is being put to us by mainland conservationists. It is being put to us by conservationists on our island that we should go for a coal-fired power scheme in the Fingal Valley. Anyone who suggests that should not go to the Fingal Valley. The Fingal Valley people feel very sensitive about anyone from the mainland, where the air is very polluted, coming and telling them that they should put up with the same pollution that mainland people put up with just because mainland people say that we should place nearly a quarter of our island on the World Heritage List; that we should ensure that a quarter of our island is not touched and that no one will enter that area except those who are fit enough and young enough to go in on foot. It is an absolutely ludicrous suggestion. I believe, as opposed to Senator Harradine's statement, that this is a State issue. What we do with a quarter of our State has nothing to do with the mainland constitutional situation. People have likened this area to the Great Barrier Reef. The Great Barrier Reef is not part of the Queensland mainland as is this quarter of our State which it is suggested should be handed over to Commonwealth domination.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the referendum, it was the Labor Party Government which set the terms for the referendum. The Liberal Party wanted a no-dam question asked in that referendum. A no-dam question was not asked. I believe it should have been asked. The publicity given to the no-dam question was great. It was given publicity on the Australian Broadcasting Commission every night and on every station. Indeed, Bob Brown received more coverage on which section of the river to dam than the Liberal Party and the Labor Party put together received. The result of the referendum was a good result. There was a considerable no-dam vote , but it was nowhere near enough for a decision to be made in that regard. Sixty -four per cent of voters voted for a dam. A percentage voted for the Gordon- below-Franklin scheme and they carried the day. I remind the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats that we live in a democracy.

Following that referendum an election was held in Tasmania. Not one no-dam candidate won anywhere near the required number of votes to gain a seat. The conservationists stood candidates in every electorate yet not one got up. Surely the claim by the conservationists that the dams were not an issue is a ludicrous claim. If candidates stood in every electorate how could it possibly not be an issue at that election? As I said, not one candidate got up. Consequently the State voted as we believe it should have-that the State Government should have the power to go ahead with the dam.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better tell Malcolm Fraser to keep his nose out of it then.

—As far as I am aware the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has reiterated time and again that this is a State issue. Last time I spoke to the Prime Minister, a fortnight ago-indeed, after the answer by Mr McVeigh to a question from Mr Groom-the Prime Minister reiterated, as I have said before, that it is a State issue. That is where the situation lies at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button spoke in his usual way about a Labor Party plan. Let us have a look at the power needs of the State at the moment. The Labor Party says that at the moment Tasmania does not need a dam so do not build one. That is good farsighted planning. It is typical of the Opposition's normal planning. But we do not consider that sort of planning. The Government of Tasmania is planning for an economic upturn, not the economic downturn that the Federal Opposition, at least, is trying to persuade the Premier will occur.

I will not keep the Committee any longer. I believe that people who live outside Tasmania who want to enter this debate should realise that their State would object very strongly if the Federal Government told them what to do with a quarter of their State. This is the situation that has arisen in Tasmania. Tasmanians disagree entirely with the Federal Government having any say over what should happen to a quarter of their island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate briefly to comment on a few points made by Tasmanian senators in this place. I say at the outset that I respect their points of view. I believe that Tasmania ought to run its own affairs. But I think that Tasmania ought to run its own affairs with reasonable consideration to the fact that they are Australians as well as being Tasmanians. I think that is all anybody asks in this matter. Senator Harradine and others raised the point that I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, introduced the World Heritage (Properties Protection) Bill 1982. I make the point that that Bill merely seeks to put into legislation the undertakings we gave when we entered the International Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage-the World Heritage Convention. When we entered the World Heritage Convention, presumably we did so for a reason or were we just playing games? Do we say that it is all very well for the rest of the world to converve great treasures of the human race so that we can go as tourists and see them but when we have to do it the boot is on the other foot? It appears that when the chips are down we are not prepared to do it. That is what the people of Tasmania are saying now. That is what Tasmanian senators in this place are saying now. They are saying that it is all very well to have human rights conventions and heritage conventions until they are affected. When they are affected they say they propose to tear those conventions up regardless of the opinions of other people of this nation. I hope that we are one nation and that this is something that can be approached in a way which shows us to be one nation and not a discreditable ragtag of small groups, an attitude which has done us considerable harm in many areas in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I and the Australian Democrats want to see this matter proceed on a basis of proper consultation between the governments concerned. We hope to see a reasonable, cool assessment of what is needed and what is required and, particularly, a reasonable assessment of what the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian people need and could properly ask for to see that the Gordon-below- Franklin scheme does not proceed and that alternatives for it which already have been canvassed-if, indeed, they were necessary and that I dispute-should be costed and provided in a dispassionate way.

There is, perhaps, one new thought that I want to contribute to this debate at this time. A great deal of heat is being put into this debate by the fact that, rather perversely, the Hydro-Electric Commission, on instructions from the Tasmanian Liberal Government, is pressing ahead with work in South West Tasmania . It is doing that at a time when it knows it is controversial. It is a deliberate, perverse attempt to provoke other people in Australia who may wish to see South West Tasmania preserved. I appeal at this stage to the Tasmanian Government to please stop that work now. That is a reasonable point of view. This is an issue of great controversy in the community. Why should we not have a cooling-off period? Why should we not have a few months or a year in which to cool off? What difference will it make in the long term whether that is done or not? I will tell the Senate what difference it might make. If we do take that break of a year all of us may avoid making a terrible mistake for political and other reasons. If it is shown at the end of that year that the scheme should proceed, that it is justifiable, then let it proceed at that stage. All I am saying is that in the meantime there should be a halt to it.

The point has been made that the economics are very suspect. The bill will be as high as $1 billion for under 200 megawatts of power. That is something like $ 5m to $6m for a generated megawatt. That is enormously expensive. In the United States solar technolgy is only slightly above that figure. The economies of scale will take it below that figure almost certainly within the next decade. I have had undertakings from people in the United States who know better than I that it will be cheaper and while this dam is being built it will be overtaken by events. We live in a world in which technology in the use of metal is changing. Ceramics and plastics will play an enormous part in the world of the future. The aluminium downturn is not a temporary thing. It is something that will continue. I have checked with the Mitsui company in Tokyo. Representatives of the company have said that within 10 years-it is about the time that this new Gordon-below-Franklin dam will come on stream-they expect to have perfected a process for smelting aluminium in a blast furnace which will use something like 10 per cent to 11 per cent of the power that the present electrolytic system uses. Why should the Government of Tasmania go ahead with this scheme knowing that other methods are being developed? Does it not know about anything going on outside of Tasmania? It would not be a bad idea to see what is going on. This matter has become heated politically and has become a political football. It is a tragedy, because a lot of the ideas we discuss in this place are ephemeral and a lot of them have been created by politicians. This is not one of them. This is an issue of great basic importance. We are discussing something which we cannot correct. If we make this mistake, if we destroy the valuable assets in South West Tasmania, nothing can put them together again. Because of that literally millions of Australians are interested in it. Some weeks ago I walked in a procession in Sydney in the most appalling weather, in rain and wind. Ten thousand people took part. That is not an inconsiderable expression of opinion. I do not think any of those people wanted to 'heavy' the Tasmanian Government or the Tasmanian people. They merely wanted to show Tasmanians that a huge number of people felt strongly about something in Tasmania which is unique and beautiful. I would have thought that Tasmanians would appreciate that their island was thought of by other people as something of great value to society. It seems to me that we do not have that point of view at all. Recent polls have shown that the majority of people in Tasmania do not want the dam. But the politicians in Canberra including, with all respect, some of my colleagues in this place, do not seem to see any of that beauty themselves. To me, that is the greatest tragedy of all. Some people who live in that place do not seem to appreciate this, or if they do, they seem not to want to take any kind of step to protect it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason ended the speech that we have just heard by saying that the South West of Tasmania is unique and beautiful. Have you been there, senator?
—Yes, I have.
—How did you get there?
—Order! The honourable senator will direct his remarks through the Chair.

—I had that trouble myself a short while ago. I will direct my remarks throught the Chair. The point is that any part of the world is unique. There are no two parts of anything that are the same. If Senator Mason stopped to think for a moment, he would recognise that. Any part of the world is unique and beautiful. The South West of Tasmania is unique and beautiful. But we have to remember that in many areas of the world we must have development. For instance, if we tried to build now the road that leads to the top of Mount Wellington, which many thousands of people use to go to look at parts of Tasmania that they would not otherwise be able to see, what would happen? Senator Mason would say: 'Don't scar the mountain. Don't build this because people will go there and throw around their aluminium cans'.
—The South West has been named as a world heritage.

—This has nothing to do with it. I will get to that matter in a minute. More people now can see from the top of Mount Wellington because of the road that was built than ever would have had the opportunity if they had to walk up a track. I have run up some of the tracks in that area and I know what it is like. It is very difficult to walk straight up that hill. That is why I always go round it. But if we go to the South West-
—Did you ever fly up it?

—I did. I am glad that the honourable senator mentioned that. It was one of my successful flights. I got back, which is more, I might say, than happened to a few people who rafted down the Franklin River. Some people in Tasmania have stickers on the back of their cars that say: 'Save a life, dam the Franklin'. That is because so many people have been killed there. It cost a lot of money to get them out.
—Come off it.

—It is true, Senator. It is quite important that people recognise-as I realise-that the South West is a very pleasant area. I was against the damming of Lake Pedder. I was against that for purely engineering reasons. For the expenditure of very little money we could have had a syphon which would not have altered very much at all the amount of water to be collected and Lake Pedder could have been saved. But that is an entirely different thing. That involved the expenditure of an additional $2m and Lake Pedder could have been saved. The thing that must be decided with regard to South West Tasmania is whether we feel that there will be a requirement for more power in Tasmania.
—You will debate that question, will you?

—Give me a go. The honourable senator can have a go in a minute. At the moment the power consumption in Tasmania is down. It is down in a lot of areas of the world. But that is not to say that other areas in the world will not need additional power later on.
—It probably does.

—I would like to borrow Senator Mason's crystal ball one day. He seems to be an expert in a lot of areas. If the honourable senator does not know what an expert is, I will tell him later. Senator Mason seems to be an expert on this matter but I think he is wrong. Let us presume for a moment that Tasmania will need additional power. What would happen if we wanted to obtain atomic power? What would the conservationists and, I presume, Senator Mason, say? They would say: 'You can't do that. You can't have atomic power'.
—That would be absolute insanity.
—It would be absolute insanity. Many Communist countries are turning very rapidly to atomic power.
—Is that what you are saying?
—No, but a lot of countries--
—That would not make it right.
—I was not saying that made it right, Senator. Do not try to put words in my mouth.
—These two-way conversations are very good, but I ask you again to direct your remarks through the Chair.

—Yes, Mr Chairman. That is one alternative. I believe engineers can build atomic power stations with safety devices. But we will not dwell on that subject. I move to the alternative of steam. Where would we get it from? We would be held up by and be a captive of the unions on the mainland, from where the coal was sent to Tasmania. I know that we have some coal. I am not talking about a scheme which would run for a few years only, but something that will last for 50 to 60 years. That is the life of a dam. I doubt that there is enough coal easily obtainable in Tasmania to run a station for that length of time. We could talk about a cable from the mainland to Tasmania. It would have to be twice as long as anything that has been built in the world. It would have to be built in situ. It would take at least 10 years to build and then we would still be captive to the strikes that happen on the mainland.
—We do not have many blackouts in Victoria.

—We do not care whether you have many or any. We have had virtually nil in Tasmania except when there was one fault, but not a strike. One of the best ways for Tasmania to obtain power would be to put all of the hot air we have seen tonight through a turbine. We would do fairly well.
—Or the wind.

—That is right. Those are the only alternatives, other than that offered by the Hydro-Electric Commission. One of the things that has worried me about this situation is if Comalco Aluminium (Bell Bay) Pty Ltd decided to leave the State. I do not believe that the demand for aluminium will remain down, as it presently is. I think it will pick up.
—What about the Mitsui project?

—I will turn to that in a moment. If we presume that Comalco will stay in Tasmania, and if we take the normal progression that has been shown to be the case over the years gone by, very shortly we will need more power. I have read the philosophy of the other smelting process. I have read the patent paper about it. I think that Senator Mason was with us when we went to the Hunter River Valley. We saw the effects of some of the effluents from the smelting process using the electric system of bringing the aluminium up with the flourides.
—With respect, that is the present process.
—I know that that is the present process. From reading the patent my thought, as a pharmacist and chemist--
—And an engineer.

—At least I am not a lawyer. The problems regarding effluents and pollutants from a smelting process, which would admittedly use less power, would be such that we would not want that process in Tasmania. We certainly do not want the pollution that we would get from a coal fired station, irrespective of whether we could get the coal in Tasmania. I agree with Senator Harradine. He said that most of the people in the Government Tourist Bureau figures who go down to the South West use the Hydro-Electric Commission road. They go down the Strathgordon road to the new Lake Pedder. This is a very interesting place to see. I hope that all honourable senators at one stage or another get a chance to see it. As time goes by, and as this other dam is built, I believe more people will be able to go down into that area and see things that they would not otherwise be able to see. If the roads are properly constructed they will help tourism in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the beginning, I am a little of two minds about this matter. I hoped that the area would not need to be dammed and that it could be left in its natural state. If at some stage we are going to need additional power, as I believe we are, I would prefer a hydro scheme to any of the alternatives I have mentioned. I have spoken to many people about this matter. I have spoken to some of the conservation groups and individuals in Tasmania and other places. I believe they are very genuine. The people who have written to me have been quite numerous. I have had more letters on this matter than on anything else from any people, except the Right to Life Association. The people are genuine. Nearly all the letters I have received are hand written and are of a reasonable length. They show a deal of concern. I thank the people for sending me those letters.

I believe this issue was very much decided at the last State election. Perhaps Senator Button was right when he said earlier that the people of Tasmania voted the way they did because they saw the establishment of a dam in southern Tasmania as a means of obtaining a job or helping to keep jobs in that State. I believe that is true. The State Parliament now has the right to make its own decision. I think it would be an impertinence for honourable senators and members of parliament from other States to try to tell the State Government of Tasmania what it should do. I for one will not help them do that. If it is found that I have to come to odds with the Federal Government because of some statement of which I have no knowledge at the moment but which could be made in the future, saying that the Federal Government will interfere, I can assure honourable senators that I will put my State ahead of any allegiance that I have to any party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Tate I remind honourable senators that the Chair has been very tolerant in allowing this all-embracing debate on South West Tasmania in connection with the estimates for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. I remind honourable senators that some honourable senators wish to discuss other matters in respect of the estimates for that Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I will take very much to heart the cautionary note that you sounded at the beginning of my remarks, which will indeed be brief. At this stage I wish to make a plea for some moderation and some sensible discussion of the matter of South West Tasmania in relation to the various issues that have been raised. I think that much of this debate, as it has developed, is less well informed than it will be when the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania reports to this chamber within the next two or three weeks. Then we will be in a position to judge better some of the claims that have been made in the course of the remarks made this evening. I think that on all sides there have been rather intemperate and ill-informed remarks. For example, Senator Harradine spoke of the bulk power users-those who are mainly dependent on the generation of hydro power-as being the employers of the bulk of the Tasmanian work force.
—I did not say that at all.
—That was the understanding which the honourable senator conveyed to most of those people who were listening.
—Well, I did not say it. Have a look in the Hansard tomorrow. I said 'industries which rely on power'. I did not say 'bulk users' at all.
—The honourable senator was speaking of those users--
—I did not say 'bulk users'.
—Mr Chairman, perhaps I can address my remarks to you rather than to Senator Harradine.
—Now start being temperate in your remarks.
—Senator Harradine gave me to understand--
—Where do you stand on this issue?

—If the honourable senator would let me make my remarks he will find out. That is why I am standing in the chamber at the moment. Senator Harradine said that industrial users in Tasmania, dependent as they are on hydroelectric power, employ the great bulk of the Tasmanian work force. I understand that to have been his statement. That is incorrect. The fact is that the bulk of the Tasmanian work force is not employed in the mining or timber using industries which provide manufacturing employment. In fact, manufacturing employment declined from 36,000 in 1968 to some 26,000 in 1980. The 18 bulk consumers employ about only 7 per cent of the work force. I emphasise that the employment fears which are generated in the Tasmanian community really have to be addressed by any of the national parliament in an attempt to come to some sensible assessment of the conflicting claims made about South West Tasmania. I believe we have to be very careful in the sorts of claims we make about users of electricity in the manufacturing sector in Tasmania being great employers of the Tasmanian people. They are not.

SPEECH.PARA: Intemperate remarks were made by Senator Mason. He stated that the Tasmanian Government was pressing ahead with developments in South West Tasmania as part of a deliberate and perverse policy to provoke movements on the mainland in favour of the conservation of the area. The Tasmanian Government is acting in accordance with legislation passed by the Tasmanian Parliament. I believe the Tasmanian Parliament was constituted after an election in which the issues were such that one could say that the Parliament was constituted by a majority of pesons who favoured the construction of the dam.
