To that extent the Tasmanian Government is quite properly carrying out the wishes of the Tasmanian people. The question is whether that is a sufficient perspective to bring to bear on this matter.

I think even Senator Townley would concede that we must look to the future and try to make some projections about the type of power, the scope and the necessary increase in the availability of power that Tasmania might need in order to secure the economic future of Tasmanians, and when it will be needed. I entirely agree with Senator Townley. This has to be understood by people on the mainland. If further power is required to be generated for the future of the Tasmanian economy and those dependent on it, then it has to be hydro power because no solution will be acceptable within the Tasmanian community unless it deals with the very real fears of those involved in the Hydro-Electric Commission as engineers or as part of the construction work force or in the industries and towns which are dependent on hydroelectric activity. For that reason I think it will be extremely important that as we search for an economically viable alternative project to that put forward in relation to the Lower Gordon scheme, we look for a project which employs the skills and the work force which can be assembled by the Hydro-Electric Commission. Therefore, I warn people on the mainland that they ought to put out of consideration altogether any thought of a thermal power station being acceptable to Tasmanians. If we are to seek, as responsibly we must, an alternative to the present scheme, it must be a project which employs those skills.

It may be, for example, that the Arthur River project in north-west Tasmania could be such a project. It would provide 80 megawatts of power and would employ those skills and a considerable work force. It would have spin-off effects in the economy of Braddon electorate on the north-west coast of Tasmania, which would be extremely important as employment opportunities in that area become more depressed day by day. At the same time, it would relieve the stress on the environment of South West Tasmania which is of concern to others in the community. In other words, if we are to have a sensible, moderate discussion I believe that it should proceed, and would proceed, to a much better degree in the light of the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which will be with us shortly. It should take into account the very real considerations which I have put forward.

The fact is also that there needs to be a realisation that the present Fraser Federal Liberal Government has taken such steps that it is incumbent upon it to indicate what the consequences of the steps it has initiated are in relation to Tasmania. It is the present Fraser Liberal Government which has pressed for the listing of South West Tasmania on the World Heritage List. The nomination has gone forward. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has refused to withdraw that nomination. The consequence of that identification and listing is that there is an obligation on the national Government of Australia, whether it be Liberal or Labor, to do what is within its power to preserve that area listed on the World Heritage List.

That step having been taken by the Fraser Liberal Government, the Labor Party has only been acting responsibly and honestly in relation to the Tasmanian people in saying that as a consequence of that it will explore with the Tasmanian Government alternative economically viable power generation projects with the aim of their funding on terms comparable to those which would have applied for the proposed South West Tasmanian power generation development project. It is incumbent on a national Government, whether Labor or Liberal, to indicate clearly to the Tasmanian people that if an alternative hydroelectric scheme is to be developed-I say if power is to be provided it must be a hydro scheme-it must be provided on such terms that the Tasmanian consumer of electricity will not bear a greater burden in loan repayments than that consumer would bear if the Gordon-below-Franklin scheme were to go ahead. That is the absolute minimum basis for any responsible national Government to take to this question.

Of course, it is quite true that one would need a further contextual package of proposals in order to ensure that Tasmania's regional economic and industrial development is enhanced considerably. That requires perhaps a general approach and also a more particular one. The general approach would be to ensure that total Federal payments to Tasmania do not fall in real terms because at the moment the real threat to the employment of Tasmanians lies in the decision of the Grants Commission, to be implemented over time by the national Government, which will see a diminution in the percentage of revenues available to Tasmania and corresponding increase in the revenues available to New South Wales and Victoria. That is where the real danger to the future employment of Tasmanians lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Federal Labor Party agrees with that.
—The Federal Labor Party does not agree with that. Point No. 2 of the policy announced on Monday states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ensure that total Federal payments to Tasmania do not fall in real terms.

The Federal Parliamentary Labor Party is committed to maintaining those real payments to Tasmania from the Federal Treasury. The surrounding context for the maintenance of employment within the Tasmanian economy is the crucial key. On the more particular aspect it will be incumbent on the national Government to encourage the Tasmanian Government in co-operation with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, to establish a South West Tasmanian management authority that will be responsible for managing the area in a way which creates employment opportunities and enables Tasmanians and Australians to move into that area for the recreational and other attractions it has. This is where the Labor Party will not be supporting in its present form the Australian Democrats' Bill concerning the World Heritage List areas. It is too extreme and seems to place any area on that list, whether it be the Great Barrier Reef, the Kakadu National Park or South West Tasmania, outside the scope of human activity altogether. We would see a very real place for a co-operative management authority, as is the case with the Great Barrier Reef and the Kakadu National Park, which would have a capacity to create a situation within which tourist accommodation could be built and other steps taken in order to assist, particularly on the west coast of Tasmania, in developments which would create employment through the spin-off effects of tourist activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can amend the Bill that way, senator. It is subject to amendment.

—I am responding to the question posed earlier in the debate as to whether the Labor Party will support the Democrats' Bill. I am saying it will not support the Bill in its present form. Apparently, it is subject to modification and we will certainly be moving amendments to try to create a situation in which not all human activity is excluded from the area but in which a proper management plan can operate in a way that is compatible with the area's listing on the World Heritage List. As I have said, perhaps this debate is premature in the sense that the chamber does await a report of one of its own committees. When that report is made I hope to expand more fully some of the thoughts I have just outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very remiss of me, as a Tasmanian senator, not to participate in this debate because the implications of the listing of South West Tasmania on the World Heritage List could be very serious within Tasmania. It is unfortunate that this issue of listing and the problems associated with the locations of the dams and the generation of electricity in the South West wilderness area have been so divisive in our society, not only in Tasmania but throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When this issue was first raised in the very early days of the formulation of a plan to provide sufficient power for Tasmania's industries, I could see some benefits in distributing the available limited sources of finance as widely as possible. I am on the record as having said in those days that I could see some benefits in some small dams. In politics one puts forward a view but it is not always accepted. The Tasmanian Government has made a decision. It held a referendum on the issue. It is continuing to pursue a major project. I fully support what Mr Gray and his Government are trying to do. It would be tragic for Tasmania, from an economic point of view, if the project were not to go ahead. Tasmania has the highest unemployment in Australia. The Opposition is trying to pull the rug out economically from under a State which is finding it difficult to provide adequate jobs for so many young people.

Many people lose sight of the economic plight and difficulties facing many Tasmanian families. We all know of the major exodus of young people to the mainland. I think this is a tragedy. We have to try to find jobs for these young people in Tasmania. It has been reported that in the next few years we will have to find an additional 30,000 jobs. One of the problems in the past has been that so many industries have not been able to get a block of power at a reasonable price from the Hydro-Electric Commission of Tasmania. Consequently, many decisions have been made not to extend Tasmanian operations. In other words, the development has taken place on the mainland and not in Tasmania. Mr Gray and his Government are seeking to reverse that situation. Many people are trying to stop that development. If they do so it will adversely affect Tasmania's economy.

We have already heard many comments that Tasmania is getting more than its fair share. Whilst some people say that Tasmania should be compensated if these plans do not go ahead, the compensation might be held in good faith for a few years but, in the long term, can we be assured that it would continue? I believe we have to follow the path which will lead to something constructive, so that we can offer power with some assurance that it will be available for those industries that wish to come to Tasmania and for those that wish to expand. Hydroelectric power is non-polluting. Some of the options that have been put up by some of its opponents are quite frightening. They have suggested bringing coal from the mainland, with all the attendant problems of maritime strikes, and sighting a thermal station in the Tamar Valley. The Tamar Valley is well known for its problems of fog. What would we have then? We would have smog in that area. Many of these people call themselves conservationists. We are trying to keep our State beautiful. One way to do that is to have a non-pollutant source of hydro-electric power. We should be aiming to try to harmonise this scheme as well as we possibly can with the whole landscape.

One conservationist put a very constructive suggestion to me. He suggested that the road system should follow the valley which will subsequently be flooded and, in that event, when the scheme is completed there would not be a scar on the landscape. In future the station would be serviced by barge or motor boat. I think this is a manner in which the conservationists could play a very constructive role in harmonising the site of the power scheme with nature. I believe that the scheme will actually increase the percentage of tourists going to Tasmania.

One of the unfortunate features of this whole debate is that there has not been a great deal of accuracy in the reporting of the extent to which damage will be caused to the South West of Tasmania. As has been pointed out, the claims have been extravagant. I think this is one of the unfortunate features. If this debate does anything, I hope it will bring a greater degree of honesty to all those people participating to make sure that the facts are accurate. I appeal to everybody to try to harmonise the scheme which is now well under way rather than fight a sabotage or rearguard action which will have detrimental effects on the people of Tasmania and their employment opportunities. I think at this time when we are trying to create jobs-we had a debate on that issue this afternoon-it is important that we go ahead and create jobs for Tasmanians who want to live in Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button commenced his speach on the estimates of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment by seeking some information from the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) as to revised estimates concerning power consumption in Tasmania. How that was in any way relevant to divisions 330 to 349 of the estimates is beyond me. Nevertheless, I was not here for the whole time in which Senator Button spoke and no doubt with his capability he would have been able to make it relevant. However, his speech sparked off a debate. I apologise to the Committee for attempting to answer to a certain extent some of the points that were made by Senator Button. I recognise that this should not be a wide-ranging debate on South West Tasmania. If we are to have a wide-ranging debate on South West Tasmania he must let me know and I will join in it with a bit more preparation than I have tonight. But this is not a wide-ranging debate on South West Tasmania. I subscribe to the statement made by Senator Tate that such a debate should be informed and not intemperate. With respect, Senator Tate should speak to his leader because, on both counts, his leader failed in respect of this particular matter--
—Lamentably.

—Self-evidently. I maintain that Senator Tate failed in those particular tests because if intemperate means being incorrect and accusing somebody of doing something that he has not done, Senator Tate has been intemperate for it was he who suggested that I had indicated that the majority of employees in Tasmania are employed by bulk users of electric power. I did no such thing. I made no such statement. What I did say, of course, was that a very important issue in this whole debate is the need for power for those industries- I did not say manufacturing industries, much less bulk industries-which employ the bulk of Tasmanian workers. The onus of proof is very much on the people who are trying to overturn outside Tasmania decisions taken democratically within the State of Tasmania by the majority--
—A sovereign State.
—Senator, I do not want to go into that because I think if we- -
—Senator Harradine should direct his remarks to the Minister and to the Chair.

—Mr Chairman, I do not think we ought to talk too much about sovereign States and constitutional questions. It is more a political and a democratic question than a constitutional one in my view. Decisions have been made by the people of Tasmania, the House of Assembly and the Legislative Council. I suggest that the onus of proof is on those who take a different view. It is not for people to say to us: 'What are you going to do about the south west Tasmania?' Once these decisions have been taken through the normal democratic process they should say: 'Well, if there is another avenue, this is that other avenue and it will be cheaper, more convenient and more effective than the one that is proposed'. They should then outline clearly how that is to be done. I would ask Senator Tate, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to check what the Labor Party spokesman said when the Commonwealth Grants Commission made its statement earlier this year and compare that statement, which, as I recall, was one of approval, with the statement made here tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that so far as the environment and divisions 330 and 349 are concerned there is a marvellous area of environment down near Strahan. Amongst a number of concerns that I have had about this question was the effect that it will have on tourism in Strahan, for example. These are the issues to which we ought to be directing our attention in this debate on the votes for the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and not asking about revised schedules for power usage in the State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I wonder whether I could seek leave for a specific purpose. I am aware that the Senate has finished consideration of the departments in group B. I was in my room listening to the debate and was expecting another speaker after Senator Watson. I was caught a little on the hop. There were two items that I wanted to raise in relation to the report of Estimates Committee B, just briefly, which were not specific to any of the departments. I seek the leave of the Senate now to take a couple of minutes to cover those items.
—You will not be going over any matter that has been debated, Senator?
—No.
—But you want to deal with a matter specific to the Committee itself.
—Specific to the Committee's report.
—Leave is sought.
—The officers have gone.
—This does not involve officers.
—As long as it is understood that the officers have left in good faith.
—We have the understanding that Senator Martin will not be dealing with any matter except a matter pertinent to the Committee itself.

—The two matters I wanted to raise briefly relate to reports to Parliament and to the Hansards for Estimates committee reports. In Estimates Committee B a great deal of information was sought and was obtained from all the departments relative to reports. The information sought related to time that was taken, both for reports for 1981-82 and 1980-81, for approval of form of accounts from the Minister for Finance, time that was taken for approval of accounts by the Auditor-General, time that was taken by the printer, and then dates on which the report was given to a Minister and tabled in Parliament. I thank the departments for the full information provided on these matters, but I want to comment briefly because the timing of tabling of reports has been a matter of concern to the Senate for some time. However, I believe that it has a particular relevance to Estimates committees and it would be useful to have a number of these reports before Estimates committees commence their deliberations . One reason that it would be useful is that it would save a great deal of time in Estimates committees if senators had received the reports and could read certain matters relating to the departments' activities, the statutory authorities' activities and other bodies' activities for the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a couple of points. In the information that has been provided, very clearly, different departments and authorities have different ideas of when it would be desirable for reports to be tabled in Parliament. For example, Telecom Australia, in the summary that it provided, shows that it expects that its reports would be tabled in October or November, whereas the schedule provided by the Australian Broadcasting Commission shows that it would be possible, adhering to the schedule set for this year, for a report to be tabled in September. As I have gone through all these summaries of the reports it has seemed to me that there is very rarely a case for reports to be quite as late as they are. It seems that some departments and authorities have the idea that so long as the report for, say, the 1981-82 financial year is tabled before Parliament rises at the end of November, they have met the necessary objective. That is certainly preferable to tabling it much later, but I think that it would be more useful to the Parliament if we had them a little earlier. In the past the issue of interim reports has been raised with the purpose that reports should not be delayed in their tabling in Parliament just pending the Auditor- General's final certificate. Not very many departments or authorities do this. I should like to say again that I think that the Senate should press the issue that there are more reports that could be tabled in this manner.

The final point I make about this is that there seem to be some extraordinary discrepancies in the time various reports take to be printed. I give as an instance the Cocos (Keeling) Island report for 1980-81. It was submitted to the printer on 7 August 1981 and received back from the printer on 10 December 1981. That is more than three months for printing, and it meant that the report was not tabled in Parliament until February 1982. A report which I believe would be comparable, the Norfolk Island report, was submitted to the printer on 30 September 1981 and received back from the printer on 13 October 1981-only two weeks later-and consequently was able to be tabled in Parliament by 22 October 1981, which is a far handier tabling time.

As I went through these summaries it appeared that the average length of time for receiving reports from the printer was about a month but that the variation could be as wide as from two weeks to three months. There is, unfortunately, no indication of where these reports were printed, or whether any priority on an early delivery of a report was placed. But if it is that certain printers-I am not sure how many reports the Government Printer prints-are faster than others, that would be interesting, although I think that it is not feasible to get all that information back. What could be done is that this matter might be drawn to the attention of those responsible for the printing of reports to indicate that a speedy return of reports is something that Parliament would appreciate and that it would serve some useful purpose.

The other item that I wanted to raise-and it is raised in the report of Estimates Committee B-was the delay this year in senators receiving copies of Estimates committees Hansards. Estimates Committee B met on four occasions, and I was not aware of the delay that now happens with Estimates committees Hansards so I did not keep a note of how much later the report arrived after the first meeting of the Committee, which was on, I think, either 6 or 7 September. The Hansard for the Estimates Committee B meeting of 13 September was not received until 21 September, eight days later. The Hansard for the hearing on 14 September was not received until 22 September, again a delay of eight days. I did not receive my copy of the Hansard for the hearing of 16 September until 12 October. Part of the reason for that long interval was the fact that the Senate had been in recess for two weeks. My receiving it was delayed by two weeks. Nevertheless, there was still a substantial delay between 16 September and the date on which the Senate adjourned for that two-week recess.

That four-week delay and the other lengthy delays had two effects. One was that neither I nor the other members of the Committee could check, first, whether the Hansard was accurate, and secondly, just what items were raised. There were items about which I wanted further information. The third effect was that departments did not have the Hansard record available to them so they were delayed in getting information to the Committee. Estimates Committee B was in the position that by the time it was required to report to the Senate in September it did not have available to it the Hansard for its hearing of 16 September. Items were raised at that meeting which I, for one, would have liked included in the report. I think they should have gone into the report. I made some unofficial inquiries as to the reasons for the delays in Senate Estimates Committee Hansards. I was told that it was at least partly attributable to the fact that the Government Printing Office has changed its method of printing. A report was tabled in this Parliament, I think two or three weeks ago, relating to changes in the Government Printing Office. Some rather bland assurances were contained in the report that the changes would not upset the printing system.

I would like whoever is responsible for this matter-I suspect that it is Mr President rather than a Minister-to investigate the delays in the publishing of Hansard for Senate Estimates committees and to find out whether we can get them with the promptness that we used to. Admittedly, they never came out quite as promptly as the daily Hansards but they were not far behind. Two days was the most we ever had to wait, so far as I can remember. I believe this delay has been a disadvantage to members of Estimates committees because proper follow- through action on issues they raised could not take place. The fact that the Hansards have not been available has disadvantaged not only members of the committees but also the departments which need to have the Hansards available to them to find out the precise nature of questions raised by senators in response to which they were required to provide further information. It is only in the last few days that the last lot of answers to questions raised in Estimates Committee B hearings were made available to members of that Committee and tabled in the Senate. I believe that has had a very deleterious effect on the operations of certain Estimates committees. I certainly claim that this is so in relation to Estimates Committee B. Since Estimates committees are an important function of the Senate, I believe this is a matter of some urgency. It should be given prompt attention and this place should be given a reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I want to do so in the context of some comments made by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Peacock) on 28 April 1981 regarding the operation of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I do so in the spirit of trying to elicit whether any major changes have been made to the system of operation of the Department since Mr Peacock made that speech and, if no changes have been made, to inquire whether the system is operating in the same way now and whether the Minister in charge of this debate, the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), agrees with the comments made by Mr Peacock on that date. I refer the Committee to the Hansard of 28 April last year. Mr Peacock, who had formerly been Minister for Industrial Relations, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Over recent months I have concluded that the Prime Minister is fracturing Cabinet government and the parliamentary system as we know it. Our system of government will operate only if there is a responsble relationship between the Cabinet and the Parliament. Our present system has deteriorated because that relationship has foundered. It has foundered because the Prime Minister increasingly centralised power around himself. Any erosion of the Cabinet system goes to the heart of the parliamentary process.

I refer to that passage of the Minister's speech because it is always a matter of concern here when we discuss, as we sometimes do, the role of the Senate in acting as some check on the Executive Government of the day. It is possible that what was said by the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Industry and Commerce, was in some respects incorrect. What I am more concerned to find out is whether there have been any changes in some of the processes which were described on that day by the Minister. At page 1609 of the Hansard, of the same date, Mr Peacock said:

The Prime Minister's role in having decisions reversed in the absence of the responsible Minister is totally contrary to the principles of Cabinet government . It is inexplicable, save by reference to the Prime Minister's obstinate determination to get his own way although undermining the authority of a senior Minister.
He went on to say:
On the day I resigned I said the Prime Minister had by-passed the system of Government.

He then went on to make some comments about the structure of so-called Cabinet government evolved by the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He referred to the formation of various formal committees and the existence of a powerful new element, the Co-ordination Committee. He referred to the desirability of a Prime Minister consulting with Cabinet, particularly with the Cabinet Ministers directly concerned. At page 1610, in describing the system which operates in the Government according to Mr Peacock, he said:

This is not just a kitchen Cabinet; it is a formal structure crushing the Cabinet system. Added to this, individual Ministers are lobbied by the Prime Minister. That is a principle of proper Cabinet government that should not happen.
Further on at the same page, he said:

Liberalism distrusts concentration of power . . . Therefore, the ever increasing centralisation of power is striking at the heart and core of liberalism . . . I believe the growth of centralised power within our Government today is restricting effective formulation of policies required by Australia.

Of course, we in the Opposition frequently are accused of being critical about these matters when we say that a very grave restriction has been imposed on the effective formulation of policies required by Australia; in fact there has been the absence of formulation of policies required by Australia. If we spend a lot of time debating those issues in the Senate then maybe we are wasting our time if the allegations made by Mr Peacock regarding the operation of the Cabinet system in Australia are correct. It is for that reason I want to pursue this matter. It would be wrong for the Senate to continue to debate policies if the entire fault can be corrected by alterations to the way in which the Cabinet system operates under the present Prime Minister and by alterations to some of the committee systems which the present Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Peacock,-I must add he is my own member of Parliament-has raised from time to time. In considering the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I would merely ask whether any significant changes have been made to the operation of the Cabinet system, whether the Government or Ministers in the Government are still of the view that liberalism distrusts concentration of power, whether, in fact, under this Government there has been a centralisation of power which strikes at the core of liberalism and whether the consequence of that is restricting effective formulation of policies required by Australia.

Perhaps it might be said that these questions are not relevant to the estimates for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Of course, they are relevant in the sense that the Prime Minister has a well known penchant for hiring consultants. In his own office he has a significantly high level of staff turnover which involves costs being imposed on the Department and on the taxpayer. If the advice which the Prime Minister gets is from outside consultants who are paid high salaries and there is a high turnover of those consultants, they are matters which are of concern or should be of concern to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. More importantly, of course, it would be nice to have some statement from the Government about whether the allegations which were made in April 1981 and not, as I understand it, denied by anybody except the Prime Minister in a rather oblique sort of way, are in fact correct-that government in Australia still suffers from the great disabilities and inhibitions described by Mr Peacock at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of matters in relation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in terms of what Senator Button was saying a moment ago. I asked at the hearings of Senate Estimates Committee C, based on the annual report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, whether possibly a 31.9 per cent staff turnover per year was a bad thing in terms of cohesive administration. I think the general reply was along the lines that the reason for that turnover is that they like a turnover in terms of cross-fertilisation of ideas. I realise that the Government has been fairly bankrupt in ideas and that maybe some cross-fertilisation would be a good thing. But it probably also leads to the introduction of the many new schemes of the Government which are inconsistent with the previous ones. It is probably the reason why we have had six health schemes in seven years and why there is so much turnaround in government performance. Senator Button has already indicated just how important the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, with its mini-Cabinet system, is in the formulation of policy. Therefore, I think that staff turnover is not a good thing, but I will leave it at that.

SPEECH.PARA: The other question I wanted to raise tonight relates to the fact that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet employs 59 consultants at an average cost of $6,500. This is the biggest growth industry in the Estimates, apart from computers. In total the Government is currently employing 2,699 consultants. The total cost of the consultants for the Government-this information has been provided by another department-works out at $52,051,213. I think we are getting to a stage at which the Government will be hiring consultants to determine which consultant it should hire. The average cost of those 2,699 consultants is $19,000 a year.

There are some examples I should like to quote. The National Gallery has 10 consultants, at an average cost of $45,000; the Department of Social Security has seven consultants at an average cost of $35,000; the National Capital Development Commission has 314 consultants at an average cost of $27,000. We can go through every department, down to the Institute of Multicultural Affairs which has 50 consultants at an average cost of $4,000 each. I have also noticed that the Department of Aviation has eight consultants at an average cost of $88, 000. This raises the question of why the Government is hiring so many consultants when in fact it is trying to institute staff ceilings at other levels. I ask the question: Why cannot the Government use the expertise in the Public Service without constantly having to go outside the Service? I believe there is a case for occasional use of consultants, but 2,699 seems a lot.

The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet uses consultants in the following manner: the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, three; the Office of National Assessment, one; Commonwealth Ombudsman, nil; the Australian Science and Technology Council, five; the Advisory Council for Intergovernment Relations, four; the Auditor-General's Office, two; the Public Service Office, 45. I suppose the real question is why the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet uses so few consultants compared with other departments. Its record is not particularly bad in the use of consultants compared with, say, the Department of Transport and Construction, which uses 1,400 consultants. There are many other departments which use consultants and if honourable senators want further information on this matter they can look at the additional information provided to Estimates Committee C. I raise the question of consultants because it is a worry to those of us who served on Estimates Committee C. Every department, every section, is hiring more and more consultants at an ever increasing cost. I do not think this is a particularly good trend. I believe that the expertise could be developed in the Public Service to minimise the number of consultants being hired. I would hate to think that the staff freeze in government departments is forcing those departments to use consultants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button raised some matters relating to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. He quoted at length from a statement of a former Minister. I do not know that what was quoted was of any great relevance. The former Minister is now the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Peacock). I have no comment to make on something that Senator Button quoted from 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner, Senator Button raised the matter of the staff of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. He stated that the staff of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet had increased by 79 per cent over a period of three or four years. I think the figures ought to be placed on record. If we look at the year ended 30 June 1977, the core staff of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-this figure relates to the Department itself and not to some of the other bodies attached to it-was 473. In 1978 the figure was 456; in 1979, 448; in 1980, 442; in 1981, 441 and in 1982, 431. For 1983 the projected figure is 421. Those figures show a reduction over the period from 1977 to 1983 of about 10 per cent. I think perhaps Senator Button had some other information which was not accurate. I simply place on record those figures of the staff ceilings of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet during that period.

Senator Robert Ray raised matters that he raised at the Estimates Committee hearings. With regard to the consultants for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, as he later commented, he was interested in the very few consultants who are engaged by that Department. But could I say that in general the consultants that are used by government for its services are sometimes required because of a need for expertise outside the Public Service. Before consultants are appointed, there is a general practice of consulting with the Public Service Board and agreement by it to such appointment. Of course, as part of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, a number of decisions were taken that may have required consultants to be appointed for particular reasons. In general the range of expertise within the Public Service is very wide indeed. But from time to time, for instance to service an inquiry or a committee, there may be a requirement for consultants to be appointed. This is done in a prescribed way which maximises the use of the expertise within the Public Service and, with the consultation that is undertaken with the Board, I think is conducted in a satisfactory manner. I have no further comment to make on matters that were raised on this Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will recall that a number of questions were raised in Estimates Committee C about the sum of $1.5 billion that was set aside by the Government for Treasury to spend in respect of matters relevant to the 1982-83 Budget. The Committee extracted some assurances from the Minister that very close attention would be given to the way in which this money would be spent. A considerable amount of attention in the survey which was carried out was directed to obtaining a public reaction to the Budget. It would be a fair comment to say that members of the Senate Estimates Committee felt that there was a direct relationship between the survey being carried out and the premature election that was mooted at that time. One has only to recall that for the last two or three months the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has kept the Parliament and the nation on tenterhooks about an early election. In more recent times the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) has refused to confirm or deny the Government's intention to call an unnecessarily early election.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was concerned that this survey was prepared with the direct intention of obtaining voter reaction to the Budget to see whether the political climate would be favourable to the Government with a view to making a decision to call a November or December election. We were equally concerned about the unspecified nature of an allocation of $1.5m to Treasury for the purposes of publicity associated with the 1982-83 Budget. There seems to be a link between the survey funding and the $1.5m. The Committee was not given any indication of how that money was to be spent or for what purpose it was sought. Such a large sum of money was set aside without any planning or any reasons being given for that sort of vote. It is true that the Minister finally made available a statement. But it has been somewhat alarming to find that the Treasury has been rather reluctant to be caught in a party political slanging match about the $1. 5m.

The Government was finally forced to make a decision that the campaign to spend the $1.5m would proceed only after the South Australian election because it was clearly a very sensitive area. Of course, now it can be said that it is still a very sensitive area in view of the fact that in a few weeks time the people in the Federal electorate of Flinders will be called upon to record a vote in a by- election there. Clearly, the senior public servants in Treasury felt some sensitivity about this matter. That was echoed by the Estimates Committee. One would have thought we could have been provided with the program and the schedule of how such moneys would be spent. In a period when we were told that there needed to be a cut-back in public sector spending and there needed to be restraint, we were asked to give an open cheque to Treasury, about which Treasury was clearly unhappy. Press reports indicate that the Government was the body that made the decision and that the Public Service heads had serious misgivings about this sum of money being spent in this way. In other words, taxpayers' money was seen by the Treasury officials as being used for party political purposes. Indeed, that was the view of members of the Opposition on the Senate Estimates Committee. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
Progress reported.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American school children and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of media reports of school children in the United States of America having gained access illegally, through the use of publicly accessible telephone or data transmission networks, to confidential computer records in that country.
(2), (4) and (5) It is not possible for access to be obtained to the Department of Finance's computer systems in this way.
(3) The Department of Finance uses various security measures to safeguard against unauthorised access for its computers, including:
Restricted access to the building housing the computers;
Further restricting access to the Computer Centre to authorised persons;
Centralised control and storage of data files;
Strict controls over the removal of computer tapes and disks from the computer centre and disposal of computer print-out; and
Stringent hardware and software controls on access to the computer from remote terminals. 'Dial-up' connection is not possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does section 107K (1) of the Repatriation Act deem a person to be a regular serviceman if he has completed three years full-time service, regardless of whether that period of service was before or after 7 December 1972, provided that his service had not ended before that date; if so, does it follow that there is no such thing as a period of 'eligible service' for the grant of a pension or acceptance of a disability for a regular serviceman.

(2) Are the Repatriation Commission boards and tribunals interpreting 'eligible service' in respect of serving and retired members of the regular forces to include only that service on or after 7 December 1972 plus the completion of three years full-time service on or after that date.

(3) If this interpretation by the boards and tribunals is incorrect, will the Minister instruct; (a) all levels of the claims and appeals system that a disabled regular (or retired regular) serviceman may apply to have his disabilities accepted as service related irrespective of when the disabilities occurred during this service, and (b) that all claims or appeals previously rejected on the basis of this incorrect interpretation should now be allowed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 107K of the Repatriation Act defines a regular serviceman in terms as outlined by the honourable senator, but it does not follow that there is no such thing as a period of 'eligible service'. Eligibility for pension under the Repatriation Act arises under section 107M and that eligibility is only in respect of incapacity or death that has arisen out of or is attributable to defence service. Defence service is defined in section 107J as continuous full time service as a member of the Defence Force on or after 7 December 1972 and, therefore, 'eligible service', as used administratively within the Repatriation system, applies only to service on or after that date.

(2) No, while the Repatriation boards, the Commission and the Tribunal apply the principle of 'eligible service' only in respect of a period on or after 7 December 1972, in accordance with the definition of 'defence service' in section 107J, it is only necessary that a regular serviceman with a continuous period of service of three years or more has served on or after 7 December 1972 to be eligible for consideration. There is no requirement as implied in the question that the whole qualifying period of three years of service itself be completed on or after that date.
(3) The Repatriation boards, the Commission and the Tribunal apply the above principles which, I am advised, represent the correct application of the provisions of the Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 13 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to difficulties which are being experienced by prawn fishermen on the far north coast of New South Wales, whose trawls have been entangled in long lines from Japanese tuna boats.
(2) What action is being taken by the Government to protect the livelihood of Australian fishermen and safeguard their equipment and catches in this important area of the New South Wales coastline.
(3) Is a new tuna fishing agreement now in the course of negotiation between Australia and Japan and is this agreement to come into operation on 1 November 1982.
(4) What steps are being taken during the negotiations to see that the rights of Australian fishermen to fish in Australian territorial waters are not interfered with in any way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) In response to representations from Australian fishermen the matter of conflict between the operations of Japanese longliners and Australian prawn trawlers off the north coast of New South Wales was taken up with the Embassy of Japan in Canberra. The Embassy was advised of the nature of the problem and their co-operation was sought to ensure that Japanese longliners avoided operating in the area where the conflict was reported.

Subsequently special surveillance operations were undertaken and an official of the Department of Primary Industry travelled to the area to further investigate the extent of the problem. The matter was then raised with Japanese officials and industry representatives during the course of the recently concluded negotiations on a new 12 month tuna access Agreement to come into force from 1 November 1982.

As a consequence of these discussions the Japanese Government has now agreed to an expansion of existing full year closures off the north coast of New South Wales to avoid further conflict with local trawl and trap fishermen. The area in which further closures will apply extends from Smoky Cape to Byron Bay out to a distance generally between 20 and 30 nautical miles from the coast.

(4) Prior to negotiations on any arrangement involving foreign commercial fishing vessels operating in the Australian fishing zone the relevant State and Territory governments as well as fishing industry representatives, are consulted . These consultations are undertaken to ensure, as far as possible, that the operations of foreign fishing vessels do not conflict or compete with those of Australian fishermen. In addition representatives of State and Territory Governments and the Australian Fishing Industry Council are invited to attend the negotiations as observers.

As a general rule foreign fishing vessels are prohibited from operating within 12 nautical miles of the Australian coast and are therefore not permitted to operate in Australia's three-mile territorial sea.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are any imported live virus strains currently being held in Queensland, for purposes of scientific research; if so, what are those strains and where are they being held.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department assesses requests for importation of viruses and grants import licences when appropriate. A search of departmental records has shown that the following live virus strains have been imported into institutions in Queensland for scientific research since 1972 and are still held by those laboratories.
Dengue virus (strains 1, 2, 3 and 4)-Queensland Institute of Medical Research
Ross River virus-Queensland Institute of Medical Research
Human polyarthritis virus-Queensland Institute of Medical Research

(2) Before licensing the import of viruses, my Department must be satisfied with the precautions to be adopted by the receiving laboratory for the handling of the viruses. These must meet appropriate safety standards. The level of security enforced is dependent upon the type of virus (that is exotic or non- exotic, pathogenic or non-pathogenic), the status of the institution and the purpose of the importation. The institution applying for importation may be inspected by quarantine staff prior to approval to ensure that adequate security precautions exist and that staff are aware of virus containment procedures. Restrictions are placed upon the use of the virus depending upon its nature, and set procedures which are contingent upon a licence being granted must be observed in disposing of the virus when no longer required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The procedures under which Social Security Appeals Tribunals operate in each State provide that the Tribunal should provide to the appellant in cases coming before the Tribunal a copy of the written submission lodged with the Tribunal by the Department of Social Security. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) If medical evidence is involved in an appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, can that evidence be handed to anyone other than the appellant's doctor; if not, and the appellant has no doctor, how does the appellant obtain that information.
(2) Would the Minister for Social Security consider changing the rules to allow access to all information relevant to an appeal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The procedures under which the Social Security Appeals Tribunals operate provide that appellants in cases coming before the Tribunal should receive a copy of the written submission lodged with the Tribunal by the Department of Social Security. Where the decision in question involves a medical assessment, that submission should note all available medical reports and opinions, indicating which support and which do not support the decision subject to appeal .

In addition, copies of medical reports and any other documents provided by an appellant will be furnished upon request to the appellant, and other medical reports will be provided to a medical practitioner nominated by the appellant on a doctor-to-doctor basis where the reporting doctor consents. The nominated practitioner is then able to determine whether or not the disclosure of any of that information to the appellant might be prejudicial to the physical or mental health or well-being of the appellant. The medical practitioner nominated by the appellant need not necessarily be the appellant's treating doctor.

(2) The operating procedures of Social Security Appeals Tribunals, both in relation to access to records of the Department of Social Security and generally , are currently under review by my Department in consultation with the Tribunals .

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1981 (Hansard, page 721) Senator Martyr asked the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It is in four parts. Firstly, is it correct that the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance relating to the registration of births and deaths does not concern itself with the birth or death of children of less than 20 weeks gestation or weighing less than 400 grams? Secondly, is it correct that children of less than 20 weeks gestation are capable of being born alive? If delivered alive, is there any legal obligation placed on medical staff in the Australian Capital Territory to attempt to maintain and save the lives of such children? Thirdly, does the Australian Capital Territory have any Ordinance similar in purpose and effect to the Infant Life Preservation Act of the United Kingdom? Finally, does the Australian Capital Territory Transplantation and Anatomy Ordinance 1978 exclude from its control human ova, human embryos, human foetuses and tissue or organs obtained from them? Is there any Australian Capital Territory Ordinance or law which exercises control over such material?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, divided into its constituent parts:

Part 1-Section 5 of the Registration of Births, Deaths and Marriages Ordinance 1963 defines a child to include a child not born alive, being a child-if the period of gestation is reliably ascertainable-of not less than 22 weeks gestation or, in any other case weighing not less than 500 grammes at birth. All provisions in the Ordinance concerning the birth and death of children are limited by this definition.
Part 2 (a)-Foetuses of less than 20 weeks gestation can be born alive but they do not survive. The shortest known gestation period for a baby which has survived is 25 weeks.

Part 2 (b)-There may well be a legal obligation on medical staff in the ACT to undertake reasonable efforts to maintain and save them as living beings. The extent of the obligation would depend upon the current state of medical knowledge and the medical facilities available. The obligation may arise otherwise than under statute. It is not my function to give legal advice to private individuals, or private Senators and Members, and for that reason I decline to answer this question more specifically.

Part 3-There is no Australian Capital Territory legislation in terms similar to the Infant Life (Preservation) Act (UK). However, section 82 and 83 of the Crimes Act 1900 (NSW) in its application to the Australian Capital Territory make it a felony, punishable by penal servitude for ten years, to unlawfully procure a miscarriage.

Part 4 (a)-The Ordinance excludes tissue which is foetal tissue, spermatozoa or ova only from the provisions of Part II of the Ordinance. That Part regulates donations of tissue by living persons. The remaining provisions of the Ordinance apply to all material within the definition of 'tissue', which is defined in section 4 of the Ordinance as including 'an organ, or part, of a human body or a substance extracted from, or from a part of, the human body'.

Part 4 (b)-Human ova, human embryos, human foetuses and tissue or organs obtained from them would fall within the definition of 'tissue' in the Transplantation and Anatomy Ordinance 1978. Other laws of the Australian Capital Territory may have application to this material, for example, as noted in the reply to question 3, there are circumstances in which some provisions of the criminal law may be applicable. There is, however, no other statute law which is expressly concerned with this material.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1910) Senator Childs asked me , as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, by saying that having a telephonist with local knowledge is vital to country people when they ring their local telephone exchange in emergency and natural disaster situations. Is it a fact that the Tweed Heads telephone exchange is due to be closed on 3 November? Is this one of the 16 telephone exchanges in New South Wales due to be closed in the near future? Did the Prime Minister intervene to prevent the Hamilton exchange in his electorate in Victoria being closed? Will special consideration be given to the Tweed Heads exchange which is in the electorate of the Deputy Prime Minister? Will the Minister give urgent consideration to providing special assistance to Telecom in order that 16 country exchanges in New South Wales will not be closed?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Although a number of manual assistance centres will be closed over the next three years there will be no decline in service. Introduction of new equipment will mean that a call for assistance will often be handled by an operator some distance away from the areas from which the call originates, but in such cases, the operator will have access to all the information necessary to process the enquiry. Emergency 000 calls will not be handled in this way but will be directed to the nearest available manual assistance centre where operators will be able to reach the required emergency authority.
(i) The answer to the first question is Yes.
(ii) The answer to the second question is Yes. However, as a result of a Telecom review, only 14 of the previously designated 16 manual assistance centres will now be closed in New South Wales.

(iii) The answer to the third question is No. What the Prime Minister did do was to pass on to the Minister for Communications the Hamilton community's concern about possible job losses and reduced services. This, together with similar expressions of concern from other areas led to Telecom being asked to re-examine its original plans. Nine additional centres will now be retained as a result of this review and the Hamilton exchange is one of these.
(iv) The Tweed Heads manual assistance centre received the same considerations that were applied to all other centres. It is scheduled to be closed in November 1982.

(v) The revised plan shows a positive approach by Telecom to the social employment and economic issues of rationalising the use of manual assistance centres throughout Australia. The plan which now provides for the closure of 22 centres around Australia will ensure that not only will there be no decline in service, but improvements in technology and operating procedures will provide customers with speedier responses.

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Attorney-General inform the Senate what procedures were used and are currently being used by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth or any other State capital to report on action to be taken or any investigation, opinion or any other matter being handled by that office. I ask the Attorney- General for the titles of any such reports and to whom they have been sent. Do these reports in fact go to the Crown Solicitor's Office in Canberra? If not, where are they sent? How regularly are reports sent? Has any direction been given by the Crown Solicitor's Office on action to be taken on any such reports received from the Perth office or any other office? Have any such reports been directed to the Attorney-General or his Department for attention? Were any such reports or copies thereof forwarded to the Australian Taxation Office?
The Acting Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Monthly Returns of Business and Monthly Returns of Important Litigation have been, and are currently being, sent by the Deputy Crown Solicitors to the Crown Solicitor. The form of Monthly Return of Business currently in use was brought into operation in July 1978. The form of Monthly Return of Important Litigation currently in use was brought into operation in 1979. It is the responsibility of the Divisional Manager to monitor these returns. The Returns are not forwarded to other Departments or to the Australian Taxation Office. In addition to Monthly Returns, Deputy Crown Solicitors are required to provide day-to-day reports of litigation raising constitutional or other important issues and matters of political significance. The Deputy Crown Solicitors also correspond with the Crown Solicitor from time to time on individual cases. Directions are given, as appropriate, by the Crown Solicitor. Correspondence from a Deputy Crown Solicitor on an individual case is, where appropriate, submitted to the Attorney-General. Such correspondence is in appropriate cases used as a basis for correspondence between the Crown Solicitor and the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1982 (Hansard, page 774) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the management of Telecom Australia is proposing to close the public terminal for telegram and telex services at the Brisbane General Post Office? Is the Minister aware that in the whole of Queensland this is the only public facility where a telegram or a telex can be sent 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and that this service has existed for the benefit of the people of Queensland since Federation? In view of the great importance to individuals in times of family crises and of national disasters, whose only means of communication is a public facility, will the Minister ensure that at least this one facility remains in Brisbane? Furthermore, with the Commonwealth Games imminent, will the Minister ensure that action is taken immediately to retain this facility? Will he also see that adequate ISD telephone services, which are not available at present, become available in Brisbane before the Games?
The Minister for Communications has provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

In an effort to reduce the loss being experienced with the public telegram service-currently about $20m annually-Telecom is conducting an on-going program of reviews aimed at ensuring that public telegram rates reflect the costs of operating the service and that these costs are kept to the minimum consistent with the maintenance of an acceptable standard of service for customers.

As part of this program, consideration is being given to the feasibility of centralising in a few telegraph offices the handling of after-hours telegrams currently being handled at some of the smaller 24-hour telegraph offices. Any such proposal would only change the way in which the service was provided and would have minimal effect on customer service. However, in accordance with a previous undertaking, Telecom will be discussing the outcome of this review with the Minister for Communications.

The honourable senator may be assured that Telecom appreciates the importance of the telegram service, both under emergency conditions and to those who do not have readily available alternative means of communication.

During the Commonwealth Games Telecom provided a comprehensive range of telecommunications services to ensure the success of the Games. The facilities provided by Telecom were commented upon very favourably by the organisers and visitors to the various Games sites.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 September 1982, (Hansard, page 860) Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources , the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In the interests of the Australian canned fruit industry and having regard to that industry's declining export markets, will the Government give consideration to lifting the ban on cruise vessels of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Is not the Government's action having a detrimental effect on the Australian canning fruit industry and its growers in particular.
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government is well aware of the proposition that sales of canned fruits could be made to the Soviet Union should Australia relax its ban on Soviet cruise ships. These reports appear to have originated from an Australian trading company.

The Soviet Union does not normally purchase canned fruit from hard currency sources. I am advised that the latest statistics available suggest that Soviet imports in the last few years came almost exclusively from Bulgaria and Hungary -that is COMECON partners of the USSR. It is therefore open to question as to why the USSR should wish to import canned fruit from a hard currency source like Australia.
The measures adopted subsequent to events in Afghanistan and Poland do not in any way preclude Australian firms from establishing contractual arrangements with the Soviet Union.

I am concerned about the difficult circumstances being experienced by the Australian canned fruits industry. In this regard the Government is providing short-term assistance to growers in the 1982 season by way of carry-on finance and tree-pull assistance. The Government, through the Trade Commissioner Service will also provide the industry with all possible assistance to find commercial export markets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1039) Senator Lajovic asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In view of the announcement by the Treasurer that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) will resume the collection of statistics on foreign ownership and control, will the Minister ask the Treasurer to ensure that the ABS improves, clarifies and refines those terms in order to prevent the confusion, obscurity and controversy contained in the previous interpretation of what is foreign ownership or control, which totally misinformed the general public.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The ABS has examined a number of matters related to the resumption of foreign participation studies, including the most appropriate statistical definitions of foreign ownership and control. In this examination, the ABS sought the views of major private and public sector users of the foreign participation statistics and, as far as possible, took their views into account.

The ABS concluded that, for statistical purposes, it was unavoidable for the definitions of both foreign ownership and control to be based mainly on specified degrees of ownership. While the decisions of an enterprise can be influenced by a variety of means other than voting rights directly associated with ownership, it is not practicable to introduce such considerations into the definition of foreign control. Consequently, the definitions of foreign ownership and control will be similar to those used in previously published statistics.

Nevertheless, in response to requests and comments regarding the statistics, the Statistician has decided to provide separate figures wherever possible in future for the following two categories of enterprises which would otherwise be classified as foreign-controlled:

(a) joint Australian/foreign-controlled enterprises, i.e. enterprises in which a single foreign resident individual or foreign-controlled enterprise holds at least 25 per cent of the number of voting shares but where this holding is equalled by a single Australian resident or Australian-controlled enterprise; and
(b) Companies publicly announced by the Commonwealth Government as being ' naturalised' or 'naturalising' for foreign investment policy purposes.

To the extent that confidentially restrictions preclude separate figures being published for each of these categories, they will be combined for publication purposes with the foreign control category. It is hoped that recent amendments to the Census and Statistics Act will facilitate minimisation of such confidentiality restrictions by means of companies giving consent to publication of specified data.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1113) Senator McLaren asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It refers to Government claims that ministerial power to dismiss members of the various statutory bodies for impropriety applies only to impropriety committed as a board member. Does section 19 (2) (e) of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act give the Treasurer power to terminate an appointment on the ground that it is not in the best interests of the Corporation that the director continue in office? Did the Prime Minister say on 2 June that the dismissal of tax evaders from Government positions was a matter for the relevant Ministers? Given that the Treasurer has both the statutory power and prime ministerial sanction, why has he failed to remove Mr Denis Horgan from his position in the Australian Industry Development Corporation?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Senator McLaren's reference to the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act is correct.

The Prime Minister did not say on 2 June 1982 that the dismissal of tax evaders from government positions was a matter for the relevant Ministers. What he did say was that matters in relation to the public offices held by any such person should be referred to the Minister concerned. The Prime Minister went on to add that it was also a question of the accuracy of the particular allegation and this should not necessarily be assumed.
As I indicated in the House of Representatives on 23 September, 1982 the mere naming of people in reports is not of itself a reason why somebody should be removed from a particular body.

As mentioned in my joint statement also on 23 September 1982 with Mr Horgan, firm arrangements have been made between the Government and Mr Horgan for an inquiry to be undertaken by a leading counsel, nominated independently by the President of the Law Council of Australia, into transactions involving the sale of companies which have been referred to in tax allegations made against Mr Horgan under parliamentary privilege. This inquiry will determine whether any action of Mr Horgan's in respect of those transactions was illegal, dishonest or a conflict of private interest and public duty.
In accordance with those arrangements, the Acting Attorney-General, Mr Neil Brown Q.C., announced on 11 October, 1982 that the inquiry would be conducted by Mr J. W. Von Doussa, Q.C., of Adelaide.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1107) Senator Douglas McClelland asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned escalating stock feed prices and possible abuse of the Commonwealth's drought aid initiatives.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

The current severe drought in the eastern States of Australia has increased demand for stock feed. At the same time drought conditions have reduced supply. Under these circumstances there is bound to be some increase in prices. The Fodder Subsidy Scheme initiated by the Commonwealth has been designed so that fodder prices do not escalate as a result of its introduction. The subsidy is based on the nutritive value of fodder relative to wheat, the price of which is primarily the result of conditions in the international wheat market. If prices of non-wheat fodders increase then farmers will logically turn to wheat or lesser priced grains for drought feeding.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Closer Economic Relations with New Zealand

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1195) Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Vanuatu: Use of Ports by Soviet Warships

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1609) Senator Teague asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, a question in relation to statements allegedly made by the Prime Minister of Vanuatu, Father Walter Lini, concerning the availability of Vanuatu's ports to the Soviet Navy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am now able to provide further information regarding the statements attributed to the Vanuatu Prime Minister, Father Walter Lini. These statements appeared in reports of a conversation with journalists in Suva after the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting.
On his return to Vanuatu, Father Walter Lini held a Press conference on 22 October 1982, during which he referred to Press reports of his alleged remarks in Suva and made the following statement:

'Vanuatu is a neutral country and as such will respond fairly to any legitimate request for ships of any nation to enter our territorial waters on legitimate business. We will not permit nuclear powered vessels or nuclear armed vessels in our territorial waters. This policy applies to all countries Russia or America.'
Australia recognises that decisions by sovereign states of the South Pacific about relations with foreign countries are properly ones for them to take.
We for our part have made clear our view that we would not wish to see a projection of Soviet naval power into the South Pacific, which would serve to destabilise this peaceful area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment visualise Australia, by the year 2000, having over one million hectares of pine plantations, largely comprising of Monterey Pine.
(2) Would not such pine forest expansion seriously deplete our existing native forests.
(3) What percentage of this pine forest expansion will develop from repurchased farmlands rather than from the demolition of native forests.
(4) What effect will (1) above have on Australian wildlife habitat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Matters concerning forestry policies are within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Primary Industry. The answer to parts 1, 2 and 3 of the question are based on advice provided to my Department by the Department of Primary Industry.
(1) Yes. If current trends continue Australia will have in excess of one million hectares of pine plantations by the year 2000, of which Monterey Pine would comprise the major proportion.

(2) No. The expansion beyond the present area of about 750,000 hectares would represent approximately 1 per cent of the 40.8 million hectares of existing native forest and a proportion of such planting would in any case be on previously cleared land.

(3) Not known. Decisions about forest management are primarily the responsibility of State governments. The proportion will depend on State government policies and the availability of farm lands in the future.

(4) The effect will vary according to the circumstances of particular plantations, but in total it would be small, having regard to the relatively small area of softwood plantation in relation to the area of native forests.
