QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How are the President, Deputy Presidents and all the other members of the Repatriation Review Tribunal selected and appointed.
(2) What is the present composition of the Tribunal and how many members are there from each State.
(3) Is every effort made to ensure that all States are adequately represented on the Tribunal.
(4) How are the Chairman and two members of the State Repatriation Boards selected and appointed.
(5) Is the ex-servicemen's member always chosen from senior officers, or is it possible, or usual, for lower ranks to be appointed.
(6) What is the present composition of the Queensland Repatriation Board and are they all Queenslanders; if not, what reason is there for appointing members from another State.
(7) Is the Queensland Repatriation Board based in Queensland; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The appointment of members (including the President and Deputy Presidents) of the Repatriation Review Tribunal is provided for in section 107VZH of the Repatriation Act 1920.

Vacancies of Deputy President and member on the Repatriation Review Tribunal are advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and national Press. From time to time, ex-service organisations are invited to submit lists of names of persons from which appointments as Services member may be made.
(2) The composition of the Tribunal as at 1 October 1982 was as follows:
Acting President Mr B. Virtue Sydney
Deputy Presidents Mr L. B. Foley Sydney
Mr B. J. Locke (part time) Sydney
Mr A. G. Knox (part time) Sydney
Members Mr E. D. Hirst Sydney
Mr I. M. Green (part time) Melbourne
Services Members Mr L. R. Flynn Sydney
Mr J. L. Merson (part time) Sydney
Mr D. F. Gilson (part time) Sydney
Mr C. J. Fagan (part time) Melbourne
Mr D. M. Tehan (part time) Melbourne
There are also 71 part time medical members and these are located in all States .
(3) State of origin is not a determining factor in the selection process. The Tribunal has permanent offices in Sydney and Melbourne. The President arranges sittings, as required, in other cities.
(4) The establishment and constitution of Repatriation Boards and the appointment of members of Repatriation Boards are provided for in section 14 of the Repatriation Act 1920.

Permanent vacancies on Repatriation Boards are normally advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and national Press. In addition, in accordance with the provisions of the Repatriation Act, ex-service organisations are invited to submit lists of names of persons from whom appointments as Services member may be made. The Repatriation Commission makes recommendations to the Governor-General under section 14 of the Repatriation Act for the appointment of members.

(7) No. 7 Repatriation Board is based in Brisbane. From time to time an additional Board is transferred from interstate to assist in coping with workload when this is justified.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware:

(a) That there is no mechanism for the Commissioner of Taxation to expedite the resolution of genuine differences between taxpayers and the Commissioner of Taxation which result in the raising of an objection; and
(b) that, under the new arrangements, the taxpayer has to pay 100 per cent of the tax on the item in dispute until such a dispute has been resolved.

(2) Has the Government given consideration to either expediting the Board of Review mechanisms or increasing the number of Boards of review in order to cope with the increase in workload due partly to the inexperience of staff as a consequence of the transfer of assessing staff to tax evasion sections.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourble senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Special units have been established in each branch office of the Australian Taxation Office to deal with objections as expeditiously as possible after the objections have been lodged. Some 90 per cent of all objections received are resolved by these special units.

The remaining 10 per cent of objections which lead to references to a Board of Review or appeals to a court are handled in specialist appeals sections in each of the branch offices. Again, only a very small proportion of these cases ever reaches the taxation Boards of Review or the courts.
Once a case is referred to a Board of Review or a court the time at which that case will be heard is a matter to be determined by the Board or court.

(b) It is true that under the new provisions relating to the payment of tax, provision is made for an increase in the rate of penalty tax for late payment to increase from 10 per cent to 20 per cent per annum. This increase is part of a general review of the level of penalties imposed for breaches of the taxation laws and which have remained unchanged for many years. The new rate of 20 per cent per annum will apply to a taxpayer who does not pay his tax by the due date for payment notwithstanding that all or part of the tax may be in dispute. However, where a taxpayer pays tax that is the subject of a dispute and subsequently succeeds in his objection or appeal against a disputed assessment, he will be paid interest on the disputed amount that is required to be repaid to him by the Commissioner. This matter was canvassed in the Treasurer's Press release number 151 of 10 August 1982.

(2) In his Press release number 151 of 10 August 1982 the Treasurer announced that he was having discussions with the Commissioner of Taxation into ways in which the time taken in settlement of disputes with taxpayers might be reduced. Those discussions are continuing. It is not accepted that the increase in workload of the Boards of Review is due in any way to the inexperience of staff of the Australian Taxation Office. It is due to a very large extent to the adoption of the dispute procedures of the income tax law by a number of taxpayers who see these as an opportunity to artificially delay the payment of tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 570) Senator MacGibbon asked me as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Have any estimates been made of the cost in man hours, supervision, computer time, printing, postage and the like in assessing a taxation return from a pensioner who is $2.60 a week above the tax threshold? Would the tax levied in this case come near to covering the costs involved?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Treasurer has advised me that costs of processing various types of return are not maintained by the Taxation Office. Estimates of the cost of collecting income tax are provided in the Commissioner's Annual Report to Parliament. In recent years costs have represented less than one per cent of revenue collected . It would be possible to express total outlays on a cost per return basis but the resulting figure would not be particularly meaningful in the context of the honourable senator's question as it would of necessity be an average cost covering many different types of returns.

I might also point out that all individuals with incomes exceeding the minimum taxable amount are required to lodge income tax returns. Consequently the Commissioner of Taxation has no discretion but to process the return and issue any resulting assessment regardless of the revenue involved. Obviously it is inherent in a system incorporating a minimum taxable amount that some taxable incomes will be very close to that amount and some far in excess of it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1982 (Hansard, page 281) Senator Colston asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Sunday Mail of 15 August 1982 which describes Queensland as the nation's company tax haven? How has the Federal Government allowed this situation to develop? Has any investigation been made of the tax dodging schemes outlined in the Sunday Mail article? If so, has any action been taken against these schemes?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The newspaper article referred to by Senator Colston pointed out that Queensland's tax haven status is based on limited partnerships.

Limited partnerships, as provided for in the Mercantile Act of Queensland, have for many years been an accepted means by which groups of individuals or companies with a common interest can establish and conduct legitimate business. The use of limited partnerships therefore does not necessarily raise tax avoidance implications.

There is cause for concern, however, when the special feasures of limited partnerships are exploited for tax avoidance purposes. The Commissioner of Taxation is well aware of the manner in which this exploitation can occur and his officers carefully scrutinize the affairs of limited partnerships. The kinds of arrangements mentioned in the article have been the subject of the Commissioner's inquiries. Where a tax avoidance scheme is identified, it is the practice of the Commissioner to take all administrative steps necessary to contest its effectiveness and where appropriate to bring to the Government's attention any weaknesses in the law that are being exploited to the detriment of the revenue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1110) Senator Coleman asked me as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question relates to health insurance when a de facto partner pays family rates, even though there are no children involved, which she or he then claims for taxation purposes. I ask, is the Minister aware that this type of claim is not being allowed, at least not by the Australian Taxation Office in Perth? In a recent communication from that Office, one of my constituents was informed:
The basic health insurance rebate applied only to premiums which secure entitlement to basic benefits for the taxpayer on his/her legally married spouse.

Will the Minister advise when we can expect amending legislation to remove such phrases as 'legally married spouse' from the Income Tax Assessment Act, thereby avoiding the current confusion which exists in other legislation?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Under the health insurance rebate provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act, a partner in a de facto relationship is excluded from the category of dependants in respect of whom a taxpayer is eligible to claim the rebate. A taxpayer with children who obtains family health insurance cover is, however, still entitled to the rebate for the total amount paid for basic hospital and/ or medical benefits. Where a taxpayer does not have children, each party in the de facto relationship can claim the rebate in respect of individual health insurance cover obtained. There are no proposals to change the health insurance rebate provision to include de facto partners in the category of dependants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1982 (Hansard, pages 1613-4) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question, without notice, concerning the waiving of charges for admission to the Australian National Gallery on certain occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian National Gallery has advised that there is an established practice amongst European institutions which charge admission for there to be one day per week when entry is free for everyone. The experience in those institutions has been such that these free days place considerable pressures on security staff. It is also relevant to note that most galleries which have free days are closed to the public for one day a week, whereas the Australian National Gallery is open seven days a week.

The honourable senator will, no doubt, be aware that the Gallery recently announced that, by arrangement with Esso Australia Ltd, the Gallery will be open to the public free of charge, for a three hour period, from 5.00 p.m. to 8 .00 p.m., on Thursday evenings from 4 November 1982 to 10 March 1983 inclusive.

In relation to the general admission charge of $2.00, the categories of persons exempt from this fee are as follows: children under 15, full-time students, persons in receipt of pensions, benefits or allowances under the Social Security Act 1947 and the Repatriation Act 1920 and their dependants, and members of the Australian National Gallery Association.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1609) Senator Foreman asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When does the Government intend to bring down its decision on whether to grant increased temporary assistance to Kelvinator?
(2) Is the Government deliberately holding back its decision until after the South Australian State election on 6 November?

(3) If so, are we to assume that Kelvinator, like the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, will not be granted the additional protection it requires and the company will be forced to retrench 400 workers immediately after the State elections?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
(1) The Government announced its decision on temporary assistance for room air conditioners on 27 October 1982.

The Government accepted the Temporary Assistance Authority's recommendation that temporary assistance, in the form of a production bounty, should be provided for certain refrigerated room air conditioners of a kind used for domestic purposes.
Details of the temporary assistance arrangements are contained in the Press statement by the Minister for Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Administrative Services on 27 October 1982.
(2) and (3) There has been no delay by the Government in taking a decision on this matter.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Credit Union and Building Society Cheques

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October 1982 (Hansard, pages 1789-90) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice regarding claims by credit unions and permanent building societies that they are disadvantaged under the bank account debits tax arrangements by comparison with banks.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is a fact that 'cheques' drawn by banks (including savings banks) will not give rise to a liability to bank account debits tax while 'cheques' drawn by credit unions, building societies and, where relevant, other non-bank financial institutions will do so. To see this position in proper perspective, however, it is necessary to have regard for the general context of the tax and the operating modes of all the institutions concerned. I have given assurances to the credit union movement that the Government does not wish the tax to cause serious disadvantage to credit unions (or, for that matter, to other non-bank financial institutions). The Government accordingly will be closely monitoring the situation and keeping the legislation under review.
